reviews.review: A great temple complex. The temple complex has lots of tourists visit, but it also has many people going to worship there. We had an eight course vegetarian meal at the restaurant and it was very good. The inside and outside of the buildings had many things to see. A good day out!

Great experience. Our family visited the monastery on a guided tour while on a Royal Caribbean cruise. We absolutely loved the experience. The buildings are gorgeous with vibrant colours and carvings. The highlight of the visit was taking heaps of photos and selfies with the big budda. The view is beautiful from the hill when the budda sits. Our guide was very informative about the monastery and the background of the budda. A must see if in Hong Kong!

Inspiring place. The monastery is well worth a visit and if you can link up with a guided tour there is a lot to learn. There are many people there paying their respects to the dead and incense abounds. The buildings are elaborate and colorful with lots of symbolic icons and paintings. There are three places to eat: a cafe, a VIP restaurant and a regular restaurant. All serve delicious vegetarian food.

The Giant Buddha worth the walk... Myself and my wife both enjoyed the visit to the monastery and the Giant Buddha ..plenty to look at and see as guests of the 800 or so monks that live there...some small shops and water available..made for interesting talk later about the philosophy of Buddha..

A fascinating place to visit.. We visited The Po Lin Monastery as part of a cultural tour we did. Although there were a lot of people visiting that day the place had a serenity about it, We got there by cable car that takes about 25 mins and affords excellent views of the airport and the countryside. I have a fear of heights but I was OK because we didn't have the crystal cable car so our floor wasn't glass. The big Buddha Statue is magnificent and if you are feeling fit you can climb the stairs to get a closer look. The monastery is noted for it's vegetarian food although we didn't try it it may be worth looking into. There are quite a few tourist type shops and some eating places where you get off the cable car. If you have a free half day then I would certainly recommend a trip to Po Lin monastery. You can catch a train from Kowloon.

Peaceful experience. Hongkong offers a vast choice of structured tours and we chose to go off on our own to Lantau which was a super decision. There was a short line for the cable car tickets (which we could have avoided if we had gone with a tour) but the wait gave us a chance to review the various ticket options. The cable car ride in the transparent botttom car was outstanding. The view of the airport and dense greenery on the hills and then over the water - every minute of the ride is worth it. One can spot the Buddha in the distance and its a mesmerizing sight! We spent time leisurely in the shopping arcade, resto/cafes and the gardens around the monastery before climbing the steps to the Buddha. Enjoy the tranquility and try to ignore the hoards of tourists clicking photographs endlessly. While returning, we stopped at the Citygate mall for outlets shopping and dining before heading back to the city.Excellent day trip!

if in HK you can't miss it!. If you are tarvelling to HK and you have half a day of spare time you can't miss this mistic and awesome place. You can' reach it by getting to Lantau Island by MTR and then the attracation begins by taking the cable car up to the mountain.When you reach the top you walk across the various awesome Monastery buldings which lead you to long stairs climbing up the hill where the giant Buddha statue is sitting.AWESOME!
That one big budda. It was pretty cool, the budda was huge, the view was great, it is definitely worth the time to visit this site

Go for the vegetarian food if nothing else. Sounds funny but finding a pure vegetarian eatery in HK-China was a pleasant surprise. One can have a set meal or pick and choose like we did.We loved the food.Was pretty reasonably priced too.The monastery itself was calm.and serene.

Climb the steps to the top. A must when in Hong Kong. The cable car gives the best views of the area and approach to the Buddha. We did the boat trip and saw Pink Dolphins! Lovely little shops around the Monastery. Wonderful view from the Buddha.
peaceful. Take the time to walk through at a leisurely pace. A whole lot to see. Vast temples and the smell of incense everywhere.

Have your hiking shoes ready for this one =P. The hike wasn't the easiest, but it was definitely worth it! This is such a beautiful and magical place to visit. As my siblings and I were hiking up the steps, we see people praying step by step up the stairway. If you are visiting Hong Kong, you must visit PoLin Monastery.

Beautiful if touristy . Took the bus from Mui Wo which was easy and very cheap. Arrived in the morning mist with the local cows scattered around the stone statues. Climbing to the giant Buddha got the heart pumping but it's an impressive sight. Good views from the top as you expect.Plaza below had places to buy incense sticks and ice cream\souvenirs etc. Was v reasonably priced.The main temple itself is beautiful. The ball of 10000 buddhas is truly amazing and in stark contrast to the outside world. You can buy meal tickets which I must admit we did t fully understand. Plenty of people saying though. Walked the 'fun' and 'wisdom' paths on the way to the yha. I preferred the wisdom as it takes you to the sculpture of wood. Word of warning though we were bitten multiple times in v short period of time. The but spray is a must here!

Colourful & Serene. Going to this place is an excellent leg stretcher away from Hong Kong crowds...they have a vegetarian restaurant that serves good and cheap food...half a day would be enough for Ngong ping village and Po Lin

Beautiful. The bus ride to get there is insane but once you are there, it is amazing. Beautiful scenery and very helpful staff. The vegetarian restaurant was helpful although the food ranged from very nice to quite challenging
lots of stairs. lots and lots of stairs and lots and lots of tourists... lovely to see, some very over priced stalls - it was a nice day out

nice day out. Situated in Lantau island, which is a fantastic islands for the sceneries, is part of a day out in landscapes and nature, specially if you reach that place with the cable car in a sunny day.

Amazing place. if your legs are strong . go all the way up. Amazing place. if your legs are strong . go all the way up.amazing view. it would have been better if the weather was cold and not extremely hot

Amazing Sculpture. Very calm place, have to go through a rope way which is out of the world, very peaceful, neat and clean, must go when you are in Hong Kong, one of the major tourist attractions out there.

An experience to remember. It's important to note, Po Lin Monastery is only a piece of what many refer to as Ngong Ping 360. The cable car, Ngong Ping Village, Po Lin and Tian Tan Buddha are all separate and deserve individual reviews. Po Lin Monastery was an experience I will carry with me for years to come. I would highly recommend Po Lin and Tian Tan Buddha if you have any amount of time in Hong Kong, to include a lengthy layover at HKG. I am not a religious person, but even I found myself moved by the natural and manmade beauty that is Po Lin Monastery and the surrounding grounds. I visited during a three day trip to Hong Kong, dedicating a Tuesday morning to the Ngong Ping total experience. At noon on this particular weekday, the crowds were non-existent and the morning drizzle / fog cover only added to my enlightened experience. Give yourself at least two hours just to wander the grounds without specifically visiting any number of temples or the monastery. For a small donation, visitors are offered a snack or meal to visit Tian Tan Buddha interior and eat at Po Lin Monastery. I opted for the snack and was pleasantly surprised at the food selections offered. There are also numerous dogs that call Po Lin Monastery home. Having recently lost my two dogs, I found one in particular to shadow me for part of the visit. I took it as a sign that things will be ok, and that was something I needed.The colors and architecture of Po Lin Monastery are incredible. I wish I would have spent more time here, or researched more specifically on the grounds. I would return for a second visit and highly recommend for anyone religious or not to spend time here. It was a moving experience and I thank everyone for their hospitality there.
Worth a visit.. The monastery is beautiful and a very calm and serene experience. Definitely worth a visit to the Lantau Island!

Worth A Visit - at anytime in Hong Kong. Even you're local, it is still great to relax and visit The Giant Buddha and local sceneries next to it. You'll feel it's a calm and peaceful place. Great food and some presents to buy too.

Magnificent setting.. The hills around this enormous statue of Buddha give this place a truly majestic feeling. Walking up the 250+ steps is definitely worth it to see this amazing work of religious art up close, as well as savouring the view out to sea and some of the smaller statues surrounding it. Inside there are exhibitions and some more beautiful artwork, which are l worth having a look at too.

As part of the Nong-Ping 360. If you are already planning to visit Lantau Island and Big Buddha, the monastery is just right next to the Big Buddha so it's definitely worth a visit. The 3 temples and the buddha statues in them are beautiful and if you are a Buddhist, makes it all the more meaningful.
A nice attraction. Travelling here by public transport is an ideal opportunity see much more. The steps up is a challenge for elderly though. From here, one could easily visit the village of Tai O.

An awesome place for a day visit. Try to get to the cable car terminal as early as possible as the lines are massive once it hits midday and beyond. We caught a 10am ride and already had to wait about 30 mins.Once you're on the cable car the ride is awesome!The village leading up to the Buddha is excellent. A main street of shops and eateries. Plenty of options to have lunch. The stairs up to the Buddha was busy but not too bad really.Once you have done the Buddha, take a walk to through the temple and Hall of 10,000 golden Buddhas. That was awesome to see.We really enjoyed the day at Ngong Ping.

Temple was gorgeous!. Beautiful inside and out. Landscaping excellent. Cultural experience. Phenomenal artistic ceilings, beautiful surrounding grounds and chanting Monks. Worth the trip and it is free with a donation box if you want to contribute. Smaller temple you can go all the way in and as usual in HongKong the gardens are beautiful.
Amazing experience.. Worth the trip. Incredible spiritual experience, souvenir shopping and photo ops all in one place. If you make it to Hong Kong, you should definitely visit Po Lin.
A must-do while in HK!. This one definitely one of the highlights of our trip in HK. The glass-bottom cablecar ride to get there is an exhilarating experience in itself, though not cheap.
So much to see. Loved the monastery, it has so many details that it's hard not to miss a couple. I will definitely go again while in Hong Kong, it is surely worth it.

This is not the only statue of interest. A small up-hill walk from the cable car, through some tourist shops. Although this monastery is impressive, look to the right and out of the fog (when we were here) appears the 'Big Buddha', we found this even more impressive.

Beautiful site . We visited the monastery on a day tour to The big Buddha. The monastery is beautiful. The temples are ornate and colourful. We particularly liked the temple of ten thousand Buddhas situated inside the gates. A great site to see.

loved it. The big buddha is one of the best attractions in Hong Kong i loved how it was organised the small village and the area around i would recommend this to everyone. also you can take lots of pictures

My favourite place . I love going to the Buddha and the monastery. There are various ways to get there. MTR and cable car or even walk but that's not for the faint hearted. Ferry from central and use local buses and take in the fishing village at Tai O too. Walk past the Wisdom Walk as if going to walk up Lantau peak for about 10 minutes and look back for a different view of The Buddha. It does get crowded here and queues can be long. Try to choose a clear day for the best views.
Inspiring monastery. Well worth the cable car ride & the climb to the top of the Buddha statue. Nice little shopping village in the surrounds with lots of choice for restaurants & shopping

Fantastical... You have to see it to believe it!. As part of a 3 day stop-over in Hong Kong it made sense to get out of the hotel and explore some of the more popular tourist destinations that Hong Kong had to offer and it can be argued that the best views lie outside the city.On a cable car trip to the top of the mountain you really get a sense of perspective as to how small you really are compared to the acres of skyscrapers, trees and mountains. It is recommended that you go to look at the Buddha first as once you climb the stairs you are able to go inside the statue and view the precious artefacts and scriptures of Buddhism as well as one of the sacred artefacts of the religion, truly mesmerising stuff. Here there is a gift shop of sorts with all profits going towards the temple. You are also offered to buy a food token before climbing the stairs which for the equivalent of £3 entitles you to 2 dumpling, noodles and a cup of Chinese tea over at the cafe in the Monastry all vegetarian of course. You'll also notice the seemingly hundreds of 'wild dogs' running around in the Monastry grounds which I found in fact that they are actually cared for by the temple and the temple itself is something to behold. Photography is prohibited in certain areas but the sights you will see are truly something else.

A beautiful place!. A lovely calming place, full of such colour and wonder! You see pictures online but the colours here are just stunning! Would suggest getting up and going early, it's well worth the trip.

Beautiful, Spiritual.. Visited this Buddha and Monastery as independent tourists, used our octopus card and MTR app to make travel links to neatest City transport, with plans to go up on the cable car! "Was closed for maintenance" so used local bus to summit turning our visit into a pilgrimage.

Peaceful. Its a place beautiful and peaceful There are several golden Buddhas in the sanctum which is beautiful and worth seeing. One can spend few minutes of peace and tranquility in the monastery. And then go up the Big Buddhaas they are together.
Excellent. There are several golden Buddhas in the sanctum which is beautiful. One can spend few minutes of peace and tranquility in the monastery. It is very close to the Big Buddha.

Beautiful and serene place. This monastery on Lantau Island is quite beautiful and serene. There are many different rooms to visit and they are all beautiful and moving. There are a number of large dining/catering halls and they were setting up for a large banquet. Definitely worth a visit!

Very nice!. The view from here is one of the best that you can see, is right in the top of the mountains, you don`t have so many things to visit here but the view is amazing and the ride with the cable car is very nice. You can make here nice photos!
Beautiful but small. Beautifully decorated, there's actually only one or two main rooms to see, but if you're visiting the big buddha definitely don't miss this.

MUST DO!!!!!!. Yes go see! full day out.Depending on where you are staying, you can either book a sight seeing tour. Or go solo and get the ferry then a bus or do the whole cable care thing.we went ferry and bus, very easy and very cheap everyone very helpful. but worth the trip and how you get there is down to want you want to spend. but yes a must see!

Yummy simple vegetarian meal. At first the many steps to the big Buddha frightened me but surprisingly I wasn't tired after climbing up and coming down from it. And the very simple vegetarian meal was yummy.

Serenty. After arriving by cable car we were struck by the almost mystic feeling of peace and tranquility of this place.The Temple dates back to around the 15 century while the Budda was constructed in the early 20 century.A beatiful area to spend an afternoon

Only thing (& big Buddha) worth visiting in Lantau . Calm and serene. Good to take a calm stroll around. Definitely do eat in the vegetarian restaurant inside. They have regular and deluxe meals for lunch. Very clean restaurant and good food. The ngong ping village is a sham, the monastery makes the island visit worthwhile.

The cable car up is fun.. Ngong Ping village is so touristy it is a grotesque anathema to the basic tenets of buddhsm. The Buddha statue itself is quite new and has impressive views but there is a gift shop inside - I'll let that sink in.
Beaufiful and relaxing. Beautiful architecture, monuments, nature and fresh air. Monastery is great. You can buy something to eat or drink. It's very relaxing. You musn't go on a rainy day.

A must see in Hong Kong. Opposite the statue, the Po Lin Monastery is one of Hong Kong’s most important Buddhist sanctums This monastery is rich in colors, statues and the architectural style is really beautiful. You can walk around in the garden, this is really peaceful even if this is a touristic place. Of course the weather must be nice to enjoy this colorful Monastery. I loved it.

Place of worship that is an oasis away from the city. Hong Kong doesn't have much of a soul now that it's all skyscapers and shops. The soul can be found here. The site is easy to get to and although there are lots of tourists it is also very much being used. There are lots of people there to worship and the incense can be a little overwhelming.The buildings are beautiful and the vegetarian restaurant we found to be really good, although some of the desserts were a little odd.Combined with the cable car, bug buddha and Tai-O this is a lovely day out of the city.
Beautiful. The buddha is amazing and the monastery itself is phenomenal, so much respect in this religion seems lovely

Monastery is a "Must". This is on everyone's "to do" list when visiting Hong Kong. The monastery is classical old Chinese architecture and it provides great views of the Big Buddha in the distance, which you will visit on the way. The icons (or "graven images") are quite impressive and you will see many people bowing and praying, as well as leaving gifts to the Buddha like fruit and a jar of Kirkland mixed nuts. While the reviews of the vegetarian dining room seem to receive good reviews, I didn't experience that. It's a walk-up-to-order "window" and seat yourself patio area. The food we saw coming out looked sub-standard and we chose to eat our own back-up provisions. Also, bathrooms are limited and the female bathroom features the "squat hole". This was surprising given the Village and Buddha are contemporary versus old China (note my tripadvisor name- I'll critique it all!) This is worth the 1/2 day trip as long as you are prepared. Manage your expectations: 1- Walking through Ngong Ping Village is like walking through Main Street Disney. I found this interesting given this is where some go to worship and the fact that this is a monastery. 2- the incense near and in the monastery is really bad. My friend has asthma and prepared by bringing a mask. She needed it in some areas. Tips: 1- buy your ticket before you leave the airport! This gives you a "fast pass" in the line if you're taking the cable 360 car. 2 - go early! It's easily a half day visit for both the Buddha and the monastery. if you start at 10:00. 3- wear comfy shoes. It's a lot of walking.
Worth a visit. Reach this by the Ngong Ping 360 cable car .,Takes about 30 minutes to reach the Monastery and Buddhatry to Avoid this trip on rainy days but still good day out

Love it. My first time there. This is just next to the Tian Tan Buddha. Although its just next to the Tian Tan Buddha, but there are much less people there. We have a quick vegetarian lunch there after going round the temple.

Beautiful Monastery in Hong Kong. Located next to the Big Buddha, the monastery is one of the most important Buddhist temples in Hong Kong. The monastery is a Chinese style building located behind a large courtyard with an incense burner in front of it. The recently completed Grand Hall of Thousand Buddhas is very beautiful with chinese carvings on the pillars and walls and Buddha statues inside. Entrance to the monastery is through a big chinese style gate with a circular platform in front of it. After this is a long walk where you can buy candles and incense sticks for offering to the Buddha in front of the monastery.The monastery also offers Vegetarian Lunch which is required if you want to visit the museum at the Big Buddha.A must see along with the Big Buddha nearby.

Must see in Hong Kong. Overall the experience was really really good. You can reach the area where the statue is with with a cable car and the whole view from there is really awesome. At the area round the statue you can find many shops with all kinds of souvenirs. You can also enter inside the statue which was interesting. Other than that, there are some small hiking paths around where it's really nice to go since the vegetation there is really different and interesting to see.

I love it!. Opposite the statue, the Po Lin Monastery is one of Hong Kong’s most important Buddhist sanctums and has been dubbed ‘the Buddhist World in the South’. Home to many devout monk, this monastery is rich with colorful manifestations of Buddhist iconography and its pleasant garden is alive with birdsong and flowery scents.

Tallest Buddha in the world. We took a full day Viator tour out of Hong Kong. Picked up at hotel and taken to a meeting a point for the tour bus. It was about a one hour drive to the cable car that takes you to the Island (near the airport). If the weather is nice, the views are fantastic. Our guide Lawrence was the best and covered all the history and took very good care of the group. The Buddha is a must see. We had a vegetarian lunch at the Po Lin Monastery. After that, the tour went down to the coast of the South China Sea and we took a boat tour to see the White Dolphins and houses on stilts. The White Dolphins were awesome as were the houses on stilts. Definitely recommend this tour. Not only was it a very good time but it gets you away from the crowds of Hong Kong for a day.

Its huge and beautiful.... The food, the place and everything beyond is just simply great. Go there on a clear day and you will be amazed. Have been there for at least 3 times, and enjoyed every visit. Take the Ngong Ping cable car to the village and walk to the monastery, the view and atmosphere is breath taking. After climbing to big Buddha, there are some snack shops/stalls where you can grab a drink if you want. Then head back down and you can eat in the canteen or the vegetarian restaurant. I ate from the canteen shop which comes with the ticket so no charge, my selection of food included fried noodles, spring rolls, and turnip cake. After that head to Tai O village by taking a bus near the ngong ping village.  Good for families, friends, solo and everyone else..

The Buddha is hard to miss. We took the cable car to the top of the hill. The views were good and it was exciting seeing the giant Buddha for the first time.The purpose built shops and entertainment was not my cup of tea. However we loved the monastery and the Buddha. It was a bit of a climb to the top over 200 steps, but worth the view.In the monastery the monks were chanting and a ceremony was taking place. It was a very peaceful place.I wish they had not made it so commercial . The cable car and the Buddha and monastery were more than adequate , without turning it in to Epcot.

Really worth the visit. went on a tour which took in the cable cars, a must do it rained on they day that we went but still found the experience well worth it, had lunch at the monasteries again a great experience

Source of inspiration. This holy place is full of positive energies and beauties to feel and discover. Even though commerce with Chinese goodies is showing a lot - (inredibly increased since 2008) so peaceful and untouchable.
Beautiful. A beautiful, relaxing place to spend the day, eating delicious vegetarian food, enjoying amazing views and soaking up the sounds of Buddhist monks chanting. Brilliant.
Pilgrimmage. A wonder to behold with a great trip by cable car to reach this site, an amazing experience in many ways.

Peaceful!. Amazing shrines and bhuddist culture, my favourite of all of them was the 10 thousand buddah hall. This was easily my favourite of all of the smaller temples in and around Lantau island as it was something different to the Buddhist shrines I have seen around Asia. The walls are intricately decorated with, funnily enough, 10 thousand small buddhas. This temple seemed quieter and very peaceful in comparison to others on the island.
Must visit. This was a fantastic experience - extremely calm and peaceful amongst an otherwise chaotic Hong Kong. Buy tickets in advance
Wonderful. Take the time and the crystal car its more fun and its a wonderful memory and the peaceful surrounding are worth and time
260 steps. You have to be in reasonable shape to walk this, enormous once there, fairly busy around lunchtime but do it

awsome. The statue is so large and overlooks the monastery. There are a lot of steps to the top but worth it if you feel fit.The statue is just magnificent to look at and when the clouds go over it gives a mystical atmosphere. Easy to get to by ferry to Mui Wo and then no2 bus.Do check bus times for returning .The building work at the monastery has now finished and it is beautiful.The carvings are really nice.You can not take pictures inside. but you can get a good view from the entrance.A must to see

Wonderful day. We rode the cable car to the top and were awed by the sight of the giant Buddha. Our tour included a vegetarian luncheon in the monastery and it was delicious. The tour also provided a bus to ride right up to the Buddha for those who couldn't or wouldn't climb the stairs (we rode the bus!). At the top, the view was amazing.
Amazing place. I just loved it! The cable car to the Big Budha is very nice (ask for the crystal cars). If you are not fit, avoid going during hot days.
Amazing!. The walk up the stairs is not for the feinthearted, but once you reach the top, the views are amazing! The history and detail of the Buddah are stunning. Definitely a great trip.
Nice day out. Be prepared to do plenty of walking and climbing steps. It was a nice peaceful day out, Plenty of food outlets

Interesting day. We went from Tung Chung (near Hong Kong's airport) taking the cable car, the Ngong Ping 360, on a mildly rainy weekday. The weather and day meant that the queue was minimal. I have previously been and given up at the sight of the long queue on a fine weekend. The able car ride was magnificent with great views over the countryside, old Tung Chung village, the airport and coastline. At Ngng Ping village at the top of the cable car, a quaint collection of recreated / imagined old buildings with shops, cafes and attractions, we had some great photo ops. Then we walked on to the Big Buddha. There is a major flight of stairs to climb to get close to the Buddha, but these were easily managed by the four people in our party aged over 60. At the top the views were great as the mist cleared. The Buddha itself and surrounding statuary is beautiful and serene despit it's modern creation. From there we walked down to the Monastery near the base of the stairs. We passed statues of various characters from the Chinese zodiac / mythology on the way and several mild cattle sitting around being photographed (these appeared to be all male and missing certain parts of their anatomy which might explain their calmness). The Monastery is a collection of lovely buildings many with accommodation or administrative functions but artistically built. The prayer halls with statues of the Buddha were beautifully decorated with lots of golds, orange and yellows. In the grounds there's a joss stick burning area and a small, blackened building where people were burning their paper offerings (paper money, paper gold, paper clothing etc) and reading out the names of ancestors for whom these offerings were intended in the afterlife. We ate some vegetarian snacks from the Deli Vegetarian Cafe and found the desserts particularly enjoyable. Then we caught a bus from the bus terminus down to Mui Wo, another interesting excursion and from there we went by ferry to Central after a great meal in a seaside restaurant. A great day out. Snack places, refreshment places, washroom availability all good. The monastery and Big Buddha are free, but cable car and bus ride down were not. We went on an overcast, mildly rainy day, which worked well for us, but if it gets stormy I understand they close the cable car. Take umbrellas against rain or sun. You are outdoors most of the time.

Great View. expect to climb 268 steps before coming to the front of the Buddha. pay for a ticket for a set vegetarian meal (no choosing of dishes). with same ticket, gain free entry to view Buddha relic.

Count the steps.......... We decided to visit while we still can manage the steps up to worship Buddha.It appears daunting whn you are looking up the steps before you start climbing. However, once you started, you sort of get the hang of it.No doubt that it is tiring for our legs that is not used to climbing steps but you also need the stamina.But the climb is worth it!

Beautiful. The workmanship, time and effort put into making this beautiful monastery is so apparent that you are constantly flawed by all the different designs you see from outside. Inside there are beautiful golden Buddhas and the bright colours are wonderful. You don't need to spend a long time here. I was here for 20 minutes looking around and taking photos. You cannot take pictures inside the monastery but you can from the outside.

Beautiful & Peaceful place.... Although this is situated just next to the famous Tian Tan Buddha people often tend to skip this place. However, this is a must visit specially when you are so near it. It has a very peaceful setting with beautiful golden Buddha statues everywhere.
Ten thousand gold Buddhas! . Never seen anything like it. A room of pure gold, all Buddhas!! An amazing site and you should definitely visit it when you have come this far to see Tian Tan

Breathtaking place to visit!. On the way up to the mountain by the cable cars, the views that it has to offer was immensely breathtaking. When we got to the place, there was so much to see & do, the big buddha was beautifully crafted. Definitely give this place a visit when visiting Hong Kong!

April 2016. Completely worth the full day that it takes.I went with a group of Americans and am now friends with them!The tour guide was informative, gave us time to explore the monastery on our own, take pictures ( took many for me too and lent me his umbrella :p).The lunch was finger licking good- we had the vegetarian option which was delish- must try. The chants coming from the monks, the ambience, the architecture and the serenity.Simply unforgettable. The ride back was relaxing so much so that i almost nodded off.
Peaceful!. Sits at a top of Ngong Ping. It was very peaceful and if you have time, best to pray and appreciate the surroundings.

A beautiful place. The monastery looks less impressive from the outside, but remarkable from the inside. I was particularly impressed by the 10,000 Buddha hall, with its colorful decorations and golden Buddha statues. Watching Buddha followers light incenses just outside the monastery was an illuminating experience.

Beautiful roof and decorations. The monastery is in the complex just a short walk from the Big Buddha statue. The temples look quite new and are brightly painted with beautiful roof sculptures and decorations as well as of course the golden statues and brightly coloured altars inside.
Get Close to the Gods. great day trip from Hong Kong, get a bit spiritual, culture, hike, great views, site, seeing, and food.

One of the best hike in Hong Kong. Although most people prefer to take the bus/cable car to get there, I strongly suggest to hike your way to this magnificent buddha. From Shek Pik reservoir, that's a 2-3 hour hike, one-way (level - easy). From the Tung Chung road, via Lantau Peak, expect around 2-3 hour hike also, one-way (level - medium). In all cases, the reward is the Big Buddha, sitting on his lotus...

Place of worship. Typical Buddhist monastery with few pavilions and lots of holy sculptures of Budda. The one with 5 Buddas is very nice indeed. No photos allowed inside. Good detour on the way to the hill with the biggest one.

great food. As part of our tour we booked lunch in the monastery.the lunch is totally vegetarian but there was plenty to go around and was extremely tasty..dont forget to get your incense sticks and make a wish
Big. Big building Buddha in Hong Kong .PoLin Monastery it a lot local people come for visiting this place ..

A hot day alongside buddha. What an experience amidst an extremely hot day finding people scrambling for every possible bit of shade. A rather challenging climb up the more than 350 steps had one panting but also because of the breathtaking views from on top.

Amazing. Not for the faint of heart. Quite a journey to get there and a long climb up but worth the effort. Amazing experience. For those like me who don't like heights, it can be a bit daunting however, there is a bus service that you can take rather than the cable car.
Give me FIVE. In positive and with all my respect, this is a beatiful place with delicious food and a lot of souvenirs

A beautiful and tranquil place, quieter than the Big Buddha. The monastery is older than the recent Big Buddha and is a beautifully decorated, quiet and peaceful place. Light incense sticks and make a quiet prayer before wondering the tranquil courts, admitting the detail of the architecture and the reflective composure of this wonderful site.

day tour. I did this on a 1/2 day tour- they went past some beaches (yuk) so polluted! and to a fisherman's village where the houses are all on top of the water which was ok - did get to know some more about the history of Hong Kong. The big budda was very spiritual but did not understand why we did not cover up like some temples you visit - very commercializedand to get back we did do the gondala which had exceptional views

Still practicing, be respectful. Unlike most of the big cathedrals of Europe which, these days, solely cater towards getting as many tourists through the doors as possible, it was nice to experience a Buddhist monastery that still authentically practices. Despite being next to Ngong Ping's tourist traps and having a commercialised restaurant on the ground floor, the monastery here does attempt to limit the commercialisation of its sites.Signs calling for "no photos/no visitors" abound throughout the main building, and because of this most of the tourists seem to stick to the outside plaza rather than trying to gain access to the temple itself. If one does decide to try and get in, they do not seem to have too much of a problem with it as long as you are respectful and don't get in the way.People will be walking swiftly between the Buddha statues, bowing respectfully at each one, and moving on. Keep an eye out for them, and step out of the way if one is near, and they will be fine with you having a look around. Equally, the occasional photo seems permissible, as long as you aren't walking around, camera in hand, trying to document everything you see. Be mindful of your surroundings and respectful of the temple, and that way the trip becomes a lot more enjoyable for everyone.

Excellent Experience!. Definitely recommended. Take the gondola from Kowloon to the site. Bring lots of water, a hat and sunglasses. Buy the package that includes Tai O and the boat tour and return travel to the Lantau Island Metro.

Must see. One of the most impressive Buddha statues to experience. We went on a somewhat overcast week day, which limited the views from the cable car, but probably also kept the crowds down, so we could enjoy walking around the monastery and gardens more. Great little restaurant in the monastery to try some local sweet desserts.

Relaxing Weekend trip. I will be lying if i said is not crowed, but still worth the journey with the cable cars and walking up the stairs.I recommend visit late in afternoon to avoid the hot weather or early in the morning
Good. A great way to spend a day, plenty of things to do.A nice pleasant experience, would spend time there again.
Peaceful. Nice to appreciate another peaceful religious place. To be combined with the trip to the Big Buddha .
Superb. The initial section over the estuary is awesome, as is the view of the Buddha and the new bridge to Macau

tranquility. This is a must place to visit if you are in Hong Kong. You should take a snack, the food was ok, however it must be vegetarian. There are signs that state that not meat is allowed, just be mindful. Make sure you walk around the statues are detailed. Depending where you stay in Hong Kong it may take you a while to get there but it is not hard. I had to take three trains and a bus. Totally worth it. Take cash since not every place takes a credit card.

Fantastic Serene place in the lap of the mountains!. Its an amazing and fantastically serene place. The Giant Buddha on the top of some 170 odd stairs is worth the climb and a must visit location. Photographs are surely the bonus point on top with good vegetarian food and some affordable souvenir shops. Must see!

One of the best sites in Hong Kong. If you have time it is really worth making a trip to the Big Budha, it is huge and the cable car trip there is a must. Incredible view on the airport seeing the landings and take offs from above.

Breathtakingly beautiful. We visited this place after the Big Buddha and it was totally worth it! The main temple houses 3 bronze statues of the Buddha – representing his past, present and future lives – as well as many Buddhist scriptures. Please be aware that pictures are not allowed inside the monastery and be respectful with those who are going for worship. Weather is unpredictable so take an umbrella with you! We advise to have lunch in one of the vegetarian restaurants near by -affordable prices, lots of food, interesting flavours-.
Good veg food.. fantastic location. It's a nice location away from hustle bustle of urban hi town. Cable car ride to this place is one of the best i have been on. Fantastic views.
Beautiful and Serene. Must visit, beautiful place,beautiful drive. Dont miss the vegetarian food at the canteenCarry an umbrella with you , as its all open.

Good place to reflect. Definitely one of the places to go to.you have 2 options to go there, either by cable car or bus 3m.The bus is a cheaper but longer option but the cable car is worth trying out at least once, as it is one of the longest in Asia. (Top 5 I believe) Do make sure to climb up all the steps, and get a glimpse of the island's skyline. Best to go on a sunny hot weather. It tends to fog up a lot during the winter.

A must visit attraction!. A must visit attraction, make sure you take plenty of water as walking up all the steps to the Buddha in the heat is very tiring. Stop for food at the vegetarian restaurant by the side of the monastery before you leave

very nice monastery. it insets to the big buddha, people from all over the world comes here to worship the amazing budha, please respect their tradition and wear covered clothes to come here, there is a vegetarian restaurant where you can eat wonderful food at very good price.

A place where Buddah's from all over China come to worship. A sense of peace reaches out to everyone who encounters this great center of worship. Friendly courteous people abound as we all are in awe of its beauty.

A very beautiful place. I have visited many monasteries around the world. This is the most beautiful monastery I have ever visited. Unfortunately they don't allow photography inside so you don't get to see it in its full glory.

Amazing monastry. This monastery is located on Lantau Island and is also connected to the big bhudda so you can do the both of them in the same trip, you can gat a bus to the monastery / bhudda, but you can also take a cable car across to them but this is more expensive, personally I preferred the bus as it meant I got to see a bit of the island and the drive through the mountains is nice. The buildings in the monastery are fab, they are what you expect Chinese buildings to look like, and inside the buildings are bhuddas etc which are really nice to look at, it is well worth a walk around.

Spiritual time. We visited the monastery after lunch and before Big Buddah. It was so lovely. We purchased incense and watched how others did it before offering ours in memory of a friend who had just passed. It was a special visit.

By far the best in Hong Kong. I had a couple of hours of free time and came to visit the Big Buddha. It was nice. But for my surprise just few feet away is located Po Lin monastery with 10,000 Buddhas. Do not miss it. It is spectacular. Just walk around the first temple. It is behind it.
interesting place!. climb up this flight of stairs to go up to Buddha. the view up there is splendid. they do sell souvenirs too, which the proceeds would be used to maintain the place.

Overwhelmingly beautiful. This was the largest Buddhist monastery I'd ever been to, and it was truly stunning. The setting is gorgeous and the buildings are incredible--so detailed! I could have spent hours just looking at columns and ceilings. I didn't eat at the main vegetarian restaurant but I can highly recommend the little snack shop next to it that sells both hot and cold food and desserts for incredibly low prices. If you do just one excursion in HK, make it the Buddha and Po Lin Monastery!

Peace of Mind. Po Lin Monastery is located near the Big Buddha. The Monastery offers peaceful sojourn into the world of Taoism, Buddhism and what not. The Monastery has multiple player halls with statues of Gautam Buddha. The statues are not allowed to be photographed. Of special interest is the hall housing the 5 Buddhas.There is also a nice eatery nearby wherein one can enjoy nutritious vegetarian food. Reaching Po Lin Monastery is either through cable car from Tung Chung cable car station or via bus no.23 from Tung Chung MTR station.

Bhudda Fan. The trip on the cable car is terrific enough with it's views of the local foliage and china sea etc. Yet the Monastery area is excellent too with the Giant statue and the marvelously kept Monastery areas. As a tourist from the west what was there not to like? I would say this trip is a "Must" for any visitor to the Hong Kong area if you want to get a sense of what another's religious attitudes are. You cannot be disappointed!

Worth a visit. I took the cable car, although NOT the glass bottom one, to get from Tung Chung MTR Station to Ngong Ping Village. It's got nice view to and from the station, although it's much pricier than the #23 Bus which I could locate the bus stop for it.

Sacred and Peaceful place!. My husband and I walked up the many stairs and embraced the rainy weather to see a wonderful sacred site. Unfortunately, due to the bad weather, visibility was an issue, thankfully the rain subsided for a while and was able to see the beauty of the enormous Buddha. We even bought some souvenirs from there which were blessed from the monks who live at the monastery. We also ate at the vegetarian restaurant which you have a choice of a basic or premium menu, we chose the premium menu and it was authentic Chinese food. After the walk up and back in the rain from the Big Buddha, it was definitely worth the visit.
Peaceful. It was a great day out, enjoyed the sun and the beautiful surrounding. We walked 256 steps to the Big Buddha and we "WOWed" more. It was a beauty.

Don't miss the lunch. This is a very touristy place but nevertheless enjoyable. The vegetarian lunch is reliably excellent (no choice; you get whatever the set of the day is). Note that this is the same trip as the "Big Buddha" under a different name.

Asia Most Famous Buddha Statute. That's probable one of the biggest buddha statute in the world. Tourist either take cable car or bus to go up the mountain at Lantau Island. The Po Lin Monastery got its long valuable history that you can feel the quite and peaceful life of he monks. There is a rumour that if you can finish the staircase walk to reach the top of the statute and touch the lotus beneath the buddha that bring you very good luck and your wish come true. It is suggest to take photos at the bottom of the shopping mall because you can capture the entire statute. A very unique and beautiful place must go.

Beautiful place. On the ground next to Big Bhudda is the Monastery with Beautiful temples, vegetarian restaurants.There are flowers everywhere and beautiful places where you just can sit and relaxComing to this beautiful place you have three optionsCable carBustaxiIts worth a visit

Very worthwhile. Lovely, peaceful and a chance to find harmony in your day. The first view of Tian Tan (the largest sitting Buddha) nestled between the rich lush hills of the countryside is emotionally moving as your clear-floored gondola takes you to the peak. The ambience of the monastery and Buddha will help transcend the hectic pace of the city.

Peaceful and Beautiful. I felt wonderful during my visit here, the place is so peaceful, beautiful and colorful. The ceiling and wall carving was amazing. Don’t miss the second temple in the right which is so beautiful. Before you completed your visit try their light vegetarian refreshment. You will enjoy it.

Worth a visit. Visit early to avoid crowd. We book the cable car at 9:15 and went straight to the Big Buddha area. For HK38, visit the museum and enjoy a light vegetarian refreshment at the temple area. (1 plate of beehoon + 2 choices of snack + bowl of bean curd) OR an ice cream with a bottle of mineral water.)

Serenity With A View. Nice views of Hong Kong from the top, great place for some photos. Try the vegetarian food next to the monastery, bear in mind not to bring your own non-vegetarian food into the area for respect.

Buy your tickets ahead of time and avoid the wait. We took the gondola up and it was really exciting. However, do what you can to avoid the lines - going up and coming back. Also, in addition to climbing up the stairs, be sure to visit the temple which is to your right as you come back down the stairs. We almost missed it!
Beautiful. This whole site for me was the highlight of my trip. I suggest you plan an early start to your day for this one. It is very popular and becomes crowded.

Finding a peaceful retreat in a crazy world.. Only a short walk from the Big Buddha the Po Lin monastery is worth the extra few steps. As one approaches devotees burn incense that starts one on a wonderful experience of the monastery. The intricate carving and the beautiful gilded ceilings with the explosions of color left me in awe. Do not miss the second building which is just as beautiful or more so than the first. One can also get a vegetarian lunch right there in the complex to add to one's overall experience.
wonderful. Without doubt one of the best spiritual highlights of Hong Kong... which fits perfectly into breathtaking nature.An amazing experience!!!
Deserves a visit. Nice monastery close to the big Buddha statue, quiet and nice. The entrance is free, there's a place on the side where the monks grow beautiful plants and flowers

Peaceful and Beautiful. I visited the Po Lin monastery on a lovely clear sunny day in May. The complex is quite huge and it's best to take your time to walk through the area, to really admire the intricate wall carvings and the whole peaceful atmosphere. Here, worshippers, devotees and curious tourists converge. There are actually two buildings sited one behind the other. I enjoyed taking a slow walk through the complex to look at the wall carvings. In some areas, the carvings tell the story of Lord Buddha. And the gilded, ornate ceilings were simply awe-inspiring, with its profusion of colours! Overall, it felt wonderful just being here!
Visit. This is all part of the Lantau Island experience. Make sure you treat the Monks kindly they are very sincere and kind.

Monastery was gorgeous and peaceful. The monastery is beautiful. There are a number of shrines and the worship area is very large containing 5 large golden Buddha. The walls were decorated with buddhas and the ceilings displayed stunning designs. Gorgeous flowers surrounded the shrines. Definitely worth a visit on Lautau Island.

HK Trip. Overall this was okay. Obviously this was a tourist attraction that sort of takes away from the natural beauty of this place. Note, there are cows roaming around this place. If you have food they will come to you.
Peaceful if you get there early. Get first cable car at 10 and just sit back and enjoy this place. The colours and detail are fantastic.

Great place to go. Enjoyable cable car ride. The monastery as well as the Buddha statue is an experience in itself. The area from which the cable car or buses to the Monastery start is near to the MTR station. I would suggest to take the cable car for one-way of the trip at least, the glass cable car is a waste of money however, normal cable car provides the same view.There are 200 steps to Buddha statue, the statue itself is massive, the view from the statue is very good.There are a lot of restaurants serving many cuisines up top, a few local restaurants too so no problem there.

A day away from the noise. Nice place to go and visit, at least to stay away from the busy and noisy streets of Hong Kong. Ride will take you an hour or so. If you are a group of 4 and sharing, take a taxi straight forward, it will come cheaper than the buses. Not religious at all, but I did enjoy a quiet and calm day, even burnt some of those incense!

Serene and good food. It is situated next to the Big Buddha. As you approach you will smell the incense and see incense that look like large rockets burning. There is a temple structure and if you walk through, you will come to another temple structure with many small Buddhas and a beautifully carved ceiling. The architecture is stunning. There is a vegetarian restaurant that serves lovely food. we tried out some unusual snacks. the Spring rolls were very good.

Visit to Po Lin Monastery. We took a bus tour to Lantau Island and the Po Lin Monastery. The Big Buddha was awe inspiring. There are 200 steps up to the Buddha, but the bus took us to within about 20 steps from the top. Our trip included lunch at the monastery, which was vegetarian and absolutely delicious. The food was served family style and there was more than enough for all. There was a temple with golden buddhas that was very beautiful. There is also a little shopping village, which has a Starbucks and WIFI for those interested in it.

Great Experience, even in fog.. We visited the Monastery in May. The day was very gloomy, but we were still able to enjoy the experience.I recommend taking the cable car to it. It seem like it would be scary, but even in heavy rain the car didn't rock and felt very stable.Walk to the big Buddha and then go to the monastery for the vegetarian lunch and to tour the beautiful site.

I love Big Buddha's I cannot lie. The journey to the Monastery is long and requires a cable car at the end to take you to the top of a remote island of Hong Kong near the Airport. I wasn't sure it would be worth the trip. I was pleasantly surprised as the Buddha and Monastery became one of the highlights of our time in Hong Kong. The Buddha itself is huge and very impressive - but so is the monastery with the buildings and interiors with gold and lots of Buddha's.

Enjoyed it. We spent the entire day visiting Big Buddha, Po Lin Monastery and Tai O fishing village on Lantau Island. After seeing The Big Buddha, be sure to walk to the other side and see the Monastery. The buildings are beautiful with serene gardens. There is a vegetarian restaurant on the property with either outdoor tables or for an extra charge, you can dine in a nicer dining room out of the sun and heat.

Culture-rich. After descending from the Big Buddha, walked straight ahead to the Po Lin Monastery and experience the smell of incense from burning candles and the echoing chants of monks during worship.

Amazing to see. We took the cable car and were enjoying this when, there he was. It was exciting to see. Beware there are lots of touristy things and that can take away from the marvel. We walked up the stairs, it is quite a hike and we aren't old people! The clouds were coming and going but that just added to the magestics of the place. Just when you think you've gotten the best picture, there is another great opportunity. Take a moment to look around at the countryside too.

Peaceful Visit , Great Views. The Monastery is very peaceful and the 10000 Buddhas inside offer a very good sight and also peace (one is not allowed to take photos)The ride in the cable car to teh top itself is very good
Impressive temple. A must see, if you want to get closer in touch with the culture of the population. Monument and the temples are impressive, nearby you could enjoy some tourist attractions

A spectacular place. We were able to visit on a day when it was not over crowded and the buildings are spectacular both outside and inside. The cafe offers vegetarian food of the highest quality. And the gift shops are not a rip off. All in all well worth the trip especially if combined with the Big Buddha and the cable car.

Serene Place. Such an amazing building. The colourful decorative ceramic tiles are a magnificent example of the craftsmanship of the Chinese people. So Beautiful. A serene place for quiet reflection. Many other artifacts to see and admire, Like taking a step back in time.

You also have a choice of upgrading to include the glass-bottomed crystal cabin of the Ngong Ping Cable Car or a 3-day M. After picking up your MTR pass and additional tickets at the Tsim Sha Tsui Star Ferry Pier, you’re ready to begin your Hong Kong sightseeing!MTR Pass:Hong Kong is at your fingertips with your pass for one day of unlimited use on the MTR (Mass Transit Railway). With three different transportation options – trains, a light rail system and feeder buses – you can easily reach the Hong Kong attractions that most interest you. The fast and easy-to-use MTR covers Hong Kong’s major districts, including stops at the boundary with mainland China. Across 10 different rail lines, you can see it all – perhaps head to Disneyland on the Disneyland Resort Line, or check out Central, Sheung Wan and Causeway Bay on the Island Line. Or use the light rail to travel between Yuen Long and Tuen Mun in the New Territories.Airport Express Pass (if option selected):First up, use the first half of your Airport Express pass to get from the Hong Kong airport into the city. When you’re ready to go back to the airport, use your second trip on the Airport Express.

Amazing place to visit and must see. Po lin is Monastery basically, but got amazing history, cultural value and most amazing ancient heritage structures. Must see if you have a time while traveling at Hong Kong and if you love History and heritage buildings!
peaceful. an amazing place, I once peaceful and relaxing, very nice, I enjoyed in each second conducted here...

Beautiful.... A nice experience visiting this well maintained Monastery.The three main Buddhas and the 1000 Buddha hall are the main attractions.The three Buddha reminded me the Three Murthies of Hindy Mythology.Rtn.J.Ganesh
Sacred Place. A must see when you visit HK, a very relaxing and serene place, move your butt and climb up to the top for the view is totally worth it.
Amazing. Didn't expect it to be such a great place. Awesome monastery with the big Buddha just next to it, its a must for everyone visiting HK.

Must see in Hong Kong!! cable car ride too!!. Most amazing Buddha statue in Hong Kong.!!This place is also reachable by a superb ride in the cable car which gives you fabulous views of Lantau island from top.,,. beautifully made structure, the entire place has a lovely serene vibe . You have to climb up the steps to reach till the top of the Buddha. The other areas have lovely quaint souvenir shops , coffee shops and restaurants to sit down and grab a bite,,,inside the monastery they serve only vegetarian food as per timings. must visit whilst in Hong Kong!!
Beautiful place. Interesting place to visit. Fantastic buildings and very nice gardens. Reducing number of monks nowadays but interesting to see the and hear their chanting.
Pleasing Experience. Po Lin Monastry is just opposite to Big Buddha at Ngong Ping village. It's calm and very nice architect. On visit, you experience the pleasing feel.

Sacred & Serene !!. Very close to Big Buddha and sacred place for the followers of Buddha. We were lucky to view the special Kung Fu performances arranged as a part of Buddha's Birthday week. Many local shops sell religious items.

Very peaceful. we went to the monastery at the time the priest started there chanting. The view from big Buddha is very amazing and they say if you throw a coin and if it stay there you become very rich so do try

Highly Recommend Visiting the Monastery. One of our best excursions in Hong Kong was the visit to the Po Lin Monastery. It is very peaceful. Due to the cobblestones and uphill location, you should ensure that strollers and wheelchairs are comfortable for the passengers. We took a short hike also to one of the shrines. It's lush green and quiet. If possible, carve time for it.
A must do. There is more to this place other than the giant Buddha. Other buildings and statues along the way. Lots of shopping and the views are amazing!

Beautiful Monastery. As part of our tour of Lantau Island we were taken to the Monastery to have a look around and then to have a vegetarian meal. The buildings of the Monastery were very elaborately decorated and quite beautiful. Photos were only permitted outside of the buildings.The vegetarian meal was delicious - as we were pretty hungry by the time we ate that was the part of the visit I enjoyed the most!
Majestic Buddha. A nice Buddha that is very beautifully carved out. Easy to walk up stairs and visit. Monastery is opposite and dont forget to visit the 10K Buddha Room it is magnificent

Nice but crowded. Reaching Po Lin Monastery and sitting Buddha by cable car is a very nice and scenic option. Unfortunately the site around the Monastery is too comercial and crowded. Inside the building and in case you have the Buddhist meal offered there is a chance to spend some peaceful time to get forces to climb to the Buddha statue and iformation centre. There is up to you to enjoy the views or have some indepth moments.This coments related to an earlier visit.

Fantastic experience - worth the trek. Still the best excursion I ever made, if you have the time and the weather is friendly. Take the ferry to Lantau island from Central Pier on Hong Kong Island. Beautiful views all the way. On arrival at Lantau, take the rickety double-decker bus that meets the boat and takes you all the way up to the Buddha. The statue, and nearby Po Lin monastery, are fascinating. If time is tight, just take the return route. But if you have time, start walking downhill to the NE. It will take a couple of hours, but you can walk down through the groves to Tung Chung metro station, and get back to Hong Kong that way.
Delicious Vegetarian food. It's a good place to stop by when you visit Lantau island, go to their praying hall and eat the vegetarian food at their canteen, cheap and nice!
Close to Big Buddha. Worth walking over if you are at the big Buddha. Much was closed off while I was there. They didn't allow pictures.
I do like vegetarian!. The lunch at the monastery was really the high point. I was nervous about the meal but it was so delicious and I enjoyed dining with my other tour mates.

Beautiful and worth the hike. Enjoyable, beautiful, peaceful. Far from the city centre, but provides a contemplative experience. It is foggy and breezy on the top, and it's extremely peaceful. Check the weather before you go!

So peaceful. Lovely peaceful monastry in the countryside outside the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. The monastry is colourful with lovely painted buildings and beautiful artworks inside. We arrived early in the morning before the crowds and it was so quiet. Also on the site the giant Buddha ontop of a hill, well worth climbing up the steps to see the lovely views. Easy to get to via MTR then either cable car or bus. We went via bus and saw the lovely countryside. We returned to HK via the bus and the fast ferry.

Glittering Gems Below the Great Buddha Amitabha, Lantau. Eye-opener of the Soul : after paying homage to the Great Buddha Statue on the Summit !This totally golden splendour sits on the wooded slope of the mountain range of Lantau is a state-of-the-art ancient Mahayana Chinese Buddhist temple modelled upon the Golden Mountain Temples, Zhenjiang, Southern China. Its main temple structure erected on the top of the hillslope houses the 5-Orientations Master Buddhas is most awe-inspiring mastery sculptures in goldand glittering gems. The strong magnetic ambience in the hall offers wonderful soul-purifying energy for its devotees and visitors alike!After paying your homage therein, try the free for all veggie timsums and soya drink under the trees !To avoid the crowds and queues, visit the Monastery during non-peak seasons and week days.

Quite and peacfull. After a cable car drive can arrive here the wiew was magneficiant attractive you can feel deep impressed to keep that place is lije the first made years took the admires hardly advise

Beautiful place. This place is very nice. We went there in combination with the Big Buddha (is right next to it). Unfortunately it was a rainy day so we couldn't really enjoy the monastery from the outside (which is absolutely beautiful with all these colors). It would be good to visit this place, but wouldn't go here only for the monastery. From the piers you can take a bus up to the mountain, it will take approx 45 minutes and costs HKD 17.20z You can also use the cable car and then you have to pay more, it takes approx 30 minutes. Great experience though! If you are not a fan of buses, don't take the bus. The bus driver drives like crazy!
The amazing Gaint Buddha. Easy acess by mtr to Tung Chung walk to exit B you be able to see citygate mall and walk a little you be able to see the cable car ride.

Monastery visit. Took the family, all 6 to see the monastery and eat at their restaurant. The buildings and grounds were very nice. The restaurant experience was a little confusing at first, but we figured it out and enjoyed a vegetarian meal served family style. It was good, everyone found something they liked in the selections. You do not choose your menu...it is a set menu and brought to your table with tea.
Interesting. I went many years back, very interesting to see but would only go once. Always on business so very little time for sight seeing.

Amazing craftsmanship. Po Lin Monastery is located on Lantau Island. If I recall, Po Lin Monastery is responsible for the building of the "big Buddha". The architecture and craftmanship of the monastery is amazing. Just take in the carvings, the integrity of the construction that locks together and the roof lines, the so many many Buddha statues! There are cows on the grounds that walk freely. When we visited, there was some kind of event in the large temple, and visitors were not allowed in, but we were able to look in and what a sight it was!To get there, we took the MTR to Tung Chung, to the cable car (ngong ping 360) or you can catch the bus to Big Buddha. Give yourself a whole day's time for this.

Day trip to Big Buddha a must!!!. If you are in HK, make sure you spend one or half a day at Big Buddha. Do take the cable car and go for the glass panel cable which you can see through the bottom glass all the way to the top. Quite an experience!!!
The highlight of our visit. Busy, and delicious food. If you're visiting Big Buddha you really must visit this place. Great photo opportunities. Keep away from the shops!

Serene Place. we were at the monastery during an especially foggy day which gave the area an incredibly eerie setting with all the fog but it was still incredibly lovely, peaceful and quiet. the monastery is quite a big complex but most of it is closed for visitors and it is for prayer, but it's still a good look around.

Beautiful big Buddha . We supposed to catch cable car but it was raining and humid they closed the cable car we were so disappointment no refund so catch bus have to give correct money or no change went to big Buddha it was worth to see and so view on the top, we saw cable car still running so walked thru the village to cable car station which we glad to catches on it what a best view and relax.

Beautiful. The landscape and grounds are amazing. They have cows that roam the grounds and are sacred so please do not touch them. You will also have a problem at customs on the way into your own country if you touch the animals. You will meet people from all over the world as you walk around the grounds. It really just draws people in and you will fall in love with the culture.
Beautiful setting. Very colourful and tranquil, visited on the bank holiday, lots of incense burning which added to its serenity.

Seriously, take the tour my way!. Do not go to this by the MTR and cable car. Make it a longer and fun filled journey by first taking the ferry to Mui Wo (Central ferry piers, easy to find), then the bus up to the Big Buddha - make sure you have an octopus card or cash I think $16. The bus is right at the exit to the ferry terminal on the left of the bus terminus. Its a rollicking ride for about 20 mins as the bus chugs uphill to the Buddha. As you exit the bus on your left is the cable car which you can take later after you do the big Buddha and the village nearby. Now the final enjoyment is a bit of "schadenfruede" because when you take the cable car to the terminus you will see hundreds or even thousands trying to queue up for the trip to see the Buddha. You just walked on! The MTR is easy to find for a trip back to Central on a seat!

Worth the effort. Not so easy to get from Wan Chai to Lantau but worth the effort. Its only one change on the MTR but if its your first time can be a little confusing. The sky lift to the Big Buda is an experience in its self and although the walk up to the Big Buda is quite hard I think it is well worth it

Great day trip. We took the MTR to the cable car stop, and spent the morning at the monastery and the Ngong Ping tourist village. Very touristy and beware of the selfie stick. Overall a very good trip away from the city. $2 tip: Take the cable car back down and find a blue taxi to take you to Cheung Sha beach.
a must visit. MTR from Central, cable car ride, and enjoy the buddah and the monastery, a nice place to enjoy a tranquil setting

Amazing Meal. We ate in the restaurant; a pre-set good variety of delicious dishes served family style–all vegan. Best meal of our entire trip. Everything was so fresh and tasty! A highlight of our tour to the Buddha and Lantau Island.The two temples you visit are lovely. It was misty the day we were there, so we didn't get a good view of the big Buddha. We used Lantau tours, and would recommend their service.

If you have time enjoy the wonderful place. If you take a taxi from HongKong or Kowloon you Need to Change your taxi because only Lantau Taxis are driving up there but if you arrange a Price the Driver will wait for you also for 2-3 hours once you are up there
like it. the view from the top is amazing, don't forget to try using cable car when you want to go down to the city.

Absolute must see for HK visitors. Allow a day for this trip. Getting there's is part of the experience. You'll travel 25 minutes on the MTR then get aboard the cable car for another 20 minutes that will take you across and above the mountain, with breathtaking views of the mountain, city, airport island and finally the Big Buddha, Po Pin Monastery. As you arrive there's many souvenir shops and restaurants in traditional Chinese architecture, then a fascinating walk along the main pathway through Chinese Arches to the foot of the Buddha statue.Warning, there's a few hundred steep steps to the enormous Buddha statue, but if you're ok with the climb, it's well worth it to see the giant statue, see the Buddist displays inside and then (on a clear day) see the breath taking views of the ocean.Do it!.
Wonderful view. Worth the climb for the view. Be sure to get ticket that includes vegetarian lunch. A real treat. Delicious.

Great view of big buddha. Climbing up to the monastery was quite a challenge, steep stairs and large crowd. We took lots of photos along the climb and up to the monastery. If u would take vege lunch, pls go to the far end of the restaurant. There was a shop selling very much cheaper and nicer food. The restaurant nearer to the entrance will wack up HK$98 per head for 3-4 courses vege lunch. At the back with HK$98, for 2 persons u can eat till vomit.

A main Hong Kong Attraction. This attraction is worth coming to see. I enjoyed the chairlift experience in getting to the Monastery. The views are breath taking and worth the while to invest in some time to add this to your itinerary while visiting Hong Kong.

Gorgeous architecture. This is located near the big buddha on the left hand side. Can see it before or after. It has the most stunning architecture. Really amazing buildings. Contains 2 amazing shrines and halls with buddha prayer areas. Very big and busy especially weekends . Absolute must see in my opinion
Beautiful and relaxing. This monastery is located near the Big Buddha and we visited it after we made are way down the steps. The atmosphere is relaxing and spiritual and the Buddhas are beautiful.

Spectacular. We had a lovely sunny day. Walked up the long flight of steps for a great view followed by a visit to the wonderful monastery. Buy ticket that allows access inside the Buddha and then lunch at the monastery; good value and experience of eating local

Very peaceful temple, even Caucasians light up joss sticks here for blessing. bought the combo ticket for crystal cable car and tai o village . The crystal cabin is recommended as there is less queue and you can hope onto he cable in under 5 mins. You get to see 360 view of lantau island and of course you can see everything beneath your feet as it is crystal glass cabin. The monastery is right next to big buddha. Quite a semi-big monastery to visit. Very serene and peaceful inside. there is a vegetarian restaurant here for vegans .

Stunning buildings, location and atmosphere. The monastery relies on tourists visiting for its upkeep but otherwise is a calm and peaceful place. The colours are incredible and the interiors of the temples and prayer rooms are even more so. With any luck the monks may be praying and chanting which is a very unique experience to behold. The cafe on site is very good value, would recommend the range of desserts on offer.

A must visit when on Lantau Island. Po Lin Monastery is a Buddhist monastery, located on Ngong Ping Plateau, on Lantau Island. This monastery is also noted for making wooden bracelets that are only sold near the Tian Tan Buddha statue. The Po Lin Monastery is one of Hong Kong’s most important Buddhist sanctums and has been dubbed ‘the Buddhist World in the South’. Home to many a devout monk, this monastery is rich with colourful manifestations of Buddhist iconography and its pleasant garden is alive with birdsong and flowery scents. You can also enlighten your appetite at their popular vegetarian restaurant.For more please read my review of "Lantau Island"

Spiritual itinerary. Despite the fact that it is a touristy place and crowded with people, it still is a must-visit! Doesn't matter what your beliefs are as long as you find yourself and your lost peace of mind. One of the best places in HK!

Good to see. The monastery is in the same place as the Big Buddha just before climbing. There is not much special about the monastery but it is still worth to see as you go there for Big Buddha. Local people are mainly visiting there for praying purposes. The statues inside the monastery were really nice.
What a beautiful peaceful place. The vibe here is peaceful and calm. The ride in the cable car to get here is awesome. I could spend hours just walking around.

Visit to the giant Buddha. We took the cable car upto the giant Buddha with friends, wow the journey up is impressive and when we got to the top we were not dissapointed but my goodness you have to be fit to walk up the 250 steep steps to get to the Buddha. It was a really hot day and we had to keep stopping for a breather, not for the faint hearted but well worth it when you get to the top. There are some lovely restaurants around the monastery area at the base along with the usual souvenir shops, and the 10,000 golden Buddhas are amazing.

Not Just the Buddha. Many people come here from the cable car, walk through the tourist area of shops and then visit the Buddha. There is also this nice monastery to see, with a few different rooms of statues, a peaceful outdoor area, and places to eat vegetarian lunch. You can take the cable cars up from the train station, but I recommend finding an alternative way up and using those cable cars to go back down, to avoid the lines of tourists waiting for the ride up. Be respectful when walking the grounds of the monastery and enjoy the tasty vegetarian dishes. I'm not a fan of most vegetables but there was still plenty for me to eat that I liked. You may come across some stray dogs and a cow here or there, which helps remind you of the more remote location you are in outside of the big city.
top of all. IF YOU planing to go there you should wear a heavy clothes its cold and wonderful view form the top you can see mountain and the way down ,you should try to back by land not cable car .
Must Not Miss. A must visit. Take your time and dress for comfort. There are lots of steps but they give you time to take in this wonderful piece of wonder.

A true wonder!. This is just an amazing statue and a must to see when visiting Hong Kong. It is easy to get to by the metro ,and train ticket from Jordan currently costs 38dollars per person. Change train at lai king and the cable car to take you to see the Buddha is a few minutes walk from the train.

Get a meal voucher, good value.. Many steps up to the top, get a meal voucher and you can go inside and then have an ice cream. But if you keep the meal voucher you can get a nice feed down at the bottom cafe.

Best premise for tranquility. Much far away from the city,located at Lantau Island, best accessible by Tung Chung MTR, it's definitely a place one wants to visit on their trip to Hong Kong. Lot of ticket packages,carefully chose the one you want,book online to avoid huge lines at the ticket counter,enjoy the cable car ride and walk up the steps to pay respect and prayers to Big Buddha.
Well worth a visit. Great day out for all ages. The cable car is very long, and not suitable for anyone afraid of heights. Very impressive Monastery. Beautiful Temples with vibrant painted carvings.

Beautifully Decorated Modern Monastery. ThIs monastery may not have much of a history, but it is a lovely building. It is colourfully decorated on the outside under a red clay tiled roof, and the gold decoration inside is stunning.

Time for Reflection. Surprisingly peaceful, given the hundreds of tour buses that come through each day. The entrance is engulfed in clouds of incense. The intricate decoration of the monastery buildings is beautiful. Memorable. Marvel at the variety of food displayed in the vegetarian cafe.

Beautiful temple and delicious vegetarian food. We came here after came down from the Big Buddha to have our lunch. The temple was really beautifully built and very impressive. There were lots of carving done on the murals, roof and walls of the temple and its surrounding buildings. We then headed to its canteen for vegetarian lunch which was really delicious and not expensive at all.

Stunning monastery interiors. This needs to be reviewed along with the big Buddha. Yes, there is the tacky tourist village, which is not the monastery, and the monastery does also have its fair share of souvenir kiosks. However, the series of rooms are stunning. Unlike a previous reviewer, I would say do have a vegetarian lunch at the monastery. It is not over priced, but it is locally prepared, so choose carefully and don't expect western style food or presentation. If that is what you want, stay in Hong Kong Central.

A lovely place,but walking up all thos esteps was very tiering. Unfortunately it rained that day,so wet,but luckily we saw the great budhha.
Lovely place,and we tried the vegetarian food. Was different and quite nice.

Impressive Buildings and a Vegetarian Lunch. We visited the monastery on our way to the Big Buddha. The buildings are quite impressive, especially the interior of the main building. It’s free entry to the monastery. There are a couple of walking trails next to the monastery. One of the trails is the Wisdom Path that leads to 38 wooden columns with inscriptions from the Heart Sutra. The other trail is he Shek Pik Country Trail which is 5.5 Km long.We also had the vegetarian lunch at the monastery. Keep the receipt from the meal to show at the Big Buddha for free entry to the inside of Big Buddha.

Good to visit -but choose a day with good weather. We went to Po Lin on a very misty day in Hong Kong (mainly as the Peak was in cloud), we went by ferry (Leaves dock 6, next one to Star Ferries) and then bus. Ferry journey is great as you get to see virtually the whole of the harbour and see who big the Island is.The day we went was misty/ damp, which was disappointing, but still well worth the trip and on a bright day must be truly amazing, we paid extra to go inside the Buddha and though a little expensive was worth it. The walk up the stairs to the Buddha is steep but manageable , but the older ones of us may need a short stop on the way up.

Beautiful Monestary but Commercialized, Don't Eat The Food!. The Po Lin Monestary itself is awe-inspiring. If you're lucky, there will be monks praying in ceremony in the monastery. A must-see.BUT...the surrounding are is completely commercialized. There's a new, open-air strip mall selling cheesy souvenirs and other junk. If you rode the bus here, you'll be forced to walk thru it to get back to the bus. I hated this aspect of Po-Lin.Your guidebook might recommend having the vegetarian lunch at the monastery. Don't do it! The food SUCKS. Bland. And overpriced. Ugly dining room. Plastic plates and bowls, etc.
