Very nice. This is sometimes known as the Big Buddha. It is a nice walk and a bit of a climb up to the Buddha. The view is beautiful and you can see the monastery from the Big Buddha. As this is quite a bit of walking out in the sun it would be best not to choose a hot summer day.

A must do!. We took the train to this sight. It was a long line to get on- choice of glass bottom or not. We chose no glass bottom. It is a 30 minute ride to the top and a bit drafty so dress warm. There are restaurants and shops at the base and a 300 foot steps to the top. Incredible to see. Must also see the room of 10,000 Buddhas. Lots of unique things to photograph.
Included in Buddha Visit. This is an added extra when visiting the Big Buddha beautiful to wander around and to see another side of life. Very bright and grat building

A worthwhile side trip on your way to the Big Buddha. If you've got some spare time, and an interest in getting some culture, this is one of the better monasteries to visit. The detail in this place is exquisite, making it well worth a look around. There is a cafe with interesting but bland vegetarian fare on offer. If you find yourself caught in the rain, as I did, this is a good place to stop and enjoy a cup of hot tea as you wait out the storm.

Worth a trip. The countryside around here and the trip to this remote spot on Lantau is amazing. The day I went the cable car was down for maintenance. The bus ride is probably even more spectacular, particularly at Hong Kong speeds.

Inspiring and dramatic place!. The Buddha statue is situated on top ofa series of mountains overlooking the Hong Kong airport and the ocean areas below. Offering some of the most dramatic and amazing views to be found in this Asian country! Highly recommended that you see this. Be sure to book in advance as the Tram can become extremely busy at times with long lines. We waited over 1 hour just to get on the gondola.

Beautify Monastery with Unexpected Surprises. After climbing to the top of the Buddha, we came and wandered around the monastery. We went in and out of buildings respecting the serenity and prayerfulness. Incense burns, temple dogs lick water out of puddles, and if you are really lucky, one of the free range bulls/cows will walk into one of the small shrines to eat the fruit offerings off the altar. It was a real "bull in a china shop" moment.

Lovely Monastery. I took the combo package of Cable car, Nyong village, Monastery and was able to enjoy a full afternoon there.The lovely Monastery, the Big Buddha, view of Lantau Island, the boat ride in Nyong Village was all was very enjoyable
Po Lin. Nice experience to visit the Monastery as well as the Big Buddah. There is also a "Wisdom " trail which takes about 20 mins. The cable car back down is fabulous. Great views of Lantau.

Great views on a clear day. have been here on good days and cold days and once when the fog was so thick you couldnt see anything...but I always enjoy it. I no longer climb all the steps because to be honest, there isnt much to see once you exhaust yourself to get to the top! The trip up by cable car is fabulous. The Nong Ping Village at the top is ok for a bite to eat or a trinket or two. The temple is amazing and you can eat vegetarian there very cheaply. If you have time carry on to Tai O.
Nice climbing. It was a nice climb to the top of the Buddha. The quality of air was very good compare to the rest of Hong Kong.

Quite a spiritual experience. Despite the hordes of Chinese visitors this monastery still has a spiritual feel to it and many of the visitors are clearly on a pilgrimage. Don't miss the cheap and tasty vegetarian lunch at the monastery. Lovely architecture.
Monastery is at the base of the Buddha. This is an adjunct visit after alighting from the stairs of the Buddha.One can understand the religious component of the park.

Must see!!. Called Buddhist World, this monastery has one of the most spectacular halls I've seen. The hall has supposedly 10,000 buddhas! I didn't count them, but I believe it. There are also "holy cows" roaming the property, and these bovine creatures think nothing of raiding the offerings on the altars, specifically for the food. Beautiful place, often draped in fog. And there's a very good vegetarian restaurant on site. So, check out the Tian Tan BIG Buddha and this monastery at the bottom of the statue, and take your time. You can easily spend 3 hours, have lunch, and visit the various shops nearby.

Great place to wonder around. Right next to the big Buddha it would be wrong to miss this! Really quiet and peaceful loads of different buildings to look at and in. It is a working monastery so a lot of people praying and deep in thought although everybody is more than happy for people just to look around

Very cool place. Beautiful scenery, and interesting cultural sights. We enjoyed our afternoon here. There are bathrooms available and food. We took the ferry and then the bus and then found out you can actually take the cable car once we got there.

great trip out to nature. Lovely to get the cable car with glass bottom and travel part the way to small village and then walk up to the big budda, lovely walk on a nice day - recommend going early to avoid the loads of tourists and the heat

Magnificent Monastery in one of the outlying islands of Hong Kong. The Po Lin Monastery, the Big Buddha, the Ngong Ping 360 Village are 3 of the attractions on Lantau Island. To get there, take the MTR to Tung Chung Station and transfer to the Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car for a 30-minute ride to the peak where the 3 attractions are located.

first on d picture and now real. what can i said was Amazing experience ..we jumper on mtr and direct to lantau Island our 1 day..lot of pictures we took,we went to monastery,budha way etc...evetything was pefect,perfect
Beautiful view from the Buddha. Touristy but it provides a beautiful view of surrounding Hong Kong. Village adjacent is disney-esque. I recommend the monastery for lunch.
Religious workship. Many people go there to pray and pay respect to their God. Also a place of interest for the tourist and photo bud.
Fantastic. This is a great trip by cable car to the Island and the views are outstanding the Buddha is overwhelming a great day out

Heaven on Earth!. The day we decided to go the trains were not working so had to take the buses and then the tram was not working so had to walk but.. boy was it WORTH IT!! If in the city miss your meaningless shopping and must visit this place

one of my favorites. getting here on the cable car was spectacular on its own, the visit was amazing. very impressive sculptures. not too crowded, very safe. Definitely recommended. make sure to grab a bite at the vegetarian cafe

Worth the trip. This attraction is located about a 45 minute train ride from Hong Kong. It is worth the trip. Be sure to allow time to purchase your gondola ticket. We experienced about a one hour and 30 minute wait When we arrived in the late morning.
Beautiful!. Fabulous colourful Chinese architecture, an amazing hall of Golden Buddhas, a vegetarian restaurant and of course Big Buddha himself, a must see destination on your visit to Hong Kong.

Great Place to visit for anyone. I am a Christian, though I enjoyed visiting this place. You have to take a gondola or a long hike to get here. I looked at it from a historical/cultural perspective and found it fun and fascinating.

Not the Best Monastery Experience. Po Lin Monastery with its Giant Buddha was built in the mid-1990s. If you take the gondola, be prepared for arrival at the summit developed a very commercialised venue complete with a false front village street, giant 3D cartoon characters, fashion boutiques, souvenir shops, American style restaurants and loud American pop music piped over a PA system. A wide, stone-paved pathway leads to the Po Lin monastery and landscaped gardens. The site is pretty but expect crowds. Be aware also that he monastery and temple are used only on special ceremonial days, so do not expect to ses monks on the grounds. But do expect loud recorded chants over a PA system. The Giant Buddha is impressive, however the small museum building has little to offer with respect to learning more about Buddhism. Rather, the displays comprise lists of patrons and copies of speeches delivered by elected officials at the inauguration of the site. If you are looking for an authentic monastic experience, this is not the place.
Get there early. I suggest getting here early before the massive crowds. It was a beautiful place to walk around and see. It's a bit touristy, but not in a bad way. We really enjoyed it here.

You better be fit. It was beautiful landscape, clean and serene. Be prepared for hot day (read: sunscreen) or rainy day (read: umbrella). The visit will involve queuing and climbing ladders, so pace yourself and bring water. It was worth the effort. Expect the visit to be at least 2 hours.

A fantastic place to visit. The Po Lin Monastery and the Big Buddha should be on every to-do list for HK visitors. Located in Lantau Island in the heart of mountains and green lush forests, this place can be reached by Ngong Ping Cable Car, bus or taxi. You can enjoy a simple and vegetarian lunch in the monastery and go for walks around the temple or just sitting down on a bench to enjoy the peaceful tranquility of this place.

Beautiful, but very tourist oriented. It is no surprise that the monastery near one of Hong Kong´s most visited sites (Big Buddha) is marked by it´s enormous influx of tourists. It is however a beautiful thing to see. Beautiful buildings and some of them are closed off for the monks that reside here. One can hear the prayers and ceremonies as one walk by outside. You can also by incense here and make your prayers. We also got to see the biggest incense sticks ever... Well worth a visit if you are already here for the Buddha.
Magical Experience. It was a privilege to observe locals burning incense and worshipping in the monastery. It is a beautiful building and worth visiting.
A must do. Once your on Lantau take the cable car up its wonderful to see big Buddha ! About 300 steps up but you can do it in easy stages.
Buddhist Temple. Well worth a visit. Awesome location and a way to get a taste of Working Buddhist Momastery. We went as part of a tour that included Ngong Ping cable cars and a fishing village.
A cloudy day. When we went there is was very cloudy.On the way up we couldn't see anything.The boedha was nice to see.The temple also but the rest was only to sell souvenirs to the tourists.

Peacefull. An experience of peace and tranquillity fills you when you stand and watch the Monks at prayer in the great golden hall a really wondrous sight. The dedication shown by the worshippers who pray continuously from 8am until 4pm is amazing
One of the places you cannot miss. It is a must to see a Big Budda and the monastery located there. It is calm there and even if there are a lot of tourists try to find a place to rest for a while.

trip in the fog. We took the tram and loved the ride, but not a great view given the clouds. The village where you arrive is very commercial and the walk up the steps to the big Buddha can be a challenge. But we did it. Try to do on a sunny day!

Needs to be seen to be appreciated fully. If you can only do one thing in HK while you are there make sure this is it - we had a brilliant day. After we had walked up all the steps (and back down) I was advised we could have gone another way which was for those that have difficulty with stairs - oh well got some interesting photos along the way of my struggle BUT IT WAS WORTH IT lol
Buddha says hello. Wonderful place to visit... The views are lovely you would enjoy it. But be prepared to wait a long time getting there depending on where your staying.
"Amazing Big Buddha". Very amazing building and traditional, there have a market under the Buddha, we had a nice Chinese food here. Very nice!
Worth a visit.. Try to visit on a clear day if possible. Temple worth a visit also. Interesting learning how this was constructed.

A walk in the clouds. It was very misty/foggy the day we went to Po Lin. We walked after getting off the cable ride through the mist to see the Buddha. We could not. The best views of the magnificent idol were the ones through the mist and clouds on our way up and down the Monastery. Good eating places near by and the walk is fun.
dont forget to eat at the restaurant. the big buddha is amazing- take the cablecar and walk to the base of the buddha. dont forget to have lunch at the monastery restaurant- you will not regret it.

A fantastic day trip. So we made the mistake of going on a Saturday! This meant 2.5 hours queueing for the cable car ticket office...then another 45 minutes for the actual cable car. It was well worth the wait though - fantastic views of mountains and sea from the cable car. Then we arrived and made our way through the shops (some interesting and some tat-ful), before encountering the monastery itself - fascinating and inviting, we bought and lit some incense! The Big Buddha is huge (surprise surprise...) at the top of a reasonably long stairway. Amazing views of mountains around, it was a great experience and thankfully the queue to take the cable car back down was virtually non-existent. I would thoroughly recommend visiting the Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery, but maybe try a weekday if you can to avoid the long queues!

Part of the Ultimate Tourist trap. When I think of a Buddhist monastery, I think of religious tradition and history. The entire village and monastery was built to attract money. Even the lighting in the second temple is radiant light, not natural.It's OK for a visit, but don't mistake it for a real Buddhist anything. It is simply a tourist trap.I even saw someone worshipping the Billikin at the entrance of the first temple--that spoke volumes to me!!!

Nice and quiet. I haven't been to the temple for about 20 years. It certainly has changed a lot since I was here. Took the NP360 there, what a great time saver! Since I haven't been there in such a long time, everything looks so different. Could also be because I was a lot younger back then. It's a lot more touristy then it was before. Glad there is coffee on the way, but I don't remember there was a lot of food choices. Best to bring a sandwich or go back to the city to eat. With all the shops on the walk way to the big buddha, and the stalls on the side. there are some interesting things to look at, but again very tourisity and felt like I'm in the airport shopping. Do be prepare to walk alot. If you wanted a little nature walk, you can walk to the entrance of the pheonix peak and there was the rock pillars with prayers on it. It's a nice hike for the morning. I think the next time I am there, I might do the phoenix mountain Hike. On the NP360, the paths looks super groomed with steps and wooden planks. Very well maintained.

a quiet haven. a very pleasant spot to wander and maybe take in a meal after seeing the Buddha. vegetarian meals are very reasonable and very good. courtyard is quite beautiful - shame about the commercial hub on the way to the gondolas!

Gorgeous. Unless you are really interested in doing so, I suggest not to spend too much time in visiting all the possible monasteries in HK.Just go to this one and... enjoy.Everything is designed for the meditation and the inner inspiration.

A great day out. The Po lin monastery was a good day out . You saw the day to day running of the monastery. The rooms are stunning especially the 10,000 Buddhas . You can have a Buddhist meal on site . No alcohol or meat . Or you can eat outside at the many food stalls (who do serve meat and alcohol) . Cheaper than Ngong Ping village . The sitting budda is magnificent and is worth the 450 steps to the base .The views from the top are excellent and you also get a good view of the monastery . We went to Po Lin by the Ngong Ping 360 cable car which gave fantastic views of the airport , the mountains and the Buddha.

Giant Buddha !!!!. Po Lin Monastery is the place where a Giant Buddha statue is. It is in Lantau Island and a must visit place. You have to reach Ngong Ping Village and take a rope car (Ngong Ping 360) to reach the top of the hill to view this monastery.
No words available.. It was amazing to be there, very serine and peaceful. The monastery was well kept and probably my best meal as it was fresh and delicious.

A place not to be missed. Po Lin Monastery is a Buddhist sacred place you must visit in Lantau Island. The monastery has a rich history that dated back more than a century ago. Enjoy the architecture of the buildings and sculptures around. Besides visiting the place and praying to the Buddha, I also took the vegetarian meal. The meal seems to be for two pax but it was so delicious that I finished all. If you purchase the meal voucher, you can also visit the Buddhism exhibition in the Big Buddha. The monastery is opened from 8am to 6pm whist vegetarian kitchen is from 11.30am to 4.30pm. Few ways to get to the monastery but the cable car is the fastest. Take from Tung Chung cable car station to Ngong Ping 360. Stroll through the Ngong Ping Village and you will reach the monastery in about 10mins. Go early to avoid crowds
Incredible Silence. The monastry is impressive as this feels like a secret place and only stroll away from big budha. do not miss. the silence is overwhelming...
day trip with family. took cable car there and it was a good experience. Good for family and we were surprised that the souvenior sold was not expensive compare with down town.
Beautiful . Very beautiful monastery and beautiful surroundings. We went on Chinese New Year and saw lots of people performing different kinds of rituals, it was interesting. Don't miss it!

walk. after taking the cable car to lantau island you will fnd many temples and cafes
but then you hae to walk some steps to see the buddha

An Experience for Westerners. This Monastery is really beautiful with amazing colors and sculptures. The grounds are filled with the people of this faith paying tribute and there is a great meal to be had as well.

Simply stunning!. Set in the shadows of the Big Buddha, the Po Lin Monastery has the most beautiful setting (and is less heavily frequented by tourists than the Big Buddha and Ngong Ping Village. Well worth a visit for an insight into the lives of the Buddhist monks living there.
The ride up to see this is Great!. All part of a village at the top of the mountain-- worth the trip to the village and the attraction -- great pictures to be taken here

Very nice temple in Hong Kong. Yes it is filled with tourists but it is a must visit in Hong Kong. The atmosphere is very open with a lot of green which is not the most common sight in Hong Kong. Hike there if possible as it is the best way but could be challenging though.

Worth the trip. I went to this Buddha along with a bunch of people I met at my hostel. The trip was a bit long to get out here particularly because the cable car was closed however the view and atmosphere here was well worth it. Beautiful monument not to be missed

An amazing building a real eye catcher inside and out. After or before seeing the Big Buddha it is well worth your time to walk the grounds and visit the Po Lin Monastery is a building of outstanding beauty. The use of gold and bright colours and the craftsmanship to build and create such a building is amazing to behold. The use of cameras inside is not allowed so many like us did take snaps from the outside and non of the staff appeared to be concerned. I would however be respectful if you do as this is a place of worship and many were in active prayer during our visit.

My first choice in Hong Kong. A ride to Po Lin is the listed among the most scary cable rides in the world but picturesque, safe (did it twice and still alive!) and fast.The place itself is full of energy, some cosmic energy, I mean. The statue is also very worth looking at.
Amazing. This is a must for all travellers, seeing the Buddha for the first time was an incredible experience

Great contrast to HK bustle. Came out here for a day-trip on New Year's Eve and loved the serenity of the place (despite it being busy with visitors) - what a fantastic contrast to the hustle and bustle of the city.
The Big Buddha.. Situated in Ngong Ping 360. Big Buddha sitting on a lotus.Above 250 stairs to reach there.Felling great Nice surrounding areas.
Spectacular. Cable car lines can be endless! Try Bus for a quicker trip. Amazing detail in the Monastery & Buddha - highly recommend

interesting history inside. Try to make it inside the Buddha. The history is interesting, and the paintings are fantastic. The views from the top are impressive -- we were there near sunset, so they were even more spectacular. The monastery buildings themselves are also worth the (short) walk.

Monastery is very beautiful and the Buddha is quite spectacular. I was very impressed with this place: monastery itself is beautifully built with great attention to details - ornate buildings combined with scent of aromatic bamboo sticks create unique atmosphere. Buddha statue is quite spectacular as well. I'd recommend to get there by bus, since queue to cable car can be of infinite length (it took us 2hours and 30 minutes to get to the ticket booths. Another option is to get closer to 5 pm, when queue is significantly shorter, but this will leave you less than one hour to see the place and get back, since last cable car departs at 6pm. Overall - nice experience, but do not stand in line for 3 hours to get there. Better go up by bus and back by cable car - the queue on the way back is way shorter.

Opposite from the Big Buddha. Many people mix this monastery or consider it same with the inside chapel in the Big Buddha statue base. The monastery is opposite side from the statue, from the circular plaza Buddha is to the right, while the monastery is to the left.While approaching it you'll see big pots with burning incense sticks.The monastery is very beautiful, richly decorated and new.In the monastery courtyard a lunch is served (paying of course) and I didn't like this being so commercialized. The worst is that you can choose a simple or deluxe menu, variating in price.In faith we should all be the same, right???

Buddha's Galore. After seeing the giant buddha this almost seemed like just another replica of the 1st, however if you do this as a half day tour with a tour company you would be included in the lunch time slot with the monks at this monestary that is totally awesome, take into consideration that the are strictly vegetarian but their food bursts with favour
Not as old as you would guess. Go by cable car, although you can take a bus here as it is much cheaper The surrounding shops and cafes are a little tacky.

Very Impressive. The big Buddha is very impressive. There is a temple to visit and you can climb around 300 stairs to reach almost the base of the statue. The temple is very beautiful with many Buddha statues. The place is a place of worship, so many visitors burn sticks.I reached the place from downtown HK taking the metro, and then the bus to the big Buddha. A big saving versus the cable car. (I live near mountains, so I ride regularly in cable car). The bus ride took 30 minutes and was very scenic. Also, seniors get 50% discount on public transportation.
great temple. it's number 1 attraction in hong kong , don't miss it , it's old big buddha , and traveling to this place is great experience. u will love it

Nice ride 360 peak crystal cable car bring you a super view of west part of Hong Kong island. Cable cars took around 20 minutes ride to the top of the temples in Lantau island ! Most of the Asain visitors will burning the stick when they got there, also they would like to eat some vegetables dishes next to the temple ,menu carry two kinds ,one regular and one delux (hkd$500 for two) we picked the delux one ,which came out excellent taste , you won't be disappointed ( must try!)
Very nice. Very nice, interesting monastery, be sure to get something to eat from the cafe they have. Lovely buildings , stunning inside, needs to be seen!
Fell the clamness. forget about all your trouble and get clam. This place was beautiful yet not boring. a lot of stuff to see.

It is an active monastery but seems very commercialized. The monastery was nice and next to the Big Buddha, but there is a sense of commercialism (buy your blessings; the more you give, the Bigger your plaque or statue). It is not unlike any institution or church. This monastery does look "wealthier" than most. Hopefully, the monks follow the Buddha's teachings.

Eat lunch with the monks!. We found the vegetarian lunch fantastic and more than enough food for everyone. It is a set menu and all dishes are brought to your table to share. As a family of 5 who love to eat, it was even too much food for us! As an added bonus, some of the local monks were also eating there.
Po Lin Monastery. Fascinating place to visit. The journey to Lantau Island has been on my to do list and I was not disappointed.
Simply Stunning. Fantastic cultural site to visit and much better to spend your time here and Tian Tan Buddha than the tacky Ngong Ping Village. Highly recommended.

Nice to visit along the Big Buddha. A nice finish to the Big Buddha tour, lots of incense and some nice tranquil moments can be spent here although I personally felt it was slightly detracted by the financial point of sales everywhere - I do understand that they need to fund the place, but it did feel a little double edged to me personally. Again though, a nice walk around to give you more to see after the Buddha

Beautiful Roofs. Very beautiful temple with amazing roofs. I was mesmerized by the roofs. Very intricate and colourful. The walk to it from Ngong Ping is also quite pleasant, with beautiful bronze statues with the 12 Divine Generals.Loved it. Do go there. Include in on an overall trip to Lantau to make it worth the ride.

Impressive monument. This was a pretty impressive sight to see. The island itself is lush and beautiful; the cable car ride down alone is worth the trip up. We had lunch on the grounds and it was fairly decent. The hall of 10,000 Buddhas, just completed, is gorgeous. The smell of incense can be overpowering at times when you're in that area where they burn all the incense. Lots of great Kodak moments here...
Spectacular. Well worth the visit. Was very hot on the day of visit but lovely to see this. Thrilling bus ride there, steep road and fast driver! Take your time here.

Worth the trip up! By bus or by cable car. If you want to get here, there are a few options.Bus (cheapest but longest)Cable car (pricey but great views)Crystal (glass bottomed) cable car) (expensive, but worth it if its really busy as it usually has shorter lines.Beware of the line at the bottom, it's likely that the line to buy the tickets is longer than the line to ride! Buy tickets online before you go if you can.

Very fun, but Hot in Summer. Traveling for business I rarely have time for leisure activities, but bringing my wife along on one trip, we decided to visit Po Lin. It's a long ride on the MTR from TsimShaTsui to the last stop at Lantau Island but the ride is worth it. We took the tram to the top and walked the stairs to the giant Buddha. The statue is amazing in size and beauty and the view is fantastic. You could never imagine that there is an area of peace and tranquility in crowded Hong Kong. We went in Summer and it was very hot. Fall or Winter would have been much better. The tram is equally amazing, but a bit scary, for me at least, however, the ride was fantastic. I hope to have time again to visit Po Lin and spend a little more time relaxing and hiking in the area.

Awe-inspiring but beware the tourist traps.. Getting to the monastery is a little bit of a trek and the queues for the cable car up to the village from tung chung can be very long.That said, this attraction is genuinely worth the wait. The Buddha statue is mammoth and truly a sight to behold. It's particularly fun to spot it from a variety of angles before actually getting there. You can then test your fitness levels by taking the stairs up to the statue when you arrive!The monastery is very tasteful and there are usually a large number of devotees burning incense and making offerings. The smoke can be overwhelming so be sensible and don't hang around the area for too long. There is also a nice vegetarian cafe in the monastery grounds that serves really good dim sum and dessert.A must see in hk.

Take the cable car. Combine the two sort of walk through a tourist trap but arrive at a serene place. The Buddha is amazing rising out of the clouds and although a walk up there well worth the effort just for the photo opportunities. Take some time to walk around the temple below also. Spent half the day here.

A most amazing day!. Going to Po Lin is just amazing. Best way is via the Tung Chung cable car. That takes you to the 'foothills' of the monastery and the Big Buddha. Follow the road around, it is dotted with shops and stalls - then ascend the Big Buddha and be amazed! Whether you are religious or not, you cannot fail to admire this status to Buddha and the work that went in to make it happen. The Monastery is close by - visit and see the 10,000 buddha's (or so it seems). A great day out!

Precious place. In the midst of a tourist honeypot that the Big B is now designed to be is the Monestery. Beautiful buildings and glad to say you are only allowed to peak in but what a peak. Absolutely stunning interiors as well. 10.000 Buddhas is incredible although I didn't count them all. If you go to BB make the effort to go here and to the Veggie restaurant. I would recommend the walk to Wisdom path too doesn't take too long but worth it about an hour.

Make sure you walk around the monastery. Most people come here for the Big Buddha and don't realize there's a monastery attached that is simply beautiful! The temples are breathtaking. Be mindful and respectful because this is a live religious site, meaning worshipers are always here saying their prayers, and most visitors are sometimes not allowed inside the temple, but you can stand outside and look in. It's worth a look inside! You also can't take pictures in some places. The mountains also make it serenely beautiful. Make sure to take a moment to soak in the beauty of your natural surrounds, as well as the beauty of the monastery. And don't forget to dress appropriately, this is a religious site and there are monks walking around.

Traditional Chinese Culture. Again, I didn't get to see this Monastery as the cable car was not running at the time - a huge disappointment for me as it meant I was unable to go. My partner did go however and offered me his opinion: The Monastery has some beautiful examples of traditional Chinese culture and art. As you explore the area you will find large incense sticks burning, people praying & ultimately the tour ends with the grand hall of ten thousand Buddhas which is magnificent. I would have given this 5 stars but many areas did not allow you to take photographs which I found disappointing and the cable car was not running at the time. However, if you enjoy seeing examples of Chinese tradition then this is a great place to come to.
Beautiful. A beautiful place which is peaceful and has amazing views. If you are visiting the Tian Tian Buddha, then take the time to stroll around here.
Loved the view. We went up to the buddha and did our prayers there. The vegetarian food around the vicinity were also yummy. recommended!

serene beauty. peaceful and serene .. that is how i would like to describe the place .. quiet and beautiful buddha statues .. must visit .. i think it is a buddhism pilgrimage site .. closes around 5 p.m.

Get there before sunrise or be a sardine.... Be prepared for a sprawl of international tourists - picture battery hens or sardines in a tin
Alternatively get there incredibly early in the morning 4.45-5.30 and have the place ALMOST to your self
Peaceful and restful for the burnt out, highly stressed troubled soul
Head to "Nong Ping 360"
Highly recommended
Enjoy :-)

Highlight of my trip!. Visit this place. It is a relatively newer Buddha, but still a must visit. Breathtaking views from where the Buddha sits. So much to see and do. Give yourself time. PLEASE buy from locals and not chain stores- you'll help support the island's economy.

Breath taking. Big Buddha was amazingly huge but the monastery area itself feels more private as it is an operating monastery. I enjoyed their architecture and the food offered there (all vegeterian which made me very happy).There is a cemetery underneeth the Big Buddha statue which made me feel like i was invading something I should not go to but that is very personal feeling.

Visited once and will return. Cant praise this place enough, what a wonderful experience whilst in Hongkong, definitely go and visit, its really beautiful!get the bus early though otherwise you may have quite a wait!

Big Buddha Statue. This Big Buddha Statue can be reach when we are on Lantau Island or we can say Ngong Ping 360 as the name of Tourist Destination. To Reach This Giant Buddha and the Monastery we should go up through Steps.

Great attractions even if there is a lot of tourists. I would definitely recommend seeing the Big Buddha even if there is a lot of tourists. The view at the top is simply beautiful and the Buddha is actually really impressive. Considering it is a free attraction, it's a must! And also there is so much more to do in that area alone.

Impressive. Part of the "village" at the terminus of nong ping 360, the monetary and the big guy on top of the hill are the clear highlights. The monastery as a whole is great but I enjoyed the hall with the 5 large golden Buddha to be my favorite. I also could not believe the size of some of the insence sticks the worshippers were wielding!

Perhaps one of the quieter monasteries.... Just across the way from the Tian tan Buddha is Po Lin Monastery. Now, the other year when I visited Beijing and visited a glut of temples and monasteries I was quite taken aback by the vast crowds of people, pushing and shoving each other in order to get a better view of whats inside. The act of queuing never caught on in mainland China, so you often found yourself doing as the locals do.I was expecting the same at Po Lin, and you can imagine my surprise at how peaceful and almost tranquil it was. There were people there, but not the huge throngs of humanity showing disrespect to one another.We were able to walk up to the main building, take a peek inside, take pictures where we were allowed, and then go about our business elsewhere. Though admittedly it might have been quite just because of the time we visited. I'd like to know how busy it gets at the height of the holiday season...The monastery consists of several buildings - the "Main Shrine Hall of Buddha", the "Hall of Bodhisattva Skanda", and, of course, the Tian Tan Buddha (though you could argue that this is a separate attraction). There is also the "Grand Hall of Ten Thousand Buddhas", the "Library" and the "Dharma Hall". Basically a haven for the Buddhist religion.It's a very nice place to visit and should be part of your visit to the Big Buddha.

Go see the big guy!. Take the tram if you're not in a hurry (the bus is faster, usually with little or no wait) as the views are spectacular. Find your OM! at the statue and chill with the Big Buddha...

A day to reflect and relax. This place is beautiful. Pure bliss. It was a long travel by bus but the views are majestic. The place is full of people praying the smell of incense is all over the place but I don't mind. The view inside is so beautiful too bad they wouldn't allow you to take photos. Well as they say, the great ones are not caught on cam!
Worth a visit. Good tourist attraction. Typical place for a tourist to visit in Hong kong. The sheer size of the statue is something to visit once at least.

Impressive Structures. the Po Lin Monastery has become one of the most renowned and most popular tourist destinations in Hong Kong. The Monastery consists of the the Great Hall of Treasure, the Maitreya Hall, the Hall of Ti-tsang Bodhisattva, the Weituo Hall, the Banruo Hall, the Sutra-Collection Hall and other impressive structures.

Great maintenance. Try use the bus if cable car is long wait. We could not get to the cable car as it was real long wait. The bus service takes 45mins from the citygate station. We reached mid day on sunday, crowd was acceptable.

Great view at the top. The view on top of the Buddha was great, but you needs to climb lots of steps to get to the top ( sorry, no elevator ). I would not recommend to walk up if you are not in good health.
amazing. A must visit when you are in Hong kong. Close to Regal Airport hotel. beautiful scenery and amazing view with total calmness..

Very impressive. The Monastery consists of the Da Xiong Bao Dian (the Great Hall of Treasure), the Maitreya Hall, the Hall of Ti-tsang Bodhisattva, the Weituo Hall, the Banruo Hall, the Sutra-Collection Hall and other impressive structures. In the Da Xiong Bao Dian, for example, are enshrined three Buddhas - Sakyamuni, Dipamkarara and Maitreya. In the Hall of Ti-tsang Bodhisattva there stands a bronze statue of Ti-tsang Bodhisattva, which weighs approximately 200 kilograms (441 pounds). There is also a 1,000 kilogram bronze bell.

One of my favorite places in Hong Kong. I really like this place, the Monastery near Big Buddha. It is free to go to and has many locals and some tourists. You go there on the same excursion as seeing the Big Buddha. It is about 4 easy blocks from the base of Big Buddha. You get to the courtyard outside of the Monastery and there are swarms of people buying sticks or larger of incense and placing them in large offering pots near the entrance. The smells and visuals were super. Then you walk through the first courtyard and see the main Temple area which has three stunning Gold Buddhas amidst some lotus and orchids, then behind that is a giant room holding 5 larger buddhas and smaller buddhas all over the four walls, hard to explain but dont miss it, I did not see this during my prior visit. The Monastery has food, all veggie, you can buy a meal ticket there or down at the base of the Big Buddha. Surely an enduring highlight of my visit.

Po Lin. Unfortunately when we went to the monastery some officials were there and we could not go inside, but we still had the vegetarian lunch, and if was beautiful, loved it, and I am not a vegetarian.

Small stop while on Ngong Ping. Nice little area of Ngong Ping. The monastery has some stone table and benches in front under some trees. The monastery itself is of course beautiful and the golden Buddha are amazing. There is also a spot for prayer with incense and there is even a small food place around the side that sells vegetarian dishes. There are also many cows just walking around.

The Buddha - its spectacular. Take the tram and travel to Lantau to see the Buddha.This venue has lots of eateries and places to have a drink together with shops to purchase mementos. There photo opportunities of the Buddha from the bottom of the 250 or so steps or if you are sup;er energetic you can walk up the steps to stand directly at the feet of the Buddha. Most people walk up a bit, then rest a bit, walk up a bit, then rest a bit, so don't be embarrassed to follow suit.I would imagine it might not be great on a day that is raining so try to go if it is dry and bright ....... not always possible in Hong Kong though!!There is no fee to see the Buddha - the only cost involved is the tram ride.

Great place and great view!!!. I can recommend that place to every person, who likes going for a walk in the fresh air. You should spend there all day long, because there is many interesting places to see there. Big Budda - is the main sightseen there.

Nice but crowded with tourist buses even on weekdays.. Took a bus to Ngong Ping from Mui Wo (Po Lin monastery says the sign at the bus terminal) which was maybe 40minutes? Headed to Po Lin monastery for a quick look and a meal. Do try the beancurd dessert there. Although I went on a Tuesday, the Buddha area was rather packed with tourists. I didn't go up stairs to the Buddha, and then headed to the Wisdom Path. I absolutely enjoyed the walk and it's very peaceful. There is a small dirt path upslope at the Wisdom Path where it's a lookout spot to see the Buddha's back view. Afterwhich, I walked through to Ngong Ping village for the bus to Tai O.
Peaceful. Perfect place to reflect, catch your breath and relax after climbing down from the Buddha. The incense along with the beautiful flowers creates a feeling of serenity.

Not worth the trip. I'm sure this is a nice monastery, but when we were there, we were very annoyed with the long wait for a disappointing trip up. Totally spoiled the experience for us. Worth skipping.

The home of the grand seated Buddha has to be seen................ This iconic Buddha is huge and sits on a lotus petal base in a serene mode of blessing,accessible for many by car and public transport it rests peacefully in a replica old style village built specifically to catch the tourists and to make money from tiny restaurants and little shop outlets.The most spectacular way to arrive and depart is to take the cable car that runs daily,the journey seems for ever and I do not recommend this for anyone who has the fear of heights or motion sickness as if the winds are strong the ride can become a little scary,but a wonderful ride for the keen photographer.

Average. . We visited this monastery because I wanted to see a special door that I was in a picture when doing research about our trip. When we got there, we realized that it is more commercialized and touristy spot than spiritual and sadly, because they are renovating, they had gotten rid of that antique a few months back. I wouldn't recommend going there if your time is limited.

avarage. Nicely build but you do not feel the spirituality ooze off from this place. It is one of those tourist must do and after an hour your done. Recommend go all the way to the back where the golden buddhas are

Very nice scenery. You can go up by cable car or bus.. It is a nice place to visit. The weather is very cool. There are a lot of restaurant where you can enjoy the foods and weather as well. It can be cold in the winter so you may need a jacket.

Beautiful Part of Hong Kong. We really enjoyed the beautiful cable car ride and seeing Po Lin. However, the line to purchase cable car tickets is ridiculous and moves very slowly. While in the line, we noticed an option to purchase tickets online. Unfortunately, those were sold out the day that we were there so I would recommend getting there as early as you can manage and get the crystal car if you can manage it. It does cost more, but there was no line so we were able to pass by everyone and get on. The cable car ride is beautiful but we wouldn't do it again without tickets purchased in advance.
Great Vegatrian meal. Went there on a tour, village and cable car. The vegetarian lunch is very filling. Don;'t have breakfast!

Blessed!. Amazing and incomparable experience seeing the Buddha closely. It was one of the moment in my life where I felt like I was blessed by the Buddha. Recommended for all the traveler and a must see place in Hong Kong
Nice trip and impressive Buddha. Take the 25-30 minute cable car ride here and you will be impressed. The other sites around it are somewhat touristic but it is a pretty amazing site!

Nice day out. To get to Tung Chung station is easy. But from there it starts difficulties... You can either take the bus ( probably easier) or cable car ( sure much nicer), but in order to get tickets for cable car you have to stand in a looong line ( about an hour) so what you would get the tickets, and another 20-30min waiting until you get in a cable car. I would suggest to get tickets online, when you just skip the waiting line. Once you get up its really nice, Buda statue, monastery ( you can have a lovely meal next to it), plenty of places to get nice souvenirs. On the way you have back same problem : waiting in a line to get the cable car.

One big buddha!. Having had the blessing of visiting the giant buddha in Kamakura Japan, I was ready for just another buddha. Not the case! From the walk up to the moment you hit the landing, this buddha towers over the one at Kamakura. One can walk inside the base of the buddha and walk up further if you buy a ticket before heading up the stairs. It's not expensive so do the upgrade along with the vegetarian meal. On our first visit, the weather was cool and clear. On my second visit, it was windy and foggy. The "village" is just a bunch of shops shlepping junk. Come on! Is there nowhere that is sacred? Starbucks??

Ok to see one time only. Its kinf of long ride by public tranportation.Its moderm Budda Statue, not very impressive. But view from the hill is ok. Also some trail starts from there all the way the down.

Feel the calm.... The monastery has been well kept and cleanly maintained. We appreciated the trip. This monastery is rich with very colorful manifestations of Buddhist iconography. It also has a restaurant inside the campus that serves tasty vegetarian food.

Get a Octopus. One can easily take a train to Tung Chung station. From there you have a option to take a car cable or bus 23 to Ngong Ping. I took the bus as the Q for car cable is too long (about 1.30hrs wait) and bus fare at 17.20HKD for weekday and 27HKD for weekend and Public Holiday. Get exact amount as no change given. Good if you have a Octopus card (Train/Bus top up card). For 38HKD you can try the vegetarian snack meal at the monastery.

Well worth a visit. Take the cable car for stunning views but pre book if you can as the queue for tickets can take up to an hour.very touristy around the Monastery and Big Buddha but is worth the triptake the MTR which is quick and cheap
Just amazing. We did this as part of a tour. The Buda is HUGE and can be seen from nearly anywhere on the island. If your fit you can take the 400 steps up or down to the monastery.
Beautiful. Both Buddhists and tourists, a fascinating site, the monastery is well worth walking over to from the Buddha itself

Exciting glass bottom cable car ride!. Take the glass bottom cable car from just outside the Tung Chung metro station. Adults and kids will equally enjoy the cable car experience. Once you reach the island, the Buddha statue and monastery are within walking distance. There are restaurants and souvenir stores in the same area. The architecture in the monastery is worth appreciating.

Site of the Great Buddha. Perhaps, not the most startling of monasteries, but one certainly geared up to receive visitors. (vegetarian restaurant, souvenir stalls, etc). But it is a working monastery and is the site of the Great Buddha. And it is not somewhere you would want to miss.

Giant Buddha. Located on Lantau island, we took the MTR Tung Chung station exit B, they have clear direction, this is really a giant buddha, can see it from a far distance. This place open between 10am to 5:30pm, we try to avoid the heat and go there early, climb up over 80 steps to see the bronze buddha with great views, worth the visit.

Not as impressive as suggested. Was looking forward to a great meal in the monastery (as written up in guide books) and it either wasn't open (there was a huge room which could have been a restaurant) - or overrated - there was like a foodhall shop where you could purchase. Maybe wrong season.Monastery itself interesting to look around.

Buddhism not at its Best ! Void of Peace and Bliss!. This monastery is unlike the Theravada monasteries, the most ancient form of Buddhism, its Mahayana Buddhism developed out of the Theravada tradition roughly 500 years after the Buddha attained Enlightenment. Unlike even the wonderful largest Buddha and Visiting centres in Kaohsiung Taiwan which is also Mahayana Buddhism in Taiwan Nuns and all are Far more Friendlier and welcoming and Allow Photo taking and are Open and transparent in every way as with Theravada monasteries and Buddhism. Indeed Buddha welcome questions and was Kind and compassionate alas this monetary etc is not!In the Temple monastery as with the Big Buddha (Not the largest) If one dares to Climb to the top of the Big Buddha and see an opening under the Buddha where a female 'security guard' is (with No Signage saying don't enter) Please don't enter you'll be Loudly and very Rudely Shouted at and Rudely Waved away with hostility! Certainly No Compassion there, No Transparency or Kindness where Photo taking or anything else is concerned in this Temple monastery! Even the Nuns will Meanly skulk around. Again Totally Unlike the largest Buddha complex in Kaohsiung Taiwan where Nuns and people are Compassionate and Kind to Tourists and Visitors alike and are directly from the same Mahayana Buddhism!
Spectacular. This is the most amazing temple in HK. It is such a peaceful temple, has great architecture and great views.

awesome natural view , fresh breath trip. there are alot to tell when you talk about that cool place,because it combined between the old ages spiritual feelings & the natural beauty ,it really deserve the visit no matter what ,you will never regret if you wanna visit it . it deserve the visit ,cool interesting place .
worthed visit. We'll alil suffer to reach this place after step on the stairs. I dont know how many stairs there... hehe. But its really worthed. We'll get breathtaking view. Soooo beautiful

A Day's Outing. We visited the Po Lin monastery along with the Big Buddha on our recent trip. We arrived at the cable care station in Tung Chung via a cab and took the cable car to the top. It is advisable to book the cable car through a travel agency as there is huge queue to buy on spot cable car tickets and it takes a long time, which we skipped as we prebooked through the agency.The cable car ride in itself is very picturesque, it takes ~25 mins to reach the top and the view is awesome. The monastery is an oasis and very well kept the inner chamber is just breathtaking.
Beautiful View, Advanture trip. Beautiful view during the journey but quite scare for people who be afraid of high because have to use a cable car.
An amazing trip and view - Well worth the time and $. Veg meal was fabulous, glass bottom gondola was unbelievable, tour guide was great, excellent value!

Mesmerizing. When we visited the Big Buddha, it was a very cloudy day, which made the cable car trip from Tung Chung MTR to Ngong Ping on the Ngong Ping 360 cable car even more special. Although a bit on the expensive side, the cable car ride was one of the best we had experienced. Taking in the sights of Lantau Island, passing the airport on the way, overlooking the bay... it was just incredible.At the top, at the Ngong Ping Village, the weather was much the same, with a constant cloud cover. The village was meticulously clean and the shops were really incredible. Just stepping in to the village itself brought sense of calm and relaxation on us. We started to feel at peace with ourselves and our environment. It was the start of a special journey through the village, leading up to the Big Buddha statue!Leaving the Ngong Ping Village, the path to the Big Buddha was flanked on both sides by the Twelve Divine Generals. These statues were absolutely incredible and they represent the Chinese Zodiac. I couldn't help notice that some of the names were similar to some of our Hindu gods, suggesting a lot of similarities in both religions.Looking up at the base of the Big Buddha's attraction, we could hardly see anything. The 260 steps leading up to the statue were obscured by the cloud cover. We started climbing steps, thinking it would be a tiring climb, especially for our 6 year old daughter, but we managed it with ease.The Big Buddha statue is awesome! We spent about an hour up there, just walking around and visiting the inside of the statue. It was an experience that cannot be easily described in words. You have to go there to feel what we felt.

If u like a but of culture on your holiday then go. If u like to visit placea like this and u dont have to religious then go. Its nice attraction but be aware- line car to it is extremly busy! I standed in the line for 1,5 hour out of seazon!

Fantastic. The Po Lin Monastery is a great place of interest. It is just a short walk away from the Big Buddha on Lantau island. The Monastery itself is very calming despite the number of tourists. At the backside of the Monastery there is also the hall of 10,000 Buddhas which is a must visit. the grandeur of the hall is a sight to behold.

Visited twice and still love it!. Take MTR to Tung Chung and walk to the bus terminal to take bus 23 which stops in front of Po lin monastery. I didn't bother to try the cable car...the queue is horrible especially during weekends and public holidays. You cannot enter the main shrine but can enter the one below it. It houses the 3 Bodhisattvas, Avalokitesvara, Samantabhabdra and Manjusri. Purchase the meal ticket near the bottom of the steps to the Buddha or right next to the restaurant and get free entry to musuem beneath the Big Buddha which houses a Buddha relic. Walk up to the Big Buddha on a clear day and it would seem like the Buddha is moving with the clouds. View from the top is great. There is path 15mins away from the main shrine called Wisdom Path which is also lovely.
Beautiful. Beautiful monastery and beautiful landscape. And also worth going to this place to admire their structures and the buddha

Interesting. Knowing a little about Buddhists/religion would help appreciate this. Personally I don't need an imaginary friend.Everything seems magnificent and extravagant, bright colours, large everything. Didn't see a Monk all day.Restrictions on photo taking in some areas, didn't seem to stop most though.Only loaded 2-3 images everything seems to covered otherwise
Beautiful temple and landscape. Beautiful temple to experience a cultural and spiritual experience. Easy access to HKG Hong Kong airport, within 1 hour. the landscape is beautiful.

Monastrey. The monastery was a great to visit, such great detail to the temple design. Lovely to see. The food at the temple isn't great. Seeing the big Buddha was very cool. The warrior statues on the way to the temple were interesting

Definitely worth a trip. The monument is huge but I was more impressed by the setting of the monastery, its gardens, ambiance. This is not to say that you should not go up to the big Buddha. You should.

Escape from city. We went from Tung chung with cable car to the Big Buddha. There is a special guide tour That include Cable car,bus to Tai O, Boot trip in Tai O and a guided tour at Big Buddha. It also include a fast pass too the cable car ( saves you a lot of que time)Its only a cost little bit more if you gonna do it by yourself, But you get a fast pass and a guide. I would recommend it if you are a tourist and go there for the first time.Save me 1,5 Hour Que time and time to search transport to Tai O.We went shopping in Tung chung Outlet afther it :)And i LIke the view there and YES you need to go up by Stairs :) take some drinks with you :)

Beautiful and peaceful. This is a nice day trip outside of downtown Hong Kong. The air is much cleaner and less humid. The grounds are beautifully kept and the statue is an impressive sight from both far and near. Climbing the 268 steps can be a challenge in the extreme heat so take your time and make sure you have water! Definitely worth a couple of hours of your time.

A "Must see" attraction when in HK!. Very impressive and a great walking experience. Highly recommend but be open-minded when it comes to the very long lines. Perhaps going during the weekday would be advisable.

Splendid. A very nice place to visit. After reaching the Lantau island by cable car we reached this place by walk. We had a fantastic vegetarian lunch. The Monastery is a huge one with beautiful colours and interesting statues.
Worthy walk. Easy & nice walk. Easy transportation to there. Also hiking path nearby. May catch sunrise nearby. Vegetarian enthusiasts can order food in the temple.

Beautiful visit . Beautiful place to visit. Free entry with the option of eating at the vegetarian restaurant for $98 or delux $138 (HK) banquets including admission to the museum. To get to Lantau island We caught the ferry from central to Mui Wo and then got the bus to the monastery. Getting home we took the cable car down to tung Chung and got the train back from there.

Great day out - lovely and relaxing!. Very relaxing visit, we tried the vegetarian menu and it was great! Would highly recommend it to anyone wishing to relax and find out more about the monastery & buddhism. Great to walk around the island too, the air is beautifully clean. Loved it!

Well worth the visit. A beautiful peaceful place with great views over the island. There is a small but informative museum. We did this through an organised tour so we could avoid the long line up for a ticket to travel up to the site.

See my Lantau Island & Big Buddha review - as they are all in the same place on Lantau Island. You have to buy a ticket to get into the sitting Buddha. If you wish to sample the vegetarian meal you ask for this when you buy your ticket before you walk up to the Buddha. Scrumptious meal and cheap. I enjoyed it.

I love this place. This is a great day out. We didn't eat with the monks this time, but just enjoyed the monastery. I bought some lovely souvenirs and walked the steps to the giant Buddha.Take a hat as it can get hot.
Great outing. The monastery is beautiful, very relaxing and worth the visit to see and understand the buddist religion.

One of the top ten places to visit. The monastry is one of the top ten places to visit in HK. Most time of the day overcrowed by tourists, however, it is still a serious place to worship and some buildings are not allowed to take pictures.

"Amazing Big Buddha". This is one of the thing you would say "I am so glad Idid this". It is breath taking. Very easy to go and do it by yourself, don't need a guide.We took the train and the cable car to get there . Very easy and reasonable.
Peaceful. This is a must visit location, offering a different side of Hong Kong. The experience is relaxing and the side trip to Tai O is essential as it also shows a traditional village.
Small Museum. Is located under Buddha so after finishing from seeing Buddha enjoy small ride to this historic place with amazing design and great organization

Must visit the Big Buddha. The day we went there, the cable cars were on maintenance. We ended up taking a taxi and it cost $160 HKD from Tung Chung to Big Buddha. With 4 people sharing the ride, this was the best choice. Once there, the attraction and scenery were amazing. If you are an elderly, it may be wise to just stay at the bottom as the climb up to the Big Buddha could be strenuous. There are also shops you could do all your souvenir shopping.
Great to tour along with the Big Buddha.. Very interesting and a must-see. Recommend taking as a tour with the Big Buddha. Eat at the vegetarian restaurant.

A must go attarction. Really good place to go. Cable car to go out, take crystal cable car can save your time to wait at the queue. Buy tickets online is gonna help you to save a lot of time believed me! You can never imagine how long the queue is!!

Flying High on a Glass Bottom Tram. What a trip!. This was an amazing trip for us! We paid the extra for the crystal (glass) bottom carriage it was worth the extra $10 for the upgrade. Like many other reviews, the best time to go is in the morning during the hot summer months. There are some decent restaurants once you get to the area surrounding the Big Buddha. This was definitely one of my favorite memories in HK. You can also walk to the Buddha but it takes up to 6 hours from what I hear from others.
Absolutely amazibg. Don't miss going here when you come to see the BIg Buddha, the temples are breathtaking. Please be respectful to the worshipers

Po Lin. We went to Lantau to visit the Big Buddha, and while there we went to see the monastery as well. I'm so glad we had a look around as it really is beautiful. Make the most of your Buddha visit and go explore.

Po Lin Lantau Island. Po Lin Lantau Island is a great day out. The Cable Car ride is most enjoyable. The cable car takes you to a quaint little village where the biggest bronze statue of Buddha exists. Just make sure you line up and leave on time to catch the cable car. The last one leaves around 4 pm and the queue is super long. If you miss the cable car then the Buses are available. The Bus ride down the mountain is pretty scary. The attractions at the village are cool. Inside the Buddha there is a small chapel with the ash remnants of Buddha, himself, given to China by India upon his death.

Precious Karma. A tranquil Buddhist sanctuary. Not to be missed. Colourful and religious for all. Divine for the faithful. Overall, a place to lose oneself or to do some soul searching. Remarkable Dragon Pillars adorn the Worship Chamber. There's additional wings, halls being constructed. Making it more precious, we hope!
Good to go. It is nice place to go. But you don't actually need to go in the inside of budda statue. Nothing much.

Thoroughly enjoyable...and popular. The cable car ride to here is full of breathtaking scenery. The monastery was actually more interesting than the Big Buddha statue to be honest (which doesn't have much going for it!!)

Mesmerizing. Bring good walking shoes, umbrella, HK dollars, good camera. The views are amazing, both from the cable car and at the summit. You will do quite a bit of walking and you can also go up and down the steps that lead to the main temple (267 steps). It rained the whole time we were there, so the umbrella was handy. There are various gift shops, so bringing some money is helpful if you want refreshments or gifts. We took the cable car to get here. We found the tour through our hotel. This allowed us to bypass the long lines at the cable car loading areas and it also included a vegetarian lunch which was excellent.
Peaceful Place. Definitely visit the monastery while on Lantau Island. It was a very peaceful atmosphere and the temples are incredible. Worth the visit.

Try Crystal Cabin is awesome. Take the Cable Car from Tung Chung Station it is very awesome scenery for about 30 min ride. Buy online ticket will helpfull , no need having long queue , they have special counter for redeem the voucher. If having more budget can try the crystal cabin , it is faster queue and you will have experience with crystal floor cabin.
Po Lin and Big Buddha Side by Side. You get two attractions in one here, and after viewing the Big Buddha, spend time inside the monastery - the decorated ceilings are incredible.

Amazing. Its a beautiful place which has a mythical air about it. The cable car ride is fabulous and this is a must do in your trip to hongkong. Sadly we went on the last day of our stay and didnt have much time to explore.The place is like a piece of heaven. Be prepared for long queues for the cable car. It is advisable to book the tickets online as the queue for online booking is much smaller. Give this an entire day if not more in your itinerary. The weather can disrupt the cable car service. So pray before you go :-)
Big Buddha, Lantau Island. will probably take you a few stops to get to the top. great view from the summit and look out for quite a few interesting gift shops along the way

Spectacular and monumental. Well worth the trip to Lantau Island and the long steps that you need to climb, the view from the top it's also breathtaking! Make sure that you buy a bottle of water from below at the little stores.

Beautifully Ornate Temple and Vegetarian Restaurant. The Monastery buildings are a short walk around from the Big Buddha. The carvings are so ornate and definitely worth a close up view. Also be sure to go into the Grand Hall of Ten Thousand Buddhas - the gold is almost blinding! On our visit, the cloud cover descended, which gave a slight ethereal feeling to the place. On the way out, throw a coin in the cauldron - it's not as easy as it sounds!

Big Buddha. Always worth a visit here, especially now there is the cable car, must less vomit inducing than the old bus ride. Pace yourself with the walk up to the Big Buddha and take an umbrella to shade under.There's ac vegetarian restaurant in the monastery you can try. There's also ian ice cream vendor....
Crowded popular tourist attraction. Really crowded.So many tourists were here when I visited. Nice views from here and the Bhudda is very impressive.

A must see. Great day out and a must see when in Hong Kong. Use the cable car to get there and then get the ferry back to HK. The Big Buddha is inspiring. 250 steps is not to bad and worth it as the view is great.

Po Lin - Must visit in HK. Have been to Po Lin Monastery while I was Hong Kong. I would say it is the most calm and peaceful part of HK. There were crowd near the big Buddha statue but most of the shrines were empty. Visited all the shrines and each halls of them. Lot of sculptures maintained there and each may have a story to tell in history. A must visit in HK...
The Hong Kong Boudha. try to go by foot as there is very nice trails with view on the Boudha and to return with the cable car as you won t have to stand in line to long

Enjoy the beautiful countryside and spectacular views of the airport!. I always enjoy taking visiting family - despite the heat. A well organised activity with great access from Tung Chung Outlet Mall.

Peace & Bliss!!!. Got here through my transit through Hongkong enroute to San Francisco. You have to take the Cable car from ngong ping 360 to get here. The cable ride is amazing with beautiful views of the ciy and the HK islands. You will pass a replica of the bodhi tree while on the way to this monastery.
Po Lin.. Here my family and I got to pray in peace also focus. Clean and holy. Some areas photography not allowed , respectful.

Huge statue !. Been to this place with friends on Feb this year, everything was amazing we had great time walking through the village with many of restaurants. Whoever going to Hongkong this place is a must to visit.

A Peaceful Place to Visit. Take the cable car to Lantau, See the Big Buddha and this peaceful Monastery there. The Buddha will blow your mind. The Po Lin is there. I was confused as to how many Monasteries and or temples there actually were there, but I think it's because I was taking pictures and so excited about the beautiful sunny day. The kind of place you want to spend the whole day and just contemplate, writing in a journal or eating rice cake snacks and lots of water.

Tourist attraction. A little disappointed. Expected a much quieter place. Its a vast complex to walk around with many little sights but it seems very commercialized. The shops lining the roads are good to browse and pick up some curios.

Magnificent Temple. Firstly to get to this temple there is a very interesting cable car ride. The main temple houses three bronze statues of the Buddha – representing his past, present and future lives. It certainly attracts many for their daily devotions and there is a genuine Buddhist dining hall for those who want the traditional food.

Nothing great. Its a monastery on top on Big Buddha. one of the must visit places in HK. It shows some good history about the Buddha and Buddhism. Nothing great but as you are already here in NgongPing 360, you can pay a visit here.
Visitor. An experience from the different norm of hectic life. So peaceful and calm. An insight into a different life

A must visit on Lantau island. It is a must visit on Lantau island! I have been there many times still enjoy seeing it. You can take MTR from Hong Kong or bus s64,s1 from the airport to Tung chung. From Tung Chung you can take cable cart or bus to big Buddha. But make sure you go early for cable carts as it can be very busy!!

Loved the Monastery, the shrine and the trails around it. There are a number of buildings here that look like a monastery but the first one is Po Lin and it is lovely! You approach the area through the incense that is lit to make offerings. The bug buddha sits prominently in the background. The temple was founded in 1906 as a Buddhist Temple. It has 3 bronze buddhas that represent the past, present and future. As you approach the Temple coming from the Big Buddha you will pass through as area selling souvenirs . We spotted several monks in this area. Behind the Monastery you can find a Shrine of 10,000 Buddhas which is truly amazing. There are trails in the property that lead to an old boarded up Tea house and to the Path of Wisdom and Lantau Peak.

I would still go back and remenis, find a quiet corner and meditate.. Love the Monastery, but do eat in the more expensive food place as it can be not to your liking at the cheaper one. The sad news is that the tranquillity of this soul touching place seams to have been lost in the money making side of things, such a shame, as year ago it was a place of soul and spirituality. Still worth a visit.

Nice, but not necessary during your time at Ngong Ping. Thought I'm not proud of my opinion, to me, monasteries are monasteries are monasteries. Since you are already up by the Big Buddha there is no reason not to stop in, but it is nothing special. I would rather visit the Wong Tai Sin Temples for this type of tourist visit. There is a vegetarian restaurant to the side of this temple. Order food by yourself; the package deal thing was not delicious.
10.000 Buddas. So you just get to the Big Buddha. aftrer seing it just wonder around the island. Treasures are hidden here and dont be afraid of going around the island.

Beautiful place, calming place. A lovely Monastery with buffalo roaming around the grounds, it was a very hot/humid day when we went in August so I would suggest the cooler months if possible.Highlight was the monks chanting in the afternoon, such a calming experience away from the city.However I wouldn't suggest the cable car on a weekend, get the bus it is approximately 30 mins, air conditioned and only 55HK. In addition the bus drops off away from the tourist village of Nyong Ping so we avoided that. Overall I had a great day and would recommend a visit.

Disneyland for Buddhists. I was a little disappointed of that place, because it is completely touristic and overcrowded. It´s hard to find the connection to belief. It is full of tourst shops, pizza, kebab, Starbucks and all the rest of what we call civilization. I am not sure, if this has a lot in common with what it was once meant. If you manage to filter this all out, the statue and the landscape is quite impressive. Calculate at least one hour for lineup if you did not buy a ticket in advance.
Love this place. I have been here so many times in past several years. And I do like to go back. It was nice and peaceful trips.

Peaceful !. Had a lovely day visiting Lantau and found the monastery particularly interesting (and strangely peaceful even on a busy tourist-packed day). Make sure to eat at the small food court which offers great vegetarian food at very low prices... a good way to try lots of local foods in one place.
MUST SEE. We had the most amazing time visiting here. It leaves me speechless. It is a MUST DO when in HK. The cable car ride out is amazing, splurge and go for the glass bottom car.

Wonderful, colorful and peaceful. You have to distinguish between Big Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery itself.This is such a lovely place to visit when you took the trip up. Don't miss it.Visit the Grand Hall of Ten Thousand Buddhas, it's really worth it, and have a closer look at the walls nearby. Eplore the temple as there is a hidden pond with a nice view on Big Buddha ;)
Amazing place, peaceful!!!. This buddha is an amazing monument all bronze made, you cant believe the size! and the Monastery is amazing, very nice chambers! Don't miss the 10,000 buddhas chamber!!!

Biggest Buddha in the world. If you don't believe in Chinese god, they will convince you.
And for fun, I also bought the tiny little zodiac patch. Every year, each animal will be offending the animal god.. (something like that), and you need a patch to protect yourself. Meh, I got one too, its a very nice piece of art and story behind it.

Great view, TONS of stairs.. The Po Lin Monastery was a fantastic side trip during our week in Hong Kong! It was literally in the clouds. What an awesome feeling. There are a TON of steps but the View at the top is completely worth it. Not to mention, it seems to be quite a bit cooler than sea-level.
wonderful experience.. love the free flow of rice. this is the spirit of doing charity work. wonderful food too and fast serving.

Worth making plans to see. Slightly more tourist-oriented than during my first visit in 1989 but still a truly moving experience. Take your time to immerse yourself in contemplation to really get a feel for the beauty of the intricate architecture and wander the manicured garden area.

Incredible Monastery. We visited the Po Lin Monastery as part of our half day on Lantau Island and it was quite impressive. There was virtually no queue to get into the monastery or it's surrounding gardens which are both beautiful. There were thousands of people climbing the Buddha but very few in the monastery which seemed a bit backwards but was good for us. I do get that the big Buddha is great for pictures while the monastery is less engaging for anyone looking through your travel pictures but it is still a wonderful monastery with lots of history. When you do Lantau please check out the monastery too, it is worth your while and the food from the restaurant smelled and looked really good.

Must do when in Hong Kong. Just taken some friends for their first visit to the Big Buddha, they thought it was wonderful even though the weather was very hot. This was my umpteenth visit and it has lost some of its appeal for me but I still enjoyed the visit.The cable car + the Big Buddha plus Tai O plus the dolphin boat ride at Tai O make a very good day out.

Very peaceful yet powerful place.. We visited this temple during a celebration for one of the deities and were lucky enough to see the hall of a thousand Buddhas during one of its rare opening times. The temple is decorated very beautifully and reminded me of Tibetan/Bhutanese temples I have seen. The grounds are kept very well and despite the huge numbers of tourists there is a very peaceful feeling to the whole complex.Well worth a visit if you've come up to see the cable car or the Big Buddha.

would definately return. great day out here, used the cable car to get up and down on my last trip, next time i think i would try the hike as it looked lovely and peaceful. the buddha itself is amazing, the sheer size is unbelieveable. there are a few stalls where you can buy gifts, magnets etc. also at the bottom of the steps leading up to the buddha there is a fantastic shop which tells you the history of jade and some awesome jade jewellery and ornaments.at the entry of lantau island there are a selection of shops and places to eat and drink. the shops can be a bit pricey for certain things but the restaurant we went to for a beer and a pizza slice was reasonable. we went to see the show about the monk and the buddha, was really interesting and it was in 4d - definately worth going to see. would not hesitate to go again to po lin

Beautiful Place. For those who are interested in religious symbolism. The only thing is we arrived in the late afternoon on a weekend and had to turn back because the queue was too long (the staff told waiting time should be more then 2hours!!!!!! We went back on another weekday morning and this time around queued for abour 40min only.

Beautiful. I make a point of visiting the Big Buddha whenever I fly into HK, and with it is a visit to Po Lin Monastery. This is such a special place. I feel at total peace when visiting, and feel so honoured to witness the monks chanting. Make sure to light some incense for those who have passed on. A very sacred and special place.

Make the effort. Worth the train ride, particularly when you can do a bit of outlet shopping on the way home. Catch the cable car up to Po Lin a very worthwhile trip, the views are terrific. Make sure you walk up the hundreds of steps to the Buddah. Have a meal Chinese of course before you head back.

Ok for Asians, might be interesting to non-Asians. Coming from an Asian background and having seen my fair share of temples, monasteries and so on, this didn't have the wow factor for me. I think the one with the 10,000 statues on Hong Kong Island is more wow simply due to the number of statues they have set up along this long, windy, steep path. But this monastery should be a pretty good visit for those who do not come from Asian countries.

A rewarding visit!. A quick trip from the airport to the Big Buddha takes you by bus or cable car. The Po Lin Monastery is nearby and worth a stop for lunch. Buy a combo ticket to the Buddha and lunch in the Po Lin restaurant (go for the better lunch - it is worth it!)

Peaceful place above Hong Kong. Visiting this amazing Budha + Monastery place at Lantau Island will bring you to completely different world compare to loud, busy and never-sleeping Hong Kong. Peaceful place offers you literally walk in the clouds. You'll meet local people with mountain dogs, cows (walking to the store :D) and will get a chance to taste some delicious street food. Once up, don't forget to take a short walk 'Wisdom Path' that will bring you to the stunning view at the bay....Plus already cable car ride to Budha it's worth it!!!
Huge Lord Buddha. It is actually the huge Buddha statue situated here. A great place to visit by cable car surrounded by great scenic beauty.
Colorful experience. Expected more, however the " golden room" was incredible. Quick to do as not much to see. Did not do the meal option
Nong-Ping + Monastery. Love the trip up to the monastery in Nong-Ping the cable car trip is breath taking and worth the money.

Dreams do come thru'!. Had a big dream of travelling to this Giant Buddha place, we made it up there and it was unbelievable! Caught the cable car, good view and it was more interesting when we started seeing the Giant Buddha from our cable car. Walked thru' the village and thereafter strolled along slowly (in the heat!!) towards the Giant Buddha! I think we had to endure around 260 steps each way but it was all worth it!! The vegetarian meals down below were quite nice as well!

Delicious lunch. My son and I visited the monastery recently in conjunction with climbing to the Giant Buddha and Cable Car Ride. We are both vegetarian so enjoyed the set menu lunch. We were the second group to be seated but the 10th to be served. The monastery itself was mildly interesting.
Visits all the halls .... There are many halls or shrine rooms dedicated to each Bodhisattva. The directional signs are not obvious though.

Monastary and Vegetarian Restaurant. I have been to a couple of temples and monasteries and this one is among those that is fairly average. I thought the location was magnificent but unfortunately they were undergoing renovations in certain areas.
