There is a beautiful golden viewing room back behind where the monks were praying that I almost missed due to the construction. The vegetarian restaurant was nothing to brag about but served some decent vegetarian meals. My friend and I ordered the basic meal and got a large amount of food for 98HK (the money goes to the monastery).

Big Buddha Status, Need to Climb up but fun.... We visited the Big Buddha Statue, a lot of steps, Need to Climb up but it's so much fun... We also took the bus to Tai O, tooks the boat trip, it was fun too.

Beautiful Temple.. It's been renovated early this year and it's a really nice stop after visiting the Big Buddha. I recommend to walk 20-25 mins to the Bamboo Area to relax a bit as well. Beware of mosquitoes as it's rural area in hKG..
A Must-See!. Po Lin Monastery houses the Great Hall of the 10,000 Buddhas! Now this was a breathtaking sight! Wow! The craftsmanship and details done in this hall was nothing short of spectacular!

Po Lin Monastery. The monastery was founded in 1906 by three monks visiting from Jiangsu Province on the Chinese mainland and was initially known simply as "The Big Hut" (大茅蓬 Tai Mao Pung). It was renamed to its present name in 1924. The main temple houses three bronze statues of the Buddha – representing his past, present and future lives – as well as many Buddhist scriptures.

Work of Art. Visiting the monastery was a wonderful experience. The colours, artwork and sheer size of the old monastery takes one back. A lot of talented hands went into the making of this fine building. There is a sense of calmness and tranquility when one walks in the building and surrounding garden. Watching Buddhists (probably on a pilgrimage) pay homage to the statues etc makes one feel spiritual (enough to light incense sticks, pause and pray).

A wonderful sight to behold.. If you're on your first time in Hong Kong and have an entire day for sightseeing, you should consider going to Lantau Island for this monastery. It's a huge Buddha statue that overlooks the area and is just plain outstanding.You can visit this by either taking the Ngong Ping cable car (the scenic route, also recommended!) or a ferry (for those who don't want to wait in line) and a bus (which you should take immediately after disembarking)

Beautiful. The journey (cable car) and the destination both are a treat. A few steps up to the Budhha Statue and you can have a panoramic view of surroundings.Cable car journey in itself is very nice and gives excellent views specially of the airport island.
A nice place for a bit of quite. This is a very special place. A must do in Hong Kong. Very easy to get to, by boat or train then cable car.

Worth a trip to Lantau!. We really enjoyed walking around this monastery. The architecture is amazing. Full of bright colors and details everywhere you look. Big Buddha is right next to this. We did not go up the stairs to see Big Buddha (snap a picture from down below). It was a hot day, and we were glad we spent our energy walking around Po Lin. You can purchase snacks and souvenirs at the base of Big Buddha.

Awesome. We loved visiting Po Lin temple, it was incredible so peaceful there and so interesting so pleased we decided to visit and stay on Lantau Island. Plenty of places to eat and also shops to buy memorabilia. All in all a wonderful day.
Kind of the only thing to see up there. Wasn't that impressive as we saw a lot of temples and buddhas before but when you made it to Lantau then you should have a look.

Very Nice place to Visit.. This is one of the best places in Hongkong to visit. I have visited this place in April 2015 with my friends. This place is cooler than Hongkong city. Good View of Buddha statue and pleasant atmosphere with sounds of Buddhist temple bells and prayers.
This is a precious place to visit. Each visit to Hong Kong includes a visit to Po Lin. It is serene for me and also a great place to have lunch and then take another walk around the monastery

AMAZING DECORATION. Good view of this from the Big Buddha but close up the decoration and artwork was stunning. Every surface is covered with carving or painted and the Hall of Ten Thousand Buddhas has to be seen to be believed. Good vegetarian food. Tacky shops as usual. Cable car suspended for maintenance so No. 23 bus - an experience in itself with good views of the coast.

Vivid architechture. The Po Lin Monastery is also situated in Lantau Island and can be visited together with the Big Buddha & the Wisdom Path. It is a collection of impressive and vividly colourful pieces of architecture that speak volumes about the cultural heritage of this location. It opens at 9.00am to public and closes at 6.00am. You get a better view of the overall structure at the top near the Big Buddha provided it is not misty. It is better to visit this location late morning or early afternoon. Can get a bit chilly depending on the weather so do have a sweater handy. There are restaurants serving vegetarian dishes.

Magnificent!. Reached this place by cable car. The Big Buddha Statue is magnificent and sits at the hilltop. Next to the staircase, visitors can pay visit to the temple and crowds are seen offering joss sticks. Further down the road, visitors can follow clear command of direction from signboard to "Wisdom Path" where Heart Sutra in Chinese are carved on woods. A good place to escape the busy city where the mind finds peacefulness.
Songkran. We were privileged to be able to visit Po Lin during Songkran. The monastery is beautiful and definitely worth a visit.
Monastery. Amazing decoration on the buildings. Rich and colourful. Reached by the cable car. Next to the Giant Buddha.

Lots of gold!. At the top of the Ngong Ping cable car, you pass through the village and through a grand arch to enter the monastery complex. To one side there is a long flight of steps up to the Big Buddha who sits serenely on a hilltop. Ahead is a round structure decked with colourful banners, and behind this the Monastery. Several areas are open to the public, and you come away with impressions of fierce gold figures, and incredibly ornate gilt decoration. The craftsmanship is magnificent, but I felt I would have to study Buddhism to understand what it all meant.
Majestic .... Would highly recommend a visit although the location is a little far away from everything. Should allow for a full day to take in the sights and a little shopping.
A glimpse into Buddhism. A "must see" when you visit Hong Kong. But PLEASE all you tourists, respect the sanctity of it!! It is a holy place for those who follow the religion.

Po Lin Monastery - Combine with a visit to the Big Buddha. Po Lin Monastery (free to visit) is found on Lantau Island. Constructed in the early 20th century, it is now one of the most popular monasteries to visit in Hong Kong, much to do with its proximity to the Big Buddha and Ngong Ping cable car. Opening Hours are 8am to 6pm every day. The feature attraction of the Po Lin Monastery is the recently opened (Oct 2014) Grand Hall of the Ten Thousand Buddhas. The Grand Hall and adjacent buildings display a colourful and decorative exterior that is lovely to view on clear days. The interior of the monastery is also worth having a look, make sure to see the three seated buddha figures. While you are on the monastery grounds, find the giant Reunification Cauldron which was made to commemorate the return to Hong Kong to the People's Republic of China. The large Mountain Gate Entrance to the monastery grounds is also interesting. Just a few minutes away you can visit the Big Buddha statue, while the Ngong Ping village is a few minutes further walk in the direction of the upper cable car terminus. Our preferred way to visit the Po Lin Monastery is to take the Ngong Ping 360 cable car from Tung Chung. This is an enjoyable and scenic approach to the area attractions. You can also take public bus 23 directly to the Ngong Ping Village, 5-6 minute walk to Po Lin Monastery. Tip: Other attractions on Lantau Island that you may wish to before or after Po Lin Monastery include the Citygate Outlet Shopping Mall back at Tung Chung, the nearby Tai-O fishing village (bus 21) or Mui Wo beach and village (bus 2). If visiting to/from Central, there is ferry service between Central an Mui Wo as well. For those with layovers in Hong Kong, you can take bus S1 between the airport and Tung Chung, just outside the Ngong Ping 360 lower terminus. The bus ride is 12-15 minutes one-way. Just be aware of the cable car opening hours (10-6pm weekdays, 9-6.30pm weekends) and potential queues at both the lower and upper terminuses. Note: Taxi service to/from the Po Lin Monastery is readily available at the airport but be prepared to wait for taxi service when coming back down the mountain as service is far more limited in that direction.

interesting trip. Visited the manastery as part of an organised tour and found it fascinating, allthough the smell and smoke of all the josticks was sometimes overpowering!!!!lunch was part of the trip and was served with some speed on large round tables seating up to twelve people , the food just kept coming, faster than people could eat it, cant comment on the qaulity personally as its not my thing but others said it was " authentic"

Big Buddha base camp. One visits the Po Lin monastery before taking the walk up the hundreds of stairs to the Big Buddha statue at the top of the hill. It was pleasant and calm as are all Buddhist monasteries. The vegetarian restaurant was very busy. The grounds are beautiful and it is very pleasant to stroll around admiring the various statues and architecture.

The Best View from Lantau Island. Excellent Experience! The only place worth to visit in that Nping Gong 360 cable car trip. A lot of people took this place as its final one of their earthly lives (some times looks like the Holocaust museum in Germany). Enjoy it and always be respectful.

Terrific but a tourist attraction. I live in HK and go up to Ngong Ping often when we have visitors. We advise getting the ferry to Mui Wo, then getting the number 1 bus to Tai O fishing village to enjoy that and then the 21 bus from Tai O up to the monastery. Now the Buddha and the monastery are tourist attractions as is the Ngong Ping "village". It is still fun and a very worthwhile place to visit to enjoy the mountains and the fresh air and I always enjoy my visits even though it is cheesy. The children loved it.The dim sum at the veggie deli is delicious and well worth a visit just for that.If going on the Ngong Ping 360 cable car I advise you do the trip down to avoid the queues in Tung Chung.

Reaching the Buddha on a Lantua Island plateu. The 1906 monastery was spared by the communist rulers. Today the complex high on a hill has a shrine with three large bronze statues, an erstwhile nunnery, an old tiny village and a beautiful plaza with large granite arch. Looming over the buildlings up a series of steep steps is Tian Tan, a giant Buddha statue. Even a short visit to this peaceful place, calms and soothes frayed nerves...It presents a counter-view to all that one experiences in hi-tech, material Hong Kong!

Thoughts on the Manastery. Took a ferry from Central (Pier 6) to Mui Wo in Lantau and then caught a Number 2 bus to the terminal at Ngong Ping. From there it was a short walk to the Po Lin Monastery.First impressions were of disappointment. As we walked through the crowds and under the entrance arch, the Buddha was hardly visible through the murk of pollution. Bought some drinks and ice creams from the numerous vendors and then started the climb up the long stairway of almost 300 steps to the Buddha. There were many tourists and worshippers but the main feeling was that this was a commercial attraction rather than a holy place.A quick descent was followed by a pleasant meal at the vegetarian restaurant and then a look around the various halls with their ornate design and religious artifacts and relics. Several visitors were happily ignoring the 'no photography' signs.There is no doubt that the the scenery is spectacular but there is a vast difference in atmosphere between this relatively recent Big Buddha (completed in 1993) and some of the really old temple sites in Sri Lanka or Myanmar. Perhaps the crush of visitors was the problem. Hard to avoid that in such a populous area.Overall, the initial disappointment was maintained throughout the visit. Others obviously disagree.

A beautiful sanctuary. This is another very colorful yet restful complex. As with the other religious sites we’d visited in the Hong Kong area, the carvings, statuary and colors were wonderful. One can buy incense in front of the first building, and we learned just how devoted a person could appear when we saw some incense sticks as large as a bazooka. Let me tell you, they put out some smoke! As with the Wong Tai Sin Taoist Temple, those with allergies and smoke sensitivities should anticipate a need to dodge occasional clouds of incense.

Meet the Buddha. The Po Lin is a beautiful monastery with gorgeous halls and beautiful Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. The food is plain and simple but healthy and nourishing - as it should be. This was my second visit in four and a half years and it felt both times like a mini pilgrimage: taking the boat from the centre of Hong Kong to Lantau then a coach to the the monastery before climbing the 264 steps to be next to the Tian Tan Buddha who dominates the landscape surrounded by Boddhisattvas. Inside the lotus upon which the Buddha sits, there is a well worthwhile exhibition. On the second floor (I think!) is simple painting of the Buddha 'going for it' : a depiction of utter fearlessness and openness to uncertainty and anything the future has to offer. It is breathtakingly inspiring every bit as much as the huge serenity of the parent which embodies it. After the climb and respectful visit treat yourself to the cablecar back down to the main island, preferably with a glass bottom. It takes just over half an hour I think, and you can see the planes landing, taking off, taxiing like toys at the start of your descent then as you get closer you can appreciate them for the sky dragons they really are.

silence, remote devine atmosphere. ok it is a bit of a trip, the is a cable car to one of the shopping centres, also MTR stop, you can go from the other side by taxi, or clomb the way up, which is easier than downbought some nice music there, i am nusually not in for this kind of thing, but it really brings you in the mood

WORTH the hassle of getting there!!. I admit to complaining pretty much the entire way from Kowloon to Hong Kong Island to the ferry that took us to Lantau Island to being jammed on a bus along a 45 minute ride to get to the Giant Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery. Fortunately, we had a private guide that helped us navigate the several legs of public transportation.Once there however, Po Lin Monastery was inspired. Set atop a mountain on Lantau Island, the Giant Buddha stands over 100 feet tall. Of course the 250 steps to the top are daunting, particularly for a dad with seven knee surgeries on his right knee! But it was worth it. The Buddha is amazing - inspiring at over 100 feet tall. Once down the steps, don't miss visiting the two main buildings of the Po Lin Monastery. The closest temple is an amazing site - every detail covered. But the next building over cannot be missed. The Grand Hall of 10,000 Buddhas was jaw-dropping.Do not miss the Po Lin Monastery if you have the chance.Before you go, we finished the tour by taking the 25 minute tram ride down to the city next to the airport where we caught a 35 minute cab ride back to Kowloon. My point is that despite my complaints about the hassle getting to Po Lin, it could have been much easier if we had just taken the taxi and fantastic tram ride both ways. Do that!

Well worth a visit - and good to combine going to the airport. Next to the airport, you can (or should ?) take the cable car from Ngong Ping (choose for a little extra the one with glass bottom) or walk the trail all the way.You can leave your luggage at the taxi stop at the foot.The Buddha it self is big..., really big and the temple behind magnificent.Food up there is not spectacular.But all in all enjoy the scenery and all the steps up to the sitting Buddha

Beauty beyond description. I was not prepared for this much beauty!Maybe it's because I have never visited any Buddhist monasteries before. But, oh my, what a surprise I got!No effort was spared in crafting the beautiful buildings. And the attention to the minutest detail was not lavished on the inside only! Oh no, even the roof and outside walls were given that extra-special attention.I wonder how long it took to complete that work of such magnificent beauty..."Beauty beyond description" doesn't do it justice! You simply have to see it to believe it.If ever you go to Hong Kong, make the effort of going to Po Lin on Lantau island -- it's worth the effort!

peaceful. The monastery was beautiful, quiet and peaceful. Even though there are many tourists visiting, they naturally don't make loud noises since there are many people who actually visit to pray. The ambiance of the place is majestic enough to make people fall speechless.

Nicely set monastery. Located a ten minute walk from the Ngong Ping Village is this monastery complex. There is a front courtyard with sculptures and ponds and incense is available for purchase for prayers. The monastery itself was an extraordinary building. The detail was incredible with reliefs, numerous timber carved animals and everything was brightly painted. Inside the main building was dedicated to the 10,000 buddhas. It was all gold and had a beautifully painted boxed ceiling. The entrance to the monastery was flanked by two large lion creatures. It was a nice place to stroll around and get away from the crowds in the village.

Well maintained, pretty place. Part of the broader Ngong Ping village and the Big Buddha (Tian Tan) complex, the monastery is to my mind the highlight of a visit to this area. To get to the Monastery you need to endure the very commercial Ngong Ping village, but you will be well rewarded by the walk up the hill to the Monastery.The main temple (into which we could not go due to a ceremony being underway) is lovely, with the Grand Hall of Ten Thousand Buddhas at the rear of the monastery being quite fabulous. The Grand Hall could be easily overlooked, so don't forget to walk up the stairs alongside the Monastery to get to the Hall. Well worth spending a little contemplative time here.

Lovely Monastery...!!. This beautiful monastery is located within the Ngong Ping Village and close to the Big Buddha. The monastery building its refurbish and well maintain. It has an amazing chinese architecture and there is a unique calm around the entire complex. The golden Buddhas and the hundreds of tiny Buddhas are a must!!

A pieceful working monestary. If you visit Tian Tan then I recomend that you take time to look at he beautiful monestary. The golden Buddhas are beautiful and the air is filled with the rich smell of insence. You can also have w vegetarian meal here and share it in the big dining hall. Great experience.

Do NOT miss Hall of ten thousand Buddhas !!. This is on top of one of the peaks on Lantau Island which you can get to via a few different ways we got here via the cable cars. The monastery is about a 5 walk from the cable cars. On the walk to the monastery there are warriors that signify the Chinese years. It also has big Buddha watching over it.The monastery is made of what I have always considered traditional Chinese building with engravings and dragons all over the building and its painted in bright colours. There are areas where you can burn essence sticks and there is lots of areas for worship which you would expect in a monetary, there is one hall which has 3 giant gold Buddha which are beautifully decorated even the ceiling is hand painted.Then there is the hall of warriors which has 6 gold statues of fallen warriors which again is amazing with all the detailed decoration but by far my favourite part of the monastery and the hall blew my mind right at the back so it isn't as easily found as the others is the hall of ten thousand Buddhas this hall is amazing and I could quite happily spend all day just looking at the detail in this hall their are 5 gaunt Buddhas being presented with gifts then there is a boarder of gold Buddhas going right around the hall then all around them are thousands of tiny Buddhas it's completely unbelievable you have to see it to believe it.So all in all loved the monastery but you can not miss the hall of ten thousand Buddhas !!
Day trip. This was a very interesting day trip everything was so colourful the temples are beautiful. Sits at the bottom of the big Buddha. We booked through the hotel

Calm. Very nice secluded monastery with decent architecture and a peaceful atmosphere. There isn't much to see but the complex designs on the outside of the buildings are beautiful and the inside of the biggest hall is an explosion of colour. There are many animals roaming around outside.Because this is so close to the "big Buddha" (a must see sight in its own right) you can easily do both in a few hours. I would recommend going if in the area.

"Zen". Lovely colors and the ambience is pure zen.Had vegetarian lunch here as part of the Tour of Tian Tan Buddha, was filling and satisfactory.You must take some shots of the Monastery and its adjacent areas from atop the Tian Tan Buddha.

Beautiful and calm. We visited this monastery on our way to the vegetarian restaurant from Big Buddha. It is a very beautiful place and brings you a very clam feeling. Colorful and complex roof structure of the buildings is amazing. Outside you can see very large incense sticks lit and offered to Buddha. Saw many locals worshiping here.This must be visited if you come to see the Big Buddha. It is about 3 minutes walk to your right from the steps down from Big Buddha.

Full of Tranquility. Journey to this monastery begins at the Tung Chung Cable Car station to Ngong Ping and then a short walk to the Monastery.This monastery is filled with tranquility. There is also a restaurant offering Chinese vegetarian meals for HKD98 or HKD138/person depending on which set you are choosing.There are about 3 halls in this monastery which are open to public to do prayers in front of statues of the Buddha. I find this place relaxing and calming, a good time away from the hustle and bustle of the city life.

Cheap and delicious. We had a wonderful lunch at the monastery, the food is vegetarian but you don't miss meat. It was fast and efficient service, not much English is spoken but they try hard to understand you. It was great

Do not visit Hong Kong and not visit this place. Utterly beautiful once past the repro village (tourist tat).The scenery, the big Buddha, & the monastery would each alone be worth the trip. Our visit included a vegetarian lunch in the dinning hall which was the best meal of its type my wife & I have ever eaten.

Visit it but skip the meal. While a visit was on our itinerary, we picked up the vegetarian meal token from a counter at the base of the Big Buddha. While the monastery itself was fascinating, like most religious places in Hong Kong, we didn't get much to understand what people were doing and what everything meant. It was soon meal time and we sat down at the table. We were served vegetarian food, alright. But what that meant was boiled vegetables (extremely large pieces), a ton of soup and heaps of rice. For an experience, I'd urge everyone to try it. If you are looking for quality food, though, look elsewhere.

Enjoyed my visit.. I got a bus there and back from Tung Chung. No queue, cheaper and a scenic bus ride. The village and area around the Big Buddha is tacky. There are a lot of steps up to the Buddha, but it's well worth the climb. The Buddha is huge, but the views from up there are also worth the climb. I actually enjoyed the little walks and trails in the area.

Very interesting monastery. Nice to walk around and take photos!. This monastery is much more interesting than the Tai O fishing village also in Lantau island. You can combine both by bus in one day. We didn't go up the stairs to the big Buddha as I thought was not really necessary. It's nice to get photos through the big gate entering the main yard of the monastery. Monastery buildings are nice and well kept with many chrysanthemum flowers. Overall a pleasant visit. Exiting the monastery area and walking down there are many nice shops with arts and crafts. We got things cheaper here than elsewhere. Even half price! Get your souvenirs here!

Must See in Hong Kong. This is a great addition to the Big Buddha adventure. It is very beautiful. The pictures you will take are amazing and you can immerse yourself in the culture. The incense and flowers are amazing, unlike anything we have seen before. The crowds can be a bit overwhelming and people are rather pushy as you try to appreciate the beauty; however, if you just take it all in stride you will not be disappointed by the Po Lin Monastery. Wish there was an official English tour that would give you some of the backstory but oh well.

Worth a visit. I visited Po Lin Monastery whilst on a business trip in Hong Kong. The place, although very crowded, is so peaceful with the locals and tourists having a great respect for the place. The site is immaculate!They also have a vegetarian restaurant there which I greatly recommend - the food is very fresh and the tea very much so refreshing under the heat of October.

Worth a visit. One of the best sites in Hong Kong.Easily accessible by Hong Kong's clean and efficient underground (MTR). Be amazed by the quality of the workmanship and obvious pride in presentation. You must also visit the recreation of the tang Dynasty Garden across the road.Not a leaf out of place and the carp pond is extraordinary.

Monastery near the big buddha. I previously commented on Lantau island and big buddha during our visit to Lantau island. Due to prayer in progress at the time of our visit, we didn't get to go inside the monastery. Only viewed it from the outside. Beautiful and grand as expected.

Soul Cleansing. For a soul cleansing treat, visit the monastery. It is clean, neat and peaceful. No matter what your religion, buy a handful of incense and offer them. Take lots of photos, except in areas where it is not allowed such as the prayer halls. If you are feeling strong, climb to the Buddha statue.
Monastery at site of Tian Tan Buddha. It was fairly nice but not something I would go out of my way to see. Luckily, it is on the way to the statue so was able to walk around for a few minutes.

Pretty Monastery & A Good Day Trip. We visited the Po Lin Monastery and Big Buddha as part of a day trip to Lantau from Hong Kong. The cable car ride to the Ngong Ping Village was fun and the weather being all cold with a misty sky, quite thrilling too. The Monastery is beautiful, with its dazzling 10,000 Buddha statue hall, and smaller temples with well carved statues and sculptures. The walk up to the Big Buddha in the cold weather was equally fun and the statue is also quite impressive, visible almost until half way through the cable car ride. It's definitely worth a visit.

A must see. I have been to HK a few times now and each time I make time to see the monastery. It has an amazing atmosphere and is a welcome break from the craziness elsewhere in HK. Make sure it is on your itinerary.

Great look inside a monastery. Although pictures aren't allowed inside Po-Lin, you can go inside and see what it looks like inside a Monastery. Really cool experience.
Plus outside the monastery, there are still traditional religious events from lighting incense sticks to prayer. If you go to see the Buddha you might as well see Po-Lin!

Lantau island not to be missed. I have just arrived back from a 5 day break to Hong Kong. We decided to take the cable car to Lantau island which took about 25 minutes to get to you will definitely need a head for heights if you choose this mode of transport to get there, it cost about £16 in English money but that also included lunch. At the top there is craft shops and places to purchase refreshments, but obviously the main attraction is the Buddha and temple the grounds are beautiful to walk through. To get close to the Buddha there are lots of steps so you need to be fit. An enjoyable visit and well worth the trip

Serene statue. We been here when we had a transit halt at Hong kong. It is definately worth a visit..You can easily spend half a day here. We took a bus from airport towards the cable car depot. Buy the cable car tickets from the airport as there is a long line at the actual cable car port. The cable car is a nice ride. You have a standard cabin and a crystal one. We took crystal cabin one way...it was good but not much difference. the views are spectacular. There are trails upto the statue as well but its a long one. You can climb upto the staute and spend some time around the vicinity...there are many toursit attractions as well.

more for tourists than for cult worship.. the gondola to get to the temple is really impressive.It passes before on the sea and then through the vegetation and it s not too much expensive.The place is full of stores and place to have a the or eat something.The big Buddha is awesome and really beautiful but hides a horrible secret,the is a shop in it.more for tourists than for cult worship.

Beautiful temple, good hiking, average grounds. First thing is getting there. There are really three choices. Taxi, Bus, or Cable Car. The bus is a set schedule and was not timely for me. The Cable car requires advanced reservations or a LONG wait if you want to use it as a round trip.I chose a taxi to get there, and then a one way cable car to get back. The taxi was 200 HKD (about $25 US) and the one way cable car was 165 HKD. I chose to arrive there before the 8:00am opening and had the place to myself to explore with out the crowds that come on the cable cars and buses.There are plenty of walks to talk from simple paths to hikes though the trees. The buddha statue is here as well but it opens at 10:00.This was the second Buddhist monastery that i have visited, the other was in Narita City, Japan. The ground around Po Lin did not measure up to the in Narita. Trash could be seen off the trails, sidewalk and paths were not well kept. The "tea houses" that I read about looked horrible.

Ignore the fake village. Tram ride was wonderful; signage at the subway station was in unusually clear English. At the end is a fake Chinese village built to appeal, I guess, to Chinese tourists. But at the end is the traditional monastery, and nearby the matchless "Big Buddha". A must-see for visitors to Hong Kong. And the tram makes it easy. (Lonely Planet gives a confusing description of how to get there; just make sure to take the subway to the tram's jumping off point, and it's easy.

If you missed this, You missed most things. Morning of Wednesday 12th November 2014, travel from Shatin Railways Station to Hung Hom Station, quite crowded even in HK standard, but only 15 minutes ride, there we met up with our best friends without going overground, and travel towards Tung Chung, caught bus/coach to Po Lin (every 20 minutes), arriving in 40 minutes. You cannot missed the Big Buddha, and the lane of 12 animal signs/figures, walked through the wisdom lane too. We went for the Buddhist vegetarian meal/banguet, costing 88 HKD each. What with Occupy Central demonstrations , its nice to be out and about. Relaxing and peace all around ...

Beautiful site. The monastery is a beautiful building and stands in the shadow of the Big Buddha. It is a busy place, but still seems quite peaceful. The interior of the temple buildings is extraordinary. Well worth a visit.

Surprisingly relaxing dispite the crowds. Visited the monastery and the Big Buddha, was fairly crowded but peaceful and relaxing surprisingly. The restaurant serves a vegetarian 'banquet' which for a confirmed carnivore was quite good.

Intricately Adorable. The view up there is amazing. The temple itself is made of elaborate, intricate designs fit for its religious significance. Entry is restricted but getting there as close as you get is simply magical ... so solemn a place ... adorable.

Beautiful architecture. The place is tranquil and the traditional architecture is amazing. I understand that the chamber with ten thousand Buddhas is open for a month and then close to public forever. It's a great experience. So be sure to visit if you are around this area this month and maybe the next?
PO LIN. Paradise on earth - not to be missed under any circumstances,the monastery is beautiful and should be seen in its amazing construction and shape

Must to Visit in HongKong. 20 Minutes travel from an aerial cable car, with beautiful 360 degree view of HongKong. Out of Pollution with clean air. 20 Minutes trekking upto Budha Top / Po Lin Monastery. Nice place to spend quality time & get Peace

Incredible architecture.. Intricate, beautiful, sacred. 10,000 Buddhas in one temple. A must see when at the big Buddha. Also loved the walk along the zodiac, with all the generals for each of the Chinese zodiac signs.
The whole area was clean and well maintained. Toilets clean.
We did not eat here, so no comment.

Interesting stop on a tour. Well preserved monastery and a popular stop for tourists visiting Lantau.
Nice to see the way of life of the monks and the surroundings they live in.
It was a a joy to behold the various paintings and sculptures that adorned the monastery.
Nice experience.

Nice excursion away from the city. Took the Ngong Ping 360 up the mountain. I personally thought the cable car was nothing special (it was mostly just forest below), and was a bit overpriced. Once at the top, walking through the village takes you to the base of the big Buddha. With all the stairs leading up the the Buddha, it was quite impressive. However, I enjoyed touring around the Po Lin Monastery area the most. The rich colours of the monastery buildings looked so stunning! Overall though, not sure I would come back again, but it was definitely good to experience it once.

Visit to the Po Lin Monastry by Cable Car. Took the N Nong Pink 360 Cable Car to the Monastery. Good views of the Big Buddha can be seen from the Cable Car. We then walked up the many steps to see the Big Buddha and had lunch in the cafe there. A must do whilst in Hong Kong.

The biggest monastery in Hong Kong. Po Lin Monastery is the monastery in Hong Kong. It has just opened the Grand Hall for Million Buddhas, which took 10 years to plan and build. Inside the monastery you felt the serenity. Outside was a garden where people can pray or take a stroll. Often the monastery held workshops that helped cleanse our souls. Only vegetarian food is served in the monastery. You can take the set in the restaurant or try the snacks.

Stunning...crown jewel of the Ngong Ping attractions. The Po Lin Monastery was stunning with the colors appearing to be newly painted with bright blue, gold, yellow and red. The gardens and flowers surrounding are also beautiful. if I knew how great it would be, I would have planned more time for both Po Lin and Grand Hill of Ten Thousand Buddhas. We were there at about 3pm in November and it wasn't too crowded which was nice. I highly recommend adding the Monastery to your itinerary!

Must See Attraction In Hong Kong!. Po Lin Monastery is one of the most beautiful things I have ever seen! It's surrounded by high mountains and the Tian Tan Buddha! Which looks like a long walk but it's worth it! The cable car to the Tian Tan Buddha and Po Lin Monastery is a beautiful trip over the ocean and mountains! Would recommend this to anyone!!

Po Lin Monastery. We visited here as part of our Lanatau tour. There were loads of gift shops to purchase souvenirs. There was only a small part of the monestary that you could access which was quite disappointing. You were able to take some pics.We had a lovely vegetarian lunch here which was great for me as I'm vegetarian. There was plenty of food.

not very interesting or authentic. I never write negative reviews, but Po Lin, to me, seemed like something you'd see at Disney World. I just felt fake to me, like it was built for tourists only, and paled in comparison to other temples I've seen. If you want to see a beautiful, authentic temple in Hong Kong, go to Mo Man Temple on HK Island instead.

Cultural and Natural Side of Hong Kong. I think that this is a must visit in Hong Kong. It's a great place to experience the cultural and natural side of the city. Mountain scenery is breahtaking and you can meet various buddhist figures of deities. Very interesting place to see, my foreign friends loved it.
Another Peace in the City. As expected, the temple is large, many people comes to worship and the garden is quiet and nice. As we are people who like to walk in temples, this is a good choice.

Amazing. Travelling by glass bottom cable car is an amazing experience. The view as you travel to the top is incredibly beautiful. Once a the top, you can wander the shops before taking the 204 steps up to the big Buddha. Well worth the time & effort

Incredible!!. The monastery is gorgeous, traditionally colourful and definitely worth seeing. Here you can also stop for a meal – there is a plenty of little cafes on the way to here from Ngong Ping cable car terminal too. And if you fancy a relaxing stroll after your lunch, head to the Wisdom of Path through the peaceful forest.
Interesting site. Accessed from Hong Kong via ferry and bus, or MTR and cable car. The large buddy and cable car are interesting. Village shopping area is very touristy.

Huge Statue picture perfect and active place for buddhist. 1st of all make sure you come here early in the morning, during opening hours to beat the line, or else you have to fall in line starting from the walk way going up the ticket booth (its long seriously).I think you can go sight seeing here for a whole day if you opt to see other attractions around Lantau island. If not maybe 2 to 3 hours is enough just to ride the cable car and see the big buddha statue.I recommend you at least take one crystal cabin going up or going down just so you can see the marvelous terrain of Lantau Island.For the monestary part, I counted the steps going up the big buddha, its a total of 250 steps. Once you arrive the top you will see the whole monastary and the surroung mountains.The monastery is actually working, you can see buddhist buying incense, paper money and make offerings. If its sunny, and you don't want to get dark, bring a umbrella or else you be scorched by the sun light.

Beautiful building...if fairly modern. We had a very peaceful lunch here. The decoration of the buildings inside are very ornate and in some areas you can take pictures. A good place to unwind after the climb to see the Buddha.

Great but relatively humble place. When visiting Big Buddha it is worth going there as well. This is a beautful place, and despite the crowds, relatively peaceful. Walking trowards it you can see people offering incens sticks of various sizes. Air is full of that scent. The Monastery itself is quite magnificent, with three beautiful Buddhas inside. We are non-budhists and it was our first monastery in HK, so everything was very new for us.Afterwards we went to the restaurant, and decided to eat outside and buy the food from some sort of bar (not the main 'luxury' place). The vegetarian food was suprisingly tasty and quite filling. We liked it very much.As the cable car was closed that week we took a bus there. There is a good connection by bus from there to a famous Tai O village. Also recommended.

Great experience. No trip to Hong Kong would be complete without a visit to the Big Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery. The easiest way to reach the area is by catching the Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car, which takes approx 25 minutes where you can enjoy the beautiful scenery along the way. If you have a fre extra $ take the crystal car for a unique view. Buy the entry ticket that gets you inside the top floors of the Buddha and also gives you lunch at Po Lin, the vegetation food is great. Also you can buy a hand carved prayer bracelet in the Buddha itself which is really a one off thing to do.

Small but pretty temple. Very cool temple and monastery right near the Buddha statue. Take the cable car up and explore the Buddha, temple, and don't miss the wisdom path. The statues inside a amazing, but be careful as the staff is not keen on taking photos of them. The complex is also fairly small, so don't expect a huge amount of time exploring it.

Great Place. Six hours stay in Hongkong is enough to enjoy the Big Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery. The easiest way to reach the Buddha is through the Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car, merely 25 minutes , where you can enjoy the beautiful scenery along the way.
Added Bonus when you see Big Buddha. We went to see the Big Buddha and also enjoyed visiting the Monastery adjacent to the Buddha. no cost to enter, worth taking a look see.

Must see. Cable car not required. Big Buddha statue, temple and complex. You can bus up there cheaply or take the cable car.Take the MTR, last station on orange line is 100m from bus station and cable car, which you then take to get up the hills (or you can hike 6km if up for it!)

Surprise Visit. This visit came as a bit of a surprise to us as we were not expecting to visit this place. What is even better is that my friend decided to treat us to the vegetarian lunch at the site restuarant. I will definitely recommend eating here. The atmosphere is just so serene and according to my friend you need to pay for your lunch using a coupon system as it is for a charitable cause. There was four of us and we were served a really delicious lunch. Best of all, the taste was really good with no msg detected. The servings was also very generous. The place is fairly small but very organised. It's air-conditioned too which provides us a welcome respite from the heat. Once we are done with our lunch,we adjourn to the Monastery. There was quite a bit of construction works that was ongoing, so we just wandered around where we are allowed too. It's a serene place to be at and the art-works are very educational too. If there is time, take a look at the various artefacts. What I find is that because the journey itself to the island can be very time-consuming, it means that at the end of the day, you will not have a lot of time to wander around at a leisurely pace. My advice is to make sure one plans way ahead to allow for time to see all the attractions here.
good for a visit. If you visit Lantau - do not miss this place. It has a fascinating story and lots of interesting corners to visit.
Views in all its glory. nestled in the mountains with views of the big buddha, so much raw history ... a must see is included in the day trip .. loved it
Nice. Visited last May. If you have seen everything and have a spare hour this is a nice place. Pleasant walk and nice views from the Buddha.

Surprising nice.. A surprisingly nice place . It was hot and humid the day I visited, it will be a more enjoyable experience if the weather is more cooling. Climb the stairs up to the giant Buddha statue to have a great view of the surrounding.

Very relaxing. Beautiful gardens, very relaxing and peaceful, great place to escape the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Opened 7 days a week, no entrance fee, small vegetarian cafe and tea house in the gardens. Tea house experience was great, took about 3 hours to sample all the teas we purchased, truly special experience.

Renovation. When i visit the monastery, it was on work for renovation. Almost all buildings were not a picture perfect because of the poles/barriers used for the renovation. Hope the renovation will not last that long so that tourist can take a picture of it perfectly. It is also nice to experience Chinese culture and its religion.

Tourist Trap - In a good way. I only had a short stay in Hong Kong, and was staying on Lantau, so this was an accessibly attraction for me. The cable car ride was relaxing, and would have been awesome on a clear day. There were an overwhelming number of people there, but the Big Buddha was really cool.The monastery itself was really cool too though - don't forget to stop by there. The shops are definitely set up for tourists, so be careful with prices, but overall a great experience.
Buddhist Culture. Good atmosphere here, many people pray with one of the biggest incense ive ever seen. You can go inside enter the monastery and pray, learn some buddhist culture here

touristified but still a must see. If you go to Hong Kong and have half a day, go here. Go early in the morning to beat the crowds. It's turning into a tourist trap but the cable car ride, the monastary, the park and the Buddha all make this worth while. If you have more time to spend, linger in the temples and study all the new and old artefacts. You can walk or go by car, but the cable car read is a real treat.

Big Buddha is the Highlight, but Monastery Is Nice On Its Own Too. As you probably already know, tourists usually come to this monastery to see the Big Buddha at the top of the hill, not just for the monastery itself. Still, that doesn't mean that it doesn't have anything to offer: it's similar to any Chinese Buddhist temple, but larger than most. The place is under constant upgrading, and as people donate large sums of money, becomes more ornate and interesting. If you go to the Big Buddha, definitely do not forget to go to the monastery and see it too.

This is a must see experience. Awe struck experience - very beautiful! It's a 4. - hour walk up the stairs, but I recommend 25 minute crystal cabin (glass bottom) cable car ride. Wonderful views of Big Buddha and skyline. Once on top you will see array of temples and statues. I recommend a tour to get most out of historical significance. I took Grayline Lantau 360 tour. This included VIP access to short line for cable car and VIP dining room vegetarian kitchen lunch at monastery.

The Big Buddha. I visited this place for a few times, and will keep come back, because inside the Big Buddha, there sit my parents memorial plates, which my sister arranged and reserved for my parents. But besides that, this is a wonderful place for all to visit. It is up in a mountain with many steps, requiring a strong and healthy body to climb up. But it is just a matter of time and patience, and it is definitely worthwhile to take the trip to go up. You can take a short break in the middle, while taking some pictures. In no time, you will be at the top, overlooking the views down, and the feeling is very peaceful and open. Again at the foot of the Buddha, there is a big open are where you can go around and take pictures of a few small guarding Buddhas in front. When you are ready, you can go inside the Buddha and join for the tour and learn about the history of the Buddha and for some people to do worshipping. You don't have to be religious to feel the peacefulness of this place. Just feel good to experience the culture of local people is an amazing experience!

Eat the vegetarian food on offer!. No trip to the Big Buddha should be without a visit to Po Lin Monastery as well as the great food they sell there - my favourite by far is the tofu dessert with the ginger infused sweet syrup.I always buy incense and pray outside the monastery (you cannot bring burning joss sticks in) - the Monastery has expanded over the years but still remains a sanctuary for your thoughts and time for contemplation. I've been to a number of temples around Asia but this remains one of my favourites - not least because it has by far the best food on offer. Don't go for the package deals or dine in the restaurant - just go to the counter and point at the different options - still cheap and delicious!

A must see for new-comers to Asia... not for seasoned Asian travellers.. A good 1/2 day out, nice to see. Avoid weekends or public holidays. If your friend/family/loved one hasn't been to Asia, this is a good place to take them. If your friend/family/loved one has seen 1 million buddhas already... don't bother. It's literally a big Buddha, built in the '80s.... Nonetheless beautiful and great views, but if your a seasoned traveller pressed for time.. head to an island.

Peace and Calm. Going through the NP village, you get into what they call the wisdom route. You hit a circle where on right side are the Steps to the Giant buddha and on the left is Po Lin. You can light the huge incense sticks for blessings. Step inside and you can see huge statues of Lord Buddha in gold. When I went there, there was some construction happening. The Monastery also has a Veg restaurant, coupons to which you can buy at the entrance. Its a per person meal, about HKD 88 if I remember correctly. There is a also a takeaway joint which offers dim sums and savouries (again vegan). Outside there us seating beneath huge trees which can save you from the searing sun. Plan an early visit to avoid the sun

Great enlightening day out.. Once thru the village and down the stairs of Big Buddha, turn right to the Po Lin Monastery. It is one of the largest Buddhist temples and the artwork, colorful statues, lights and cultural importance of Buddhism is a refreshing and serene experience. You almost want to walk softly and absorb everything in Buddha's house. There is a vegetarian restaurant and stands selling snacks and drinks. This visit is part of your trip up the Ngong Ping 360, the village and Big Buddha. A great enlightening day out.

Touch your inner self. Fantastic place and very informative. A lot of traditional drawings depicting the history of buddhism. Very peaceful once you are inside the temple. The view from the top is just amazing. Try to visit early and not during holiday/ weekend as this place can be crowded. We had lunch at the monastery (organised by our tour group), I must say it was delicious vegetarian meal. I feel at peace.

Amazing peace and tranquility if you can go early in the morning. A wonderful feeling of calm as well as a fabulous view awaits the traveller that visits Po Lin. I recommend going really early to experience it before the many tourists arrive.

Peacefull. The Po Lin Monastery is one of Hong Kong’s most important Buddhist sanctums which is home to many devout monks, this monastery is rich with colourful manifestations of Buddhist iconography. The monastery is next to the Big Buddha and the gardens have nice flowers and there is a vegetarian restaurant there.

Po Lin (Precious Lotus) Monastery, Hong Kong. This is a must visit if in Hong Kong... I'm very lucky to say that I have now been twice in my lifetime and it has very precious meaning to me... The Big Budda is outstanding and gives a true sense of peace. The monastery is beautiful and a truly humbling experience to visit. In all a real life experience not to be missed.

Monastery on Lantau island hill. Visited Po Lin Monastery along with the main attraction, Tian Tan Big Buddha, after a fantastic scenic cable car ride from Tung Chung terminal. The monastery had golden statues of the Buddha and was very clean and serene among colourful décor. The heavy odour of incense offered by the disciples & visitors filled the air outside the entrance gate of the monastery. The monastery provided a great setting and an ideal place to relax, set among scenic background of the hilly terrain & the Big Buddha.

Wonderful monastery with delicious food. Next to the Big Buddha, this wonderful monastery and restaurant is one of the best attractions on Lantau island. The monastery itself is where the Buddhists in Hong Kong pray (Hong Kong has a Christian community) and the vegetarian restaurant is absolutely delicious. Loved it here.

Next to the Big Buddha. Only a few minutes walk from the Big Buddha, with a lovely scent of insence everywhere. There are a few places to shop and buy snacks. Take your time and stroll about and enjoy the relaxing atmosphere.
Kill 2 birds with one stone!. A must-do if you are already visiting Big Buddha - the monastery is minutes away. Beautiful colors, and you can light incense to pay your respects before entering.
very beautiful scenery. really enjoy our visit here.. very beautiful big budha, beautiful landscape, we love the pathway too... really enjoy our visit here..

We chose the wrong day I suspect.. Nothing seemed to be happening at the Monastery during our visit and there certainly wasn't food available for purchase. There were many tourists wandering around aimlessly like us.

Po Lin Monastery. I loved the Big Buddha and the statue of the maidens, got some beautiful photos. The vegetarian meal was wonderful and so much food. I was a little sad that it was so Disneyland like for such a spiritual place. The cable ride was a little scary with the wind blowing but worth the wait. We didn't wait too long to get on even though it was during the Chinese New Year.

Beautiful,. Very much enjoyed visiting this monastery. We ate in their dining area... a simple but satisfying vegetarian meal. The temples were awe aspiring with bright colors and multiple Buddhas. Their was many pilgrims visiting the monastery it is a very active religious site, A great place to absorb the culture. I felt very good when we left.

Wonderful vegetarian food. I am a meat lover but I didn't miss the meat at all in this meal. Loved all of the different dishes we had and I am picky about Chinese food. Only thing it lacked was drink options (green tea only). It was also freezing inside.

Po Lin (Precious Lotus) Monastery During Chinese New Year. We were there during Chinese New Year, the line was quite long it took about an hour before we got in the cable car, it was a busy holiday so a wait was inevitable. I thought it was well worth the visit, I did some research before we got there and knew that the main hall of the monastery was being renovated but I did not let that stop me from going. When you stand at the bottom of the 268 steps leading up to the112 foot tall Tian Tan Buddha it was a magnificent site and we'll worth the climb, there was plenty of opportunities to take pictures on the way up, and some people did sit on the steps to have a rest on there journey to the top.

What a wait!!!! Queues Queues Queues. Probably our biggest mistake was trying to visit any tourist attraction in Hong Kong over the Chinese NYE holidays. We waited in the biggest queue of our lives (over 4 hours) to get to the ticket booth of the Gondola to then be advised of another 1.5 hour wait. At that stage we decided to sell our tickets and go to the nearby outlet mall (don't expect outlet prices but good food court anyway)......What a waste of a day!On our returning transit we had a 8 hour stopover in Hong Kong. I reluctantly convinced my parter to tackle the Gondola to the big buddha again. We arrived at 4pm ish and had only a small queues to get to the top which closed at 6pm. Nice trip up the hill. Great views through the smog.....we arrived at the top station to a epic queue of returning punters....we walked around for 20 min and then stood in a queue for 2 hours to get back down again. It was Valentines day too. Wow how disappointing! I can't say I would recommend this attraction unless u have a private car. Would be quicker to fly to Koh Samui to see the Golden Buddha (Wat Phra Yai) and It's way more spectacular.

Quiet and nice, after the crowds at the Buddha. While you are visiting the Big Buddha take a short walk over to see the monastery. It was being worked on when we were there but it was interesting to see the believers practicing their faith.

See while you're there for the big Buddha. Under construction, it's not impressive and don't buy the overpriced lunch, but nonetheless, it's worth a walk through while you tour the big Buddha and Lantau. Bring dog and cat treats if you like animals.

Experience local culture. For us this was a great way to experience local culture on a short visit. We arrived early in the day to see many customs being practiced before making the trip up the stairs to visit Big Buddha.

Peaceful and picturesque. Taking advantage of being up in the Bid Buddha area, you just need to walk few hundres meters more to see this beautifully decorated monastery. While the Big Buddha or the cable car are always crowded by tourists, the monastery remains more silence and peaceful. Extensively decorated with colourful flowers it is a perfect complement to the visit of the Big Buddha. You can see the complex from the base of the Buddha. When we were there (February 2013) there were some major renovations/constructions being carried out on the largest building. It is not unlikely to come across some monks during your visit. The complete Buddha, Po Lin, village and cable car are one of the unforgettable visits of Hong Kong.

Peaceful Monastery Despite Touristic Location. Despite being located right near the Big Buddha and tourist village, which are very crowded, the monastery is very peaceful and spiritual. Wondeful atmosphere and beauty of the place will not leave you indifferent. Just beware that reconstruction is in progress, that is why some buildings are unavailable.
A great day out. So peaceful and nice to see the shoalin monks and where they pray and train. Fantastic day out built in with the giant Buddha next door, very picturesque .
Try the vegetarian food. Look out for a vegetarian restaurant nearby. Go for the set meal, not the snacks. The meal vouchers allow u to visit a sacred relic at the big Buddha too. Check it out.

Very spiritual place. After a 40min bus ride ($55 return) due to the cable cars having a 1.5 hr waiting period.we were pleasantly amazed at how many people had come not as tourists but to worship. The outside of the monastry is under renovation so only took photos within and from the Buddha. It would be nice if the monstery had some explanation in english on the history , my friend and I wanted to know the significance of the different Buddhas.

A place of calm out of the bustle of the city. On a one-day layover in Hong Kong I went to visit this temple and the astonishing giant Buddha. Took the train to the end of the line then a 30-minute cable car ride with a view of the sea and the hundreds of islands and rock outcrops, as the seated Buddha slowly comes into view. Well worth the trip.

Very Peaceful. Would get to the cable cars early as we got there at 10.20 am and still had a wait of an hour to get into a car.Once in cable car the views are amazing starting with the airport which is below you.Then you get the first sight of the Buddha.When you arrive there are the normal tourist shops which are ok ish,but main reason to go is the walk up the steps to the Buddha,very peaceful.Well worth the trip away from the busy streets of Hong Kong.

Beautiful Ride Up, Beautiful Setting at Top, Great Meal. The ride up in the gondola cable cars is spectacular, worth the hour wait in line. The setting at the top is beautiful and we ate lunch at the monastery restaurant per a reservation (recommended). Many very excellent vegetarian dishes, much of which is grown there. Signs on the picnic tables outside all say "No Smoking, No Meat", so leave your McD behind.

Couple this with the Ngong Ping 360to save time. This is a huge imposing mark on the Hong Kong landscape. We first laid our eyes on it from the cable car and the statue is so peaceful and imposing. Entry is free..

Even with crowds still a peaceful place to visit. I have been to Po Lin a few times and find the visits to be very peaceful and tranquil. The Giant Buddha is an increditble piece of architecture and the galleries beneath it are well worth a visit. The monastery is a lovely place to have a quiet stroll around and the vegenterain lunch on offer is excellent and very filling.

I'm sure it's lovely buts it's covered in scaffolding and under construction. We were not able to go inside as it's under construction and the outside is covered in scaffolding and tar poling. When it's complete I'm. Certain it will be awesome. Shame really

The place is being renovated for a while. I never went there as the place is being renovated but I am told by reliable sources that it is indeed beautiful so keep that in mind when you go to the Ngong Ping Village as there isn't much walking to do to get there.

Do not miss this on your trip to Hong Kong. I have read some of the other reviews and we must have gone at the right time. It was a weekday and there were no crowds and now waiting. It was a perfect experience touching all of the senses. We took the fabulously clean public transportation, then the tram ride, which for some reason I didn't expect. During the ride over we passed over thick forests with just quick peeks at the trail that some brave people were trekking up the mountain. We also watched what appeared to be whole families that appeared to be digging something out of the sand in the shallows. Then came the climb to the monastery and the Buddha. Everything was mesmerizing, the elaborate stone carvings, the lush flowers, the sudden and quickly over downpour that engulfed us. We bought a gorgeous umbrella and serious rain parka and started our climb up to the Buddha. What a magnificent bronze! And surrounded by the bronzes of the maids offerings. As with most things in china you are struck first by the beauty then the wonder of how did they do that! They are a resourceful and industrious people. The view from the top was also worth the climb. Then we had lunch at the monastery. How simple, delicious and I cannot describe the feeling of peacefulness that came over us. I think I could have stayed there for the rest of the day, at least. Do yourself a big favor and do not miss this!

Very nice and unusual place to visit.. I was here with a friend who lived in Hongkong, she took me to Lantau and Stanley om the same day, it was nice contrasts showing some nice spots in Hongkong. The monastary is quite extraordinary, definately something to visit when going to Hongkong.

Impressive but crowded and not well accessible. Visited it directly after arrival to Chek Lap Kok. It was saturday morning. First of all i have to wait approximately one and half hour in queue for cable car. To visit small museum located inside Buddha statue, you have to pay for breakfast in monastery. Both, i mean museum and breakfast, are not worth time and money. Queue for trip back took 30-45 mins.It is still picturesque and interesting, but consider to use bus for one way, either there or back.

I took a tour to this monastry.. I loved the extremely neat atmosphere and the friendly people. It was so calm and ordered. The visitors were all relaxed and laughed alot. The interior was rich and very oppulent. I even met a couple from my old home town in South Africa. It was amazing talking about cricket in a monastry and so far from my home. I loved the food and drinks.

A beautiful place.. Although the public areas are very touristy, I love this Monastery and have been supporting it for a number of years now.It is well worth a visit and there are several absolutely stunning things to take photos of.My only complaint is that, probably due to language barriers and the huge volume of tourists that come through the area, it can be difficult for someone who is either a Buddhist or is genuinely interested in the religion to get information. I would suggest, however, that contacting the Guest Hall (if that's the right name) in advance would eliminate most of this difficulty.

A fantastic start to our HK trip. Personally, this was one of the highlights of my trip to Hong Kong: and it began with the journey there. The cable car ride that we took was excellent, surrounded by lush scenery around quite a distance. The area surrounding the monastery itself is beautiful, with many interesting sites, with possibly my only complaint being that it is a typical tourist trap so don expect it to be unspoilt...

Average. When i visited in July 2013 the whole structure was under renovation so didn't get to see any exterior architect. The inside was also very plain. What did stand out was the locals burning different sizes(some as tall a 6 feet) of incense sticks outside the monastery. The burning of the incense did give a spiritual feeling.Also the place has vegetation restaurant and canteen. The monastery made food was average tasting but enjoyed the experience.

The premier Buddhist temple in HK. This is probably this is probably the most famous temple in HK. Access is good with cable cars and buses making regular stops. It's worth a visit, but avoid weekends and public holidays. The giant Buddha is a famous landmark and is a must see. The On Ping Village is a tourist rip off, avoid.

Greets you before you land. It is one of the things that greets you before your plane lands at the airport. There is two museums inside the Buddha: a free one and paid access. Tickets into the paid access side is included if you purchase the vegetarian meal. However, the vegetarian meal is a tourist trap. If you like tofu pudding, there are a couple of real good shops that make it with mountain spring water.

Must-see monument. A lot of construction/renovation work going on in the Po Lin monastery itself – The big Buddha is next door and he is the main event! An impressive landmark and a beautiful location. There is a fee for walking up the steps to the Buddha but otherwise it is free.
Truly worth the visit. Fabulous visit to a fabulous site. So incredible it takes your breath away. We loved Hong Kong; this was a highlight of the trip. Not to be missed.

Picturesque Peak and Breathtaking View. The 25 minute cable car going to Lantau Island, HK was truly an amazing spectacle. You may opt to go there via bus as well. But if you want to experience an altitude of adventure with the impressive city structures and edifice of Hong Kong as backdrop then choose to ride their crystal cabin cable car. It is a bit pricey but the feel of being on top because you get to see the sea through a glass floor and scenic mountains by the window is an awesome phenomenon. So if you are in Hong Kong, never miss going to Po Lin Monastery for the world!

Amazing!!!. Wonderful.. Just can't wait to get there again.. Have a little bit adventures with my friends when we get some little vacation during summer a view last years.. After visiting BIG BUDHA then we go to NgongPing village, do some shopping there and taking more pictures..

Worth the visit. Book your tickets for the cable car beforehand online. This saves you from having to stand in the long queues. The view is amazing from the cable car and you are able to see the airport from a different viewpoint.It is an experience walking up to the monastery.Be sure to take a photo of your Chinese sign before you leave.You can also take a bus down to the fishing village. It is very dirty but you will be able to see the pink dolphins!
Great place to spend a day.. The Monastery, the Big Buddha, the other statutes in the Monastery, the veggie restaurant and finally the awesome 5+ km cable car ride was enjoyable.

Beautiful place, makes a great day trip from Hong Kong.. Definitely worth making the trip out to Lantau island for. Make sure you take the cable car from Tung Chung for some fantastic views. Take good shoes because theres a lot of steps up to the Buddha but if you buy the ticket for the exhibition at the Buddha then you get a free snack at the snack bar in the monastery. Its an incredibly peaceful place the makes a great escape from Hong Kong and if you want to make a day of it then visit some of the other places on the island like the walk of enlightenment and the Tai O fishing village, make use of the great bus service around the island which takes the Octopus card (the hong kong version of the oyster card in london)

Under construction... C1 ( 2013.06.18 ) If there was not under construction, maybe there was very good attraction. The statue at the entrance was impressive, but main building was under construction. so I was disappointed. Around there, Big Buddha and gate was very beautiful.

a special place to visit. The Po Lin Monastery has the worlds largest outdoor Buddha. You capture your first glimpse of the Buddha on the cable car ride in and its breathtaking. The place is quaint and peaceful. There are over 230 steps to tackle to the top of the Buddha. Make sure you get a photo from the bottom of the stairs looking up. Inside there is a souvenir shop (which surprised me was rather cheap). Lunch was several courses of chinese vegetarian dishes, which wasn't too bad. If you have only a few days to stay in Hong Kong this place should be on your to do list !
a must see. I did not know what to expect and on reading reviews my expectations were very high and it lived up to my expectations and more!

Birds eye view of Hong Kong Chep Lap Kok International Airport and Lantau Island where sky land and see meets !. Do you know how an airport looks from a cable car ? How many times have you landed on Hong Kong's Chep Lap Kok international airport and have no idea as to how massive this land-filled airport looks like from one vantage point ? The entire airport operation unveils in front of you as you go higher and higher on the Ngong Ping 360 cable car ride. Try and book the "crystal car" with glass bottom floors to get that feel of being suspended in air. Enoy looking down from your glass bottom floors of the cable car onto greeneries along the mountain side, a nice walking trail (for those who want to attempt this, it takes about 5 hours one way), look down onto pristine waters and scattered fishing villages along the shores of the island. During low tide, many of the villagers are seen on the shores catching cockle shells to sell in the fish market. There are 2-3 things you can do once you get off from the cable car station. Climbing up 200+ steps to meet the Bid Buddha. It is worth making that big effort of climbing up to enjoy a 360 degree view of the mountains in the area. Visiting the famous Po Lin Monastery which has been discovered by the Buddhist monks a few hundred year ago in Lantau Island used a a centre for meditation. Look for the Vegetarian restaurant and make reservations to enjoy a vegetarian meal next to the Po Lin Temple. Before leaving this peaceful retreat, stop by some of the shops to familiarize yourself with Buddhist relics, Buddhist chants and enjoy a leisurely cup of tea or coffee with a gasp of fresh air in between that one cannot get when back in the hustle bustle life of Hong Kong's downtown shopping district.It is also a good break for the kids to see something different in Hong Kong aside from shopping malls.It is definitely a nice respite when you are broke and exhausted from shopping !As a reminder. check first if the fog is going to block of view of the Big Buddha. If it is foggy up in the mountains, do not go.

High Five. The Po Lin Monastery and Tintau Buddha are a must visit while in Hong Kong. The monastery is peaceful and beautiful and the Big Buddha on top of the hill is a great spectacle. Don't forget to make sure you get into the correct position to get a picture high fiving the Buddha!

A Humble Place. A Humble PlaceOn our visit to Lantau Island, Hong Kong we visited Po Lin Monastery and the Big Buddha, very impressed with the over all features of the exhibition, allow plenty of time to view the spectacular statues, plan to have a meal locally and then catch the Ngong Ping Skyrail for spectacular views. Don’t miss this attraction if you’re in the area.

An interesting monastery a very nice and calm place, worth the visit.. A great Monastery located near Ngong Ping within walking distance from the famous Big Buddha statue on Lantau Island. This monastery is great I love the outdoor area full of flowers and well maintained but inside is to take your breath away I was ravished by the beauty of this shrine, by the smell of incense and the superb statues depicting various Buddhist deities. A nice place for tranquility transmitted by it to the beauty of artistic works kept inside.
A great photo opportunity.... Just a short walk from the Tian Tin Buddha and Wisdom Path you'll find this lovely monastery. A great photo opportunity if you're already in the area.

Average time!. Precious Lotus, as is literally translated - is a peaceful and calm visit, as long as it is not inside the market place. A clean and well maintained monastery, however, not as big as many others in the Far East or Tibetan regions. Big Buddha - as is commonly known across Hong Kong is a huge attraction, however, lacks great excitement or enthusiasm. A reasonable cost if you take a bus ride from Tung chung - a slightly expensive one if you take the rope way - however the rope ways lends a lovely sight over looking the airport, sea and lush green mountains around. Take a trip, only if you have nothing else to do.

Unique and fascinating place.. We took the ferry from Central pier #6 to Mui Wo on Lantau Island and then the #2 bus directly to Ngong Ping - it cost less and gave us a nice change of pace versus taking the MTR and then cable car. The monastery and giant buddha are massive and with the mountain backdrop there are some breathtaking views to be had. The village is very touristy but also very aesthetically pleasing in my opinion. There was a live show going on in the square and lots of good lunch options. We took the cable car on the way back and HIGHLY recommend getting the diamond class ticket. The lineup was 1/100th of the length of the lineup for a standard ticket, and the glass bottom on the cable car made it more enjoyable.

Awesome Attraction. The big budda was what we went to see and that was as awesome as they come. Well worth the visit, and what ever you do pay the 30hk $ and go inside the budda its a must do. You get a snack and drink from the cafeteria included in the price. We took the MTR from Kowloon to Tung Chung then the cable car to the top. It is alot cheaper if you do it that way rather than go on a tour. The village that they have built at the top is just a big tourist rip off. I last visited Po Lin in the late eighties when I lived in Hong Kong and before the big budda was there. Alot has changed and although the monastery is worth the trip I just hated what they have done to the place tourist wise. It was a big disappointment. When we went there were no queues and we went straight onto the cable car but I shudder to think what it would be like in the high season!

Great Buddah, BEST mountain trail/walkway in HongKong Area!. Took the cableway up to the Po Lin Monastery to see the Big Buddah and the rest of the temple area. The Buddah in itself was very impressing, but almost found it greater from a little distance. The view from the area was very nice, even though I visited on a cloudy day. DO NOT miss out on the "not much spoken about" Lantau trail back to Tung Chen. This was the best thing in the whole day. About 7k walk, took me two hours including plenty of stops for photographing the hidden away monasterys on the way down the montainside in the valley. Much more worth seeing than the Po Lin manastery, much more real. The walkway was nicely prepared and not hard to walk down, where it was steep there was always built in stairsteps. Went through rainforest, mountainside and valley, with beautiful views, smells and a sense of total calm. Hearing the monks singing when walking through the rainforest was absolutely amazing! In total I met three budist monks and one brave person walking UP the montain, in my whole two hours of walking. To get to the Lantau trail (signs to Tung Chen and another village before), just follow the way to the Tee Garden/Hostel/Wisdom Path.

a bit commercialized. went inside the monastery after seeing the big buddha. it was quite small although peaceful/quiet too. what i didn't like though was there were a lot of vendors outside selling souvenirs and trinkets of the giant buddha. it has become a bit commercialized for my liking...

The most amazing place ive ever been !. A few years ago i was lucky enough to visit the po-lin monestry and the buddha statue on lantau and to say it was spiritualy enlightening would be an understatement .We where also lucky enough to have a martial arts demo from the shoelin monks that live there which was a highlight of my last trip to hong kong .Inside the monestry we did the burning of the prayer packs we had bought outside,then into the inner sanctum where they have the gold statues and all the flowers which was so peacefull even with thousands of people/pilgrims making there way through the temple ! Then the prayer sticks that one of the monks shook out of a wooden container which was great as what he told me , a few months later did actualy come true, which to this day makes me smile !The only thing i didnt like about he day was the tofu that everybody semt to want to eat ,although after 2 mouthfulls i had eaten enough ! When we where there last the only way up to the monestry was by road and bus as the ablecar had yet to be finished when i was last there but would say its the best most scenic option to visit the monestr on the beautifull island of lantau .The sacred gate was also amazing and the walk up to the buddha and seeing the 6 stutues with here offerings was truely amazing ,then into the buddha passing the bell up the staircase to where the crystal lays within the shrine itself ,all i can say is the love and inner peace i felt was something i had never felt before nor since that day leaving and can say it was a truly inspirational place and not a place to be missed whilst visiting lantau and hong kong .

Monastery or Commercial Complex?. The Po Lin Monastery is much too commercialized. Every where you go, you can see business opportunites. Too many vendors around the monastery & even inside the complex, one encounters people offering souvenirs said to have been blessed by the monks.

Don't miss Lantau Peak!. I visited Po Lin Monastery and the Big Buddha expecting tacky. But was pleasantly surprised! (Having said that, the glass bottom cable car was over-rated and a rip off - complete tourist trap)The Buddha is beautiful, majestic. And buying a ticket to the monastery lunch gives you access to the internal museum. Some beautiful artwork. Although lots of people, they are worshipping and respectful. I had lunch at the monastery - simple vegetarian lunch. Surrounded by locals doing the same. The standout - sweets from the bakery/cafe. Yum!!But the highlight - and possibly the highlight of my trip! - was the very steep walk up to Lantau Peak. The path starts from the wisdom path just near the Buddha and climbs to the 900m+ peak. The MOST amazing views. It took almost 2 hours to get up and 1/2 hour to get down. But it was so worth it. I then caught the bus to Tai O and spent a bit of time wondering and sitting at a very hip cafe. Caught the bus back to the MTR stop - forget the cable car!

Great experience. I was fortunate that I worked in HK and stayed with a local so I learned more about the culture and local habits than any of my other travels. That being the case, I found that it was good to share with other visitors some of the habits. I think eating at the monastery was a good example. First off- when you go up to the person to get your number, make sure they really see you because you likely won't understand them when they call for you.
