Keep an eye on the people who arrived before you so you can figure out when you're getting close. Its ok to hover- I stood close enough to read the page of names/numbers so I knew for sure when it was my turn. Keep your number out so the hostess can see it too. When you get inside to eat, just look around and do what the locals do. You're not fooling anyone- they know you're a tourist.

serenity. MTR exit at Tung Chung upon exit when you see the mall across, turn left then walk a few minutes going to the Lantau Cable car. Enjoy the view while you're on your way to Lantau Island.what i like about the monastery is you get to observe the life of the monks here, at the prayer room and also their food. They don't eat and serve meat to visitors so you will also appreciate that the food are still tasty even without meat. Their pastries are also yummy! You can pray at the prayer room and look around the area.

Liked the big Buddha but too many people. I can't imagine how this place is during high season but I went during supposed low season and the place was packed despite the fact that it was foggy and rainy. Too many mainland Chinese pushing, shoving and spitting everywhere. You arrive by bus or cable car (though I've been told you can hike up there too). When you arrive by cable car you arrive at this "Disneyland-ish village" that has a bunch of stores and restaurants. We didn't stop for any of this but moved on to the Buddha. Walking up to see the Buddha is free (about 100 steps, I didn't see any elevator) but if you want to see the museum about the Buddha and the temple you have to pay. You can walk all around the Buddha and get some great views of the mountains. After seeing the Buddha we headed to the temple. There were several buildings that had some nice alters and statues but again more pushing, shoving and spitting. There are semi clean bathrooms and a vegetarian restaurant (didn't eat here). Whole visit took about an hour.

on a good day, very nice views. i like the po lin monastery. i live on tung chung. but i go to po lin here and there. its very pretty. avoid all the touristy crap at the beginning and walk into the monastery. take your time there.

A monastry very close to the "big Buddha". Prior there where a very small typical monastry, then they developed a cable car to visit the buddha (Ngong Ping 360) and it had been very successful for tourists especially chinese people even if there is still people who come to meditate. They decided to create a new village with many restaurants, then a new monastry 3 times bigger than po-lin monastry is almost finished. It is nice to visit the buddha, the monastry does not present a huge interest from my point of view, too much touristic and less and less authentic

Definitely Worth The Trip. Outside of the city, this excursion is definitely worth the trip to see something pretty outstanding, including one of the world's largest buddhas and an operating monastery. Just get there early to avoid the long lines for the sky tram up to the top!

Tian Tan Buddha & Po Lin Monastery. A trip out to Lantua and the Po Lin was interesting and enjoyable. Just avoid weekends and public holidays as the wait is very long just to get on the cable cars. Amazing views on the cable car and at the top. While we focused on visiting the Buddha and temple, there are other activities like eating with the monks.The monastery itself was interesting and the giant Bhudda, well it was impressive I must say. We really enjoyed it but I wouldn't say it was unmissable!

The Buddaha Nature Revealed. On saturday, December 15 , 2012 we traveled with our fellow colleagues and friends to see the famous "sitting Buddha" of Lantau island. We stood in line for an hour to take the cable car attraction to the mountain and we had to wait an hour to return. The wait was worth it, as Hong Kong People are charming and patient. When we arrived and walked off the cable car attraction, it reminded me of the same tourist trap kitsch like that of Gatlinburg, Tennessee. I really don't understand why us humans ruin some of the most beautiful and high quality natural places with shopping villages that have a mocked Bavarian style theme. It is so awful. Anyway, we all sat down to a late lunch together. We ate at the restaurant where food is served on the second floor. The food was awful and my wife was so disappointed that she was threatening never to eat another Chinese style meal again. That is not a good when we still had three more days to stay in China. Her intuitional radar was right on though, as two of our party of seven were sick with food poisoning the very next day. This was not an auspicious start for the day.As we wandered through the village towards the shrine, there was a subtle yet discernible change. The shops steadily improved in quality. Be sure to check out the chopsticks shop, it is very nice and high quality. We are very pleased with the gifts we bought there. Then it changed again, as we walked onto the plaza towards the big white arches we encountered many medium sized dogs. They were unlike any others we have seen in HK. These dogs radiated a unique sense of place and and ignored all of the human going-ons around them. There were dogs asleep on benches, there was a dog curled up in the middle of the plaza, who didn't move for anyone. Small children were having their pictures taken with these animals. To me, it was very unusual to see these animals acting so out of character. The trek to the Buddha came next, all two hundred steps. We climbed took pictures and I went into the museum inside. There are beautiful portraits they recount the history of Buddha and then there is the artifact on display. As a Christian from the United States it profoundly affected me, at both an intellectual and spiritual level. I am still trying to process. It gave me a much deeper appreciation of this place and its people and most of all it's history. The temple is beautiful and deeply spiritual too. The incense burning, the birds, the mountains, it is all so magical. Our party were deeply moved by this excursion. This is an experience of a lifetime.

Pity it was under renovation when we visited. We visited the Po Lin Monastery and Big Buddha by the Ngong Ping Cable Car. At the time we visited, the Monastery was under renovation so you couldn't appreciate the beauty of the building. But we did happen across prayer time when the monks were praying and chanting. The monastery gardens were beautiful and if you have time, I recommend doing the short wisdom walk which is around the back of the monastery. You get a taste of the beauty of the Hong Kong highlands. As it was such a windy day, the cable car was very bumpy and for those with a weak stomach, you may feel a little queezy.

Biggest Budda in the world. Very interesting and absolutely brilliant! One of the must see attractions in the Hong Kong area.The climb up to see the Budda was moderate in difficulty and had plenty of room to rest on the way up and down. There is a restaurant up top, several gift shops and restrooms. You will not want to miss this while touring Hong Kong area!

Amazing experience!. The big Buddha, the world's largest Buddha statue, is just huge and amazing and so is the view from the top, beside the Buddha. Have a close look at the beautiful temple as well. Spend a day out there to have a city break and enjoy the parc, the nature, the atmosphere and the view.

A must see place. This is a must see place if you are interested in Chinese culture or believe in Buddhism. I recommend you go there early in the morning because the line to the Ugong Ping 360 cable car is always super busy. They open at 10 am. We got there at 12:30pm there was a super long line all the way from the cable car station to the subway... It took us 2 hour and 40 mins to get on the cable car eventually. And it only took 25 minutes to get to Po Lin MonasteryI don't think there is a need to take that crystal cable car because the view on the way is just ok and its not like very high. There are a lot of local style stores under the Buddha including restaurants and merchandise. The view from under the giant Buddha is great. It's kinda weird that I didn't see any monk around.We took the shuttle bus back to Tung Chong subway station. They have the bus service every 20 minutes and it takes you about 40 mins each way. The bus ticket cheap comparing to the cable car, only 17 HKD. You can use octopus card as well.I highly recommend you go there in the morning to avoid the long line and spend half day there enjoying the local culture.
Tranquil, stunning scenery. Superb place to visit if you like cultural trips, peaceful, beautiful scenery, weather was sunny and warm, it is a lovely part of the world and well worth a visit
Must visit. Take a cable car from Tung Chung subway station for enjoying the great views. The hills around the monastery are the great place for hiking. You'll need a goog shoes and photocamera.

Short walk from the Big Buddha.. Enjoyed going to the Monastery, just a short walk from the Big Buddha. It is beautifully built. Unfortuately there is a construction site going on behind it. It distracted from the serene atmosphere that I was looking forward to.I enjoyed watching the Monk ring the bells at lunchtime. Each dong is done in a precise and deliberate manner. Interesting to watch.

A must see attraction. The trip to and from Po Lin Monastery and the Giant Buddha is half the fun. Catch the Mui Wo ferry from Central Pier 6 then the # 2 bus to the monastery. There are the usual market stalls around the monastery and the monastery itself is quite lovely. Beautiful trees and plants abound and the mandatory dogs that seem to be around all wats. The vegetarian meal thatyou can buy at the monastery restaurant is good value. Catch the cable car back to Tung Chung station, make sure you catch the crystal cable car, it has a glass floor- amazing! Then it's just a short walk to the raliway staion. A great day out. Don't forget to buy an OCTOPUS CARD to make travel in Hong Kong easy.

Interesting Place to Spend a Day. Took the MTR to the buses to Lantau Island. The bus takes about 45 mins. to get you to the Buddha. I get car sick sometimes on windy roads, and I was definitely feeling a bit queasy when we arrived. There is an air-tram that goes there and if I ever go back, I'll take that instead. The Buddha was built in 1997, so you aren't seeing anything ancient. But the park is nicely laid out and if you can get yourself up all the steps to the Buddha, there is a magnificent view at the top. The Buddha will also reward you for climbing all those steps as you get a ticket (before you go up) for bottled water and an ice cream after you've gone inside the little museum.The Po Lin Monastery is there. It's not as fabulous as the Buddist temples I saw in Japan, but it's interesting. There are many new buildings going up, so over time, there will be more to see.The ride up by bus, (despite my feeling queasy) was great. It takes you through isolated neighborhoods surrounded by trees and you get occasional terrific views of the water.

A must experience for everyone.... This monastery is next to the big Buddha...need a full day to really experience the place. I normally take the ferry+bus route option..scenic trip. For the cable car one needs to book in advance and its pricey. I chose to review the monastery not the Buddha as for me the monastery just cannot be missed. The feel of the place though seems more commercial at first due to large crowds but soon the energy of the place envelopes you with all its beautiful shrines and temples. Being next to the big Buddha is an advantage as it increases its grandeur. The vegetarian food is very delicious and fresh and not expensive. The touristy shops outside provide the best Buddhist trinkets.

Great location. Some major redevelopment going on there at the moment (Oct 2012), which is juxtapose with the serenity of the place.Some nice statues though, and an opportunity to donate towards the renovation and upkeep, if you're that way inclined.Good view of the Big Buddha, and if it wasn't for the building works would be a wonderful place to chill out away from the crowds!

Worth seeing as part of the excellent Ngong Ping 360 attraction.. To get to Po Lin Monastery, you need to buy cable car tix at the Ngong Ping 360 terminus at Tung Chung. The tix are excellent value as, not only are you treated to a spectacular 25 min cable car ride across Tung Chung Bay and Lantau Island parkland, you have free access to Ngong Ping Village (touristy but charming), the huge and impressive bronze Buddha statue and the very colourful Po Lin Monastery. It is a full daytrip if you have the time, and as the Po Lin Monastery is right next door to the Big Buddha, you must take a look. The outdoor area by the monastery has lots of pretty shade trees and seating, lovely if you don't mind the scent of incense burning. And there is LOTS of incense being burned as offerings to Buddha! (Probably best to avoid if you have breathing issues!) The main temple buildings are very colourful and make for fabulous photos. There is a vegetarian restaurant where you can dine in, however my friend and I bought veg food from a takeaway place next to the restaurant. I truly can't recommend it - I bought a dish of 3 type of tofu (spicy, sweet & sour, another I can't remember) and it was AWFUL! I love vegetarian meals and tofu, but this was horrible, both tastewise and visually. If I visited Ngong Ping again, I would have lunch at the Ngong Ping Village.

Big Buddha. Went to Hong Kong last year to visit our daughter and family.She took us to see the big Buddha,it should be one of the wonders of the world ! You have to do a lot of walking but it's well worth the trip if you are ever in Hong Kong!

Climbing up to the Buddha's Belly. This is the first time I visited the Po Lin Buddha's Belly since I left Hong Kong when I was little. There were fond memories of spending the summer there with my aunt who tried to convert me to a Buddhist, unfortunately she was not very successful. Visiting this place is more more easy now by comparasion to before. The MTR can take you to Tung Chung where one can choose to take the cable car or the bus to go up to the monastery. Once you arrived, you can climb up the stairs to the Big Bhddha, There is no charge to see the Bhddha, but if you want to see one of the exhibition on the first floor, you have to buy a ticket for HK$28, that include the entrance fee and a vegetarian dim sum treat afterwards. Or if you choose to try their vegetarian meal for $78. It opens from 11 am to 3 pm for food in the Restaurant there. Once you climb up to the Buddha, you have a good view of the Lantau Island. There are many exotic statues if you are into photography. On the ground there, there are a few temple one can visit, but there are also a lots of construction going on at the moment. I found the colourful surrounding make it a real good opportunities to take photos especially if you do not live in Asia, this make very good holiday photos.
Nice. Was a nice visit, although the cable car journey there was definitely the high point (make sure you pay extra for the crystal cabin), the monastery was interesting but a bit touristy

Big Buddha. This was probably the highlight of my trip to Hong Kong. I always pictured Hong Kong as a giant concrete jungle with barely any wilderness - going to Po Lin Monastery changed my perception. We took the gondola ride up to monastery which i highly recommend doing. It offers a spectacular view of the area below; in short time you'll go from looking at skyscrapers to looking at mountains, forests and beaches. As you get closer the Tian Tan Buddha will appear in the distance, also known as "Big Buddha" it is a giant statue at the top of the hill and is the main attraction in the area.Once we arrived we made our way to the statue. You really can't appreciate it's size until you're standing below it looking up! You can spend quite a bit of time climbing the stairs and checking out the smaller statues that surround it. After, we walked over to the monastery to pay our respects and admire the beautiful artwork found inside. Later on we found a little spot where the nuns were serving soup so we sat down for a nice vegetarian lunch, i'm not sure what all the ingredients were (there was no menu) but it was good.I suggest preparing for a half-day excursion. Between the gondola ride, spending time at the statue/monastery and eating lunch you'll need a good 4 hours. It's worth it!

one big buddha. Even though a web site said that it closes at 6, it is actually at 5:30, and its a good time of day thanks to the setting sun and that you miss the heat of the day. Went via the cable car which was 125HKD for the round trip, and the views of the sunset made it a bargain. You also get good views of the buddha as you approach. At this time of day there are no queues, but best to get to the cable car at 4:30 at the latest so you aren't cutting it too fine. Bring your zoom lens as well as your wide angle.

Wonderful views. We had very limited time to visit as this was our last day in Hong Kong so we didn't do a tour. We took the ferry from Central (Pier 6) to Lantau Island (HK$40.80 single trip) which took 30 mins on the fast ferry, then caught the bus (bus stop to Po Lin Monastery - HK$27 on a Sunday, cheaper on a week day) up to the monastery. We came back down on the cable car (approx HK$80 for the non glass bottom car) then the MTR which cost HK$25 back to Hong Kong Island. This proved to be a good move as the queues for the cable car were huge going up to the monastery. We got up there early and left by 1pm - we didn't have to queue for anything. The Buddha is the biggest I've ever seen and the views of the surrounding islands are amazing. Glad we managed to cram it in!

LARGEST OUTDOOR BUDDHA IN THE WORLD. This incredible Buddha is a sight that should not be missed. My brother and I traveled from Hong Kong and took the ferry to Lantau Island. When we got off the ferry boat we immediately purchased our tickets and took a scenic bus ride up a winding country road to the entrance of the monastery. The bus ride is quite scenic so have your camera ready and take a window seat on the bus. When we entered the main gate of the monastery you become so consumed with the size of the Buddha. One has to be in pretty good shape to walk up the 280 plus steps to be close to the Buddha. There is no charge to do this. If you decide to purchase a ticket to go inside the museum and go a little bit higher you will receive a coupon that you can redeem for a cold water and an ice cream treat after you have gone through the Buddha.The sights from this height are awesome. Hope for a day that has some wind so it can blow some of the air pollution out. We were fortunate that this was the case for us. As we arrived relatively early, I think we were ahead of the major air pollution that had not arrived as of 1 p.m.The grounds below are beautiful. Certainly, one can not miss this attraction if you are visiting Hong Kong. An attraction that I will never forget!

Quiet respite and good vegetarian food. A few short steps from the Big Buddha is the Po Lin Monastery. With grounds open to the public, you can walk around and appreciate the architecture and temple carvings. There are two vegetarian restaurants on the grounds and trinkets can be purchased which go back to the Monastery. We took the MTR to the Ngong Ping cable car up and the bus/ferry back to Hong Kong.

good views, an enormous buddah and interesting journey. 1st the much raved about vegetarian meal at the monastry. Ours was bland but the spring rolls were the best i have ever had. its a lot of food for 70HKD but it was not good.as we left i noticed that there appear to be a few menus, this was not explained nor offered. so check before you buy. perhaps we just had a bad experience. There is a cafe just next to the restaurant which appeared better than what we'd eaten.You can get to the island two ways (that i know of)1) the MTR to Tung Chen (or similar). This deposits you at the cable car (opens at 1000).2) The ferry from HK Island and then a BusWe did the MTR & cable car on the way and the bus and ferry on the way back.the views from the cable car were great & the views from the Ferry as you approach HK were also good.I would recommend you do as we did to mix it up a bit and get the best views.The MTR & cable car was quicker but also dearer.The Buddah and Monastry are interesting, the views from the Buddah are great.The village (so called) at the Monastry is really just a selection of tourist type shops

"Beast Vegetarian Meal money can buy". This is an "Awesome" place to visit. Serene and beautiful. We got deluxe vegetarian lunch at the monastery as it was recommended by tripadvisor reviews, it was out of this world. It was so good that even my three kids loved it. A must do in Hong Kong.
Lantau island big buddha. Must do. The vegetarian meal at po lin monastery was awesome. The low clouds and mists around the big buddha gave the effect of serenity, spirituality. Well worth a visit.
Very serene place. Great monastery!And great vegetarian food!Highly suggest you visit here after seeing the Giant Buddha.

Brilliant Bhudda - eat in the monastary cafe- instead of set menu in restaurant.. Took the cable car up to the village (not really a village, a collection of shops trying to sell souvenirs / snacks /lunch), monastary & bhudda.We missed all the restaurants (starbucks & the like) to have the 'famous' vegetarian lunch in the monastary - there is a choice of 2 set menus - the food was ok - but we should have eaten in the monastary cafe - same food but you can choose your own dishes and have a drink of your choice (not Chinese tea).Bhudda was excxellent - bit of a trek up stairs - but fantastic views from the top. Was built in the 1980s probably to bring tourists to the area.Other reviews mention free veggie food and tickets for the bhudda - during May 2012 no tickets for bhudda and no free food.

Fresh air, relaxing, good day trip. Took the bus on the way up, it was cheaper and had a nice trip up the hill. The Buddha statue was magnificient but you had to climb quite a number of stairs to reach the top. The entire monastery was quite huge so we had nice stroll, there is also free vegetarian food. Took the cable car on the way down, i find it too expensive, the price would put me off to visit the second time

Big Buddah & Po Lin Monastery = a great days outing!. It is worth the effort to visit this beautiful and peaceful site! The Cable car was closed for Maintenance when we were there recently but the sight of that huge Buddha sitting on top of the mountain is amazing no matter what your religious beliefs ... or how you get there! The setting is lovely and there are areas to burn incense offerings(if you choose to) and the temple itself is adorned with carvings, flowers, hangings and ritual instruments that are truly beautiful. Don't forget to look up at the wondeful paintings on the ceiling.You can take refreshments from the canteen while you sit outside and look at the painted wall that shows who has donated money for the upkeep/upgrading of the Temple and its surrounds(if you can read Chinese) or you can eat inside at the resturant.I think this area is a must see for everyone - a very spiritual place.

Beautiful day.. We visited the Monastery on out last day in Hong Kong since we had a midnight flight and the airport is very close. The taxi from the airport to the Big Buddha cost 180 HK dollars. The cable car wasn't working the day of our visit. The area around the monastery is very beautiful, i could spend hours walking. Of course they have taken advantage of the monastery and the Buddha, and various things are sold in stalls on the way to the monastery as well as at the shops at the village they have built. We went back to Tung Chung by bus, got off at the bus station and took the S1 bus to the airport.

Worth It. Absolutely worth the trip to Lantau Island to go here. The Giant Buddha is incredible, there are wonderful walking trails around it and the Monastery its self is gorgeous and peaceful. I went early in the day 8am, and it was not crowded, but when i left around 2pm there were hoards of buses arriving...so try to go early. Also, when I went the cable car was broken, so I had to take a bus there. The bus ride is a scenic, but the ride will probably make you quesy. Side note, don't ride a bike through the monastery, I did not, but there was some guy who did and the dogs at the monastery did not appreciate it and they chased him off the grounds. The dogs are actually very nice, and docile, they just don't seem to tolerate bicyclists on their grounds.
Peaceful and Grand. Lovely place to walk up to, after the cable car ride, and a brisk walk up to see the Buddha
Richest buddhist monks I've ever seen!. Monks with Rolex watches and driving fancy cars? That's new to me. I prefer Thailand by far. The Big Buddha was only built to cash on tourism.

Amazing escape from Hong Kong city. I visited Hong Kong with my sister in August of 2006 and our trip to Po Lin remains a standout. The bus trip to get there goes through some incredible scenery and the monastery and Buddha are incredible sights. We also opted for the famous vegetarian dining at the monastery, which was possibly the best meal I've ever had (and even my carnivorous sister was in raptures). I absolutely loved the metropolitan bustle of Hong Kong during our stay there, but this day was a memorable escape into some peacefully beautiful countryside.

Experience the culture. A must see if you are in Hong Kong. We visited the monastery as a package tour for the day. Included was early hotel pick up and drop off via bus to ferry. Lantau is very peaceful compared to the buzz of Hong Kong, so great if you'd like to get away from the crowds. Our bus tour guide was excellent, he had been doing the tour for many years and he shared a wealth of knowledge about Hong Kong, Lantau the fishing village and the monks and monastery. A vegetarian lunch was included in our day tour prepared at the monastery. Food was beautiful, very fresh. We returned from the big Buddha via the Ngong Ping 360 chairlift - amazing views from the monastery to the bus pick up on this 5.7klm ride. We were lucky on the trip down via the chairlift to have Ngong Ping 360 employee leaving work to ride with us - she shared so much information with us about the construction of the chairlift and other top attractions to catch while on our visit to Hong Kong. A really worthwhile trip. I highly recommend to include tour in your HK adventure.

Po Lin Monastery and Tian Tin Budha. I have always wanted to visit the Po Lin Monastery and the Great Budha statue since I have been coming to Hong Kong on business. Well this weekend I had that chance and regret not going sooner. The wait to get tickets is rather long. I wish I had gone online beforehand and book my ticket. That wold have made my wait much less painful.Once at the Po Lin village grab some refreshments and stay hydrated.A very nice day trip and recommend if you haven't done it before.

A must see!. Po Lin is definatey worth a visit. There is a smell of incense as you walk through which adds to the atmosphere. The main temple is beautifully decorated with three massive Buddhist statues and exquisite paintings on the ceiling and dragon carvings on the beams outside. I would recommend this attraction to anyone.

Beautiful but long day. The Po Lin monastery is beautiful. There is a giant buddha at the top of a very steep and big hill. You need to be able to walk about 200 steep steps to get to the head of the buddha. To get to the monastery, you can go by bus or now they have a tram which would definitely be the way to go. Not much to do up there but take pictures, eat local fare and ice cream. But definitely work seeing.

Buddha beautiful - shame about the touristy village. We went to Lantau island as part of a tour, primarily to see the Tian Tan large bronze Buddha. This was indeed very impressive and we were fortunate that the skies were relatively clear as it can be very hazy there. After our visit to the Buddha we had a reasonable vegetarian lunch in Po Lin Monastery and then made our way through a Disney-like village (a mini-theme park where the theme was Buddha!) to take the cable car ride down from Ngong Ping to Tung Chung. The ride was fun, with great views, and again we were fairly lucky with the weather. Our tour was for the day, we were taken over by ferry and had an excellent tour guide. I'm sure you could do this trip individually without too many problems but being part of a tour - we were a small group - was very fast and efficient, making the most of our time, and we had an excellent guide. We'd recommend a visit to this huge and impressive Buddha and the cable car ride is stunning and not to be missed.

Ain't no Buddha like a giant Buddha. A ferry from Victoria Harbor to the other side of Hong Kong in 30 mins, deport the vessel and onto a shuttle. Only for me, I made a small mistake but made sure I made it to see Po Lin. I realized during the ferry ride my flight time out of Hong Kong was earlier then I thought and we came to the harbor to get onto the bus, I didn't go as I debated to get back on the ferry and head back to make it to the airport. I sat at the harbor debating what I should do since the bus to Po Lin was already well on it's way there. I thought to myself, "you are so close, why would you go back....." When I finally decided not to be a party pooper, I hailed the next cab, got in the back, pulled out my map, pointed to Po Lin, explained I had very little time to go there (sigh language, smiles, airplane sign, time, and clock helped) to get my point across. My cabby took me all the way around the island to Po Lin, the giant Buddha. Hong Kong has beautiful beaches if you're in the right area, very quaint towns on your way to the attraction. You can the Buddha from the road in certain areas, and as soon as we pulled up, I asked the cabby to wait 5 mins so I can run, take photos, run back and go to the airport, he obliged. I ran up the stairs and took as many photos as I could all the way around Po Lin, lots of tourists but a great site to see none the less. After 5 mins, I ran back down the stairs, cabby was still waiting for me, hopped in and off to the airport we go only to find out, it's on the island as the Buddha and all we had to do was drive over the mountain so what a stellar decision to see it as it was well worth the spontaneous adventure. Massive Buddha.... Namaste.. Traveled Jan 09'

Shame about the building site. Nice temple - shame about the 10,000 buddha monastary China is asking for donations for behind it.
Does ruin the views and atmosphere slightly, but worth a go.
TOP TIP
Check out the vegetarian restaurant up there

Tian Tan Buddha & Po Lin Monastery. Incredible Buddha sitting atop a mountain top on Lantau Island. Take the scary gondola ride from the CityCenter Outlets to the monastery. It's the last stop on the MTR train after Disney Hong Kong. It's a 30 minute ride, but you won't be disappointed. Quick tip, if you use a Visa "Signature" card, you get a discount and extra pass into one of the exhibits. Save your money on the "glass bottom" gondola as you can pretty much see everything from the windows of the gondola.While we focused on visiting the Buddha and temple, there are other activities like eating with the monks. I'm told that you can have lunch in a shared table or by yourself. if you sit at a shared table you'll have the entire table eating all the food and picking through with their chopsticks. Personally, I don't want anyone elses chopsticks touching my food. We ate later in the day, however your entry fee to the bottom of the Buddha gives you a coupon good for a bottle of water and ice cream bar (which is much needed in the 90 degree heat).Buddha is absolutely incredible. While the walk up the steps is tough for those with asthma, its worth the effort. Lot's of gift shots and souvenir photo's of you getting on the gondola and off. They have the photo's, keychain, snow bubble already for you once you step off the gondola in either direction.Enjoy!
Worth visiting. This is well worth the visit. Just avoid weekends and public holidays as the wait is very long just to get on the cable cars. Good views on the cable car and at the top.

Tian Tan Buddha & Po Lin Monastery. A little bit of a hike up, but enjoyed the visit and sites from the top. A ticket to the Buddha includes a vegetarian lunch at the monastery which I had higher expectations for, but still enjoyed. The food didn’t taste like it was picked that morning, but more like it was store bought and canned. I enjoyed it never-the-less and it was a cheap option for lunch.

A nice alternative to HK Disneyland. If you have extra time in Hong Kong and want to see a little bit of the outskirts (and not HK Disneyland), you can check out the Po Lin Monastery where the world's largest outdoor sitting buddha statue is located. The monastery is located in Lantau Island (same place where HK Disneyland is), and can be conveniently reached by train, bus, and cable car. Take the MTR from Central all the way to Tung Chung station, then take the no. 23 bus from the station to the monastery or the cable car. The bus is a comfortable tourist bus and costs about HK$17 per person. Note that the buses are behind the shopping center in front of the Tung Chung railway station. The trip to the monastery took about 45 minutes, but the roads are good and scenic. Those who are in a hurry opt to take the cable car, but the line is usually long. Entrance ticket to the Big Buddha is about HK$30, which entitles you to have a look-see at the first floor of the museum inside the buddha statue as well as a free ice cream. You can pay extra to see the second floor and to get a vegetarian meal at the top of the buddha statue. The view from the Big Buddha platform are amazing. The monastery is a short distance from the stairs to the Big Buddha, and is marked by this huge gate.You can then take the cable car back to Tung Chung station. The cable car station is inside the Ngong Ping village just outside the monastery grounds, where you could buy some souvenirs. There is also a "wishing tree" where people leave their wishes with the hope of them being granted. The cable car ride to the Tung Chung station costs about HK$60 for a normal cabin (more expensive for the glass-bottomed cabin for the more adventurous types), and the view is spectacular! The cable car trip will only take about 15 minutes. You can then take the MTR back to Hong Kong island or wherever you are staying.

Worth it for the cable car ride!. Giant buddha is a spectacular site in itself but access via cable car from Tung Chung makes it even more worthwhile. On a clear day, views from cable car are first class. Po Lin Monastery is quaint but a lot of shops around are very touristy. Meal in monastery refectory is very cheap, wholesome but will be far more than you can eat and is served a la soup kitchen style! Never-the-less the whole package - cable car, big buddha, monastery - does make an interesting day out.

Give it a miss. Took the cable car last year and enjoyed the ride with great views but should have stayed on and not got off at the top.A rather tacky tourist complex greets you and after spending a few minutes walking through it with not one place enticing us in we headed for the Budha. With a hot sticky climb up and a ice cream at the top we had had enough, we decided to skip the Monastery and we headed back to the cable car. Unless your a budhist or into temples I would skip this attraction especially if you are on a tight schedule as there are to many other intersting things in Hong Kong to see.

Quite Magical. Set off from HK a beautiful crossing, make sure you are first off the ferry or you will have to stand up on the bus and also have the right change $ 12 each. The temple is quite breathtaking some wonderful photos can be taken from the temple looking up to the Budha. Walk up the stair to the Budha - do not be tempted to take the shuttle bus as you are supposed to gain enlightenment , I got very hot and thirsty!! The Budha is amazing and the museum inside air conditioned. You also get a bottle of water and a free ice-cream as part of the admission cost! It was a great day out, very hot but wonderful. A must if you are visiting Hong Kong

Awesome!. We visited Po Lin in March 2007. It was an amazing experience. We gotthere via the underground and then bus number 23. Be sure to take thebus if you want to arrive there before it's overrun with tourists. Also, a lady who seemed to be working for the cable car operator tried to confuse us telling us we should wait in line for the cable car to start operating rather than taking the bus. The bus is half the price for a return trip and by taking the bus we arrived at the monestary when it opened.

A wonderful experience. The trip to Lantau Island to see the Buddha was something we would never have missed. It's official title is the 'Largest Bronze Sitting Buddha in the World'! It just blows you away when you first see it.We took the ferry from Hong Kong Island to Lantau and then the bus up to the monastery. Be prepared for climbing what seems like millions of steps! You actually go inside the buddha and it's actually very poignant and spiritual whatever your religion.There is a gift shop at the bottom and you also get a vegetarian lunch from the monastery itself which was delicious.The monks go about their business in complete harmony with all the tourists hovering around and they are happy to chat and answer questions.A word of advice - take a 'fast ferry' to the Island - it only takes about 45 mins, but the regular ferries seemed to take hours! They alternate the services, so it's worth waiting for the fast ones each time.All in all a brilliant day!

It's a Big Bhudda alright. A fair way to spend half a day, a trip out to Lantua and the Po Lin was interesting and enjoyable. We took the ferry out from HK island, and had a very enjoyable walk back down through the woods to Tung Chung to get the MTR back into Kowloon. An easy route to follow with great views, it takes a couple of hours. The monastery itself was interesting and the big bhudda, well it was impressive I must say. We really enjoyed it but I wouldn't say it was unmissable, unlike a trip on the Peak Tram.
